39.description: It caught my eye as I biked past one day, then I checked reviews and confirmed that it was what it looked like, a legit Italian local sandwich place. They make everything fresh, so it takes some time. The sandwiches are huge, easily enough for two meals, and they are very reasonably priced, like the big sandwich places in Little Italy in New York. There are several interesting options, even for people who aren't that into deli meats. The meatball sub was very good. They do sandwiches, panini, and I think they had wraps, too. It also has a bunch of Italian cooking ingredients, imported and not, and they cram quite a bit into the small store. There's a little area outside where one can eat, when the weather allows.

37.description: Another reason to love this wonderful place? Fresh Turkeys!  We have had our Thanksgiving turkey from here for the past 6 years.  Mike gets them from Kaufmann Farms in Northern, IL and they are delicious.  Order now!

0.description: We have ordered from their 2 times. Great service. First time we ordered the man said when he delivered "thank you so much for your business we truly appreciate it." So nice! Favorites we have tried Minestrone soup. So tasty full of flavor and veggies. Milano sandwich- yum!Tortellini tomato soup- tastes like a combination of tomato soups u might have had growing up. But so good. Wouldn't order again- lobster bisque and guacamole (probably not the best place to order this lol)

38.description: Great sandwiches. Nice cold deli combinations.

51.description: This is an amazing deli. The homemade soups and sandwiches are fantastic. The deli meats and cheeses are sold for some of the best prices in Chicago. They also sell great coffee for reasonable prices. The owner, Mike is over the top kind. He gives my kiddos cheese while we wait for our order. In the summer, we pick up sandwiches and head to the lakefront!

27.description: Wonderful, awesome, delicious! We had a team of 25 girls and placed our orders the night before. They were ready when we got there and all individually marked with the girls names. All of our orders were made to order perfectly. The girls loved all the food they ordered and were very pleased with the size of their subs/wraps/panini. Highly recommend!

32.description: This place is the BOMB.  Oh my gosh.  First time eating there was today.  I ordered two sandwiches to-go: the Grainder and the Big Easy.  Both were PHENOMENAL! The chips they have are GMO free and gluten free and absolutely delicious!!!! I ordered 2 twelve inch sandwiches and a 5 oz bag of chips.  Total was like $18 for everything.  The sandwiches were incredible.  Flavorful, full of quality ingredients.  Everything tasted fresh and delicious.  Mmmmmm.I give everything I ate an A+ and the staff especially were friendly and pleasant.  I also love the selection of imported goods.  So many delicious drinks and snacks from Italia.  YUM!Definitely try this place if you are a sandwich lover. MMMMMMMM!

54.description: Completely wonderful! I ordered delivery from here today and everything was fantastic and very well priced! I will most definitely be ordering from here again!

48.description: Piatto Pronto is an excellent small Italian deli, which stocks a variety of essentials for the Italian kitchen. They have a full selection of meats from imported Italian prosciutto and capicola to many different kinds of cheeses and canned products. They even stock Volpi brand sausage and meat, which is the creator's gift to the sausage world. Need olives? This place is way cheaper than some of the big grocery store olive bars. (That's right Whole Foods, I'm talking about you.) Plus, they are nicely nestled behind glass so you don't have to worry about that random guy who sneezes over the whole olive bar during cold and flu season. In the freezer section, you will find freshly made pastas and soups, so skip the long Red Line trip to Eataly and go to Piatto Pronto if you are in the neighborhood.

44.description: When I say Chicago it's my kind of town, I refer to shops like Piatto Pronto. I could tell the minute I walked in that it was full of authenticity (unlike the coffee shop next store).  The guys working there were great, and were the typical rough Chicago personalities, you know that rough edge people get when dealing with winters here, who are actually really awesome. The sandwich I got, the turkey panino was very good, but if I were to do it all over again I would just ask for their recommendation (anything without pork, since I don't eat it). Come in, you won't be disappointed, just don't sit by the coffee shop to eat your sandwich because they will come out to tell you it's against their policy. (Actually, the coffee shop is pretty good, just not full of authenticity, with more of an engineered feel).

24.description: Consistent high quality of ingredients and preparation. Friendly, helpful service. Wonderful selection of specialty foods. Taking home some of the wonderful cold cuts from the cooler is rivaled only by the best NY delis. Killer sandwiches!!

7.description: Good bread, but there's no meat in these sandwiches. Service was slow and distracted. Too many better options in the neighborhood to waste any money here.

49.description: If you order a sandwich from this place be prepared to be blown away by not only the taste, but the pure amount you get! The service is amazing with their work ethic and their attitude. You pay $6 for a sandwich that is enough for myself, an 18 year old athletic boy, to eat a little over half of it and have the rest as a snack or for dinner!

40.description: Trekked out here last saturday in search of a pastrami sandwich, and ended up finding something better.The "New Yorker" with pastrami came with lettuce, tomato, and cheese (and mayo or mustard)....so a pretty far cry from the pastrami on rye I was looking for, but on the toasted bread it was still enjoyable.We tried the highly recommended dolce di parma (prosciutto, pesto, fresh mozz, sun dried tomatoes) and killed the 12" sandwich.   Much, much better - and next time I'd ask for the bread on the dolce di parma to be pressed beforehand too!

53.description: Great service, diverse and fresh selection of meats, cheese, salads, BEST sandwiches on the north side of Chicago (kids agree). I heartily recommend Piatto Pronto. We go every week to buy prosciutto for school sandwiches!

30.description: This place is OUTSTANDING!!! I can't say enough. It is the best food I have had delivered in Rogers Park hands down. Everything was good. If you are in RP or Andersonville you must grab some.

46.description: This is an Italian grocery/deli sandwich shop, densely packed w/coolers along one wall, narrow aisles full of imported dry goods, and a counter/case full of meats, cheeses & breads. I've only bought sandwiches here. I like to try new things, but every time I come here, it's hard for me not to get a Dolce di Parma, quite possibly the perfect Italian sandwich. This place rivals any other deli/sandwich shop in the city, hands down. They also have a variety of bottled craft sodas, some of which I've never seen anywhere else. Prices aren't the cheapest, but the quality is well worth it. Highly recommended!

1.description: At times, I am late to the party, UNBELIEEEEVABLY late. My inattention to Piatto Pronto falls into the late to the party category. WHAT TOOK ME SO LONG?Good Grief!A friend and I were looking for some wondrous, flavorful, soup to be included in our delivery order. Not such an easy task. Except, Piatto Pronto has soups galore. This establishment offers 23 (TWENTY-THREE) different types of soups on the menu. I a listing a few here to spotlight the diversity: Lobster Bisque, Italian Wedding, Chicken Poblano Pepper, Vegetarian Lentil, Cream of Potato Soup with Bacon, Tomato Florentine, and White Chicken Chili Soup with Beans. At the time of our order these soups could be delivered in 16 or 32 oz. portions. We tried two and they were both fantastic! We also ordered a salad and dessert to round out the order. The salad had extremely fresh ingredients and also was served in a large portion.Our dessert was huge! Certainly enough for two. I was impressed. The salad was out of this world. The soups, marvelous. Piatto Pronto, where have you been all of my life?

55.description: Used to think this place was the bee's knees but it's usually too busy and disorganized to order more than a single sandwich. On multiple occasions I've had my sandwich order messed up and they're never friendly about exchanging it for the right order - almost always acting as if the mistake was my fault.The owner also seems like kind of a hot-head. I won't be back. Unimpressed. Too many other great options in the neighborhood.

9.description: One of my sandwiches had mold on the cheese! eek

26.description: The following is what the Piatto Pronto scene looks like.  You walk into an Italian grocery store and place your sandwich order at the front counter.  Carbonated drinks, teas, juice, coffee and beer are in the back refrigerator.  It took 5 minutes to get our order and grab seats outside on the benches in front, where other customers are munching on their food.  The sandwiches were so good that the 6" and 12" subs were gone within 15 minutes, split among two people.  All the ingredients tasted very fresh, and the highly recommended dolce di parma lived up to all the positive reviews. Very tasty prosciutto, and the combination of fresh mozzarella, sun dried tomatoes, pesto, etc. was a marriage made in heaven.  It is the discovery of places like these that really makes me love Yelp!

25.description: Coming here for the first time, I can see that this is a very different type of place to order food to go than what I am used to. I came in for a look and I was surprised to see the interior. Of course there was a line inside ordering what they want. As I wait for my order,  I can see that there are chips, drinks, and anything else you can buy that is indeed imported from Italy, since they were written in Italian, as well as there were people inside that were speaking to the guy taking the orders in Italian. But most importantly, once I got to eat my subs that I ordered, they were very delicious. They very much live up to the hype that is given to this ethnic deli. Somehow, just writing this review makes me craving to go back there, the food is very mouth-friendly. I definitely recommend this place to anyone who wants to try a new experience in restaurants.

12.description: Best sandwiches! What a great little sandwich shop.  I'll be telling all my friend about it.

59.description: I tried a couple of sandwiches here for lunch today and they were great. I had the Il Milano and my brother tried the Dolce di Parma. They both fit the bill of what you look for in a Italian deli sandwich. I was not the biggest fan of the bread, but I'm picky with bread and it got the job done. They did not skimp out on what was between the bread which is how it should be and the ingredients were of great quality.Like others have said, they are really nice here too. I just popped in for the sandwiches but would definitely check out the plethora of other gourmet looking imported stuff too.

21.description: I love sandwiches and theirs is no exception. they're fresh and ingredients are very tasty.  I get one for my ravinia picnic every year.

17.description: The sandwiches are fresh, great and can't wait to come back again.  Service great too!

10.description: Piatta Pronto is a gem, in the Andersonville community. The selection is fantastic, the price is right and the sandwiches are always tasty. But what sets them apart is their friendly service. I usually go up with my kids, and they always treat them special. I am glad Piatta Pronto calls my community its home!

5.description: Inviting sandwich place, friendly service, but I got food poisoning from this place. I may give it another try some day but for now I have to stay away.

3.description: Whenever im in the area, i love getting sandwiches from Piatti Pronto. I usually get the Italian, but the roast beef is also delicious. At roughly $6.50 for a 12 inch plus sandwich, you cant go wrong.

35.description: Wanted something different for lunch today and an Italian sub sounded good, so after some yelping decided to head over for a meatball sub.I give the Meatball sub a solid B+.  Bread was very fresh and soft.  Marinara tasted of fresh tomatoes.  Actual meatballs were homemade and awesome.  Sandwich was quite large; could only finish about 3/4.  Sandwich topped with sliced mozzarella.Beware of F-BOMB Central, though.  I'm not sure if the owner has Tourette's or what, but every word out of his mouth was F-this and F-that and that F-in guy.  There were some regulars in the store ahead of me.  He obviously had camaraderie with them and felt he could speak his mind.  It didn't bother me, but I can see where other people might be offended.  Dude, tone it down a little.Will definitely be back to sample additional I-talian subs.

19.description: Every lunch from here has been a great lunch. And you can browse and buy some chocolate while you wait for your sandwich.

28.description: How did I not know about this place!! We just had lunch delivered today and we barely spoke to each other. Lots of ummph and oh my gods ! Fresh , delicious and at such a good price!! Cannot wait to try the rest of the menu!

45.description: Delivery was fast, food was fresh and very good.  Sandwiches are big enough for 2 means.  Everything home made.  I am a fan and will be ordering again.

33.description: I ordered through grubhub 2 large 32oz soups and 2 small 16oz soups. I received 3 small and one large, so I paid extra for one that I got in a small instead of a large. Also, there were no spoons in the bag. All of that soup and no spoons?? They soups were good though.

43.description: The Cuban sandwich is packed full pork and ham, and for under $10, this is great for this area of Chicago.The rest of the food here is A-OK.

2.description: Horrible food. Too many better options in the area to waste my time or money here. Sandwiches were tasteless and the service was horrible. Staff has a bad attitude. I also got food poisoning from this place. Buyer beware.. avoid this crappy establishment  at all costs!

18.description: I have gone time and time again for the Dolce Di Parma and pickle chips. Best sandwich on the menu. I get their homemade pesto too which is great to have on hand.They have really good dips for my book club too. I have never had a bad experience food wise or with the staff. They are very nice. I will say though, one time, I was there and they were taking out the garbage in the back and I could smell it which was really unappetizing. I know they have to take it out but if I can smell it up front, probably means they need to take it out in a more timely manner.

41.description: We ordered 2 soups, and an Amy's special on rye. The "Rye" tasted like some weird fruit bread (ate it without), and the soup was awful, tasted fermented. I gave it 2 stars, because I believe the sandwich would have been great minus the bread choice. Probably won't order again

52.description: I love Piatto Pronto.  It is my go to for lunch at least 2x per week when I am in town.  Mike and Heche make a great sandwich and you don't break the bank going there.  The soups are delicious as are the meatballs.  Great selection of imported olive oil and pasta at a great price.

50.description: I only just recently became a fan of prosciutto after going to Eataly with my roomie. I've been craving an Italian sub with the stuff and fresh mozz ever since. Piatto Pronto definitely did not disappoint. If you get the full side sandwich, you'll have 2 meals out of it so it's definitely worth the value. Roomie and I also enjoyed browsing the other European groceries the store had to offer. She nearly had a heart attack when she found the same peach tea she had preciously only found in Italy. We also left with lingonberry jam and another pile of prosciutto. I wish I lived closer; I'd be here all the time!

4.description: Great food, and great service. My wife and I visit this deli at least 3 times a month, on the way home from work.   Highly recommended. I am aware if the recent publicity..and have come to the following conclusion.I don,t care. :)  Mike can wear what ever he wants to.   If you don't like it..do not go.. Simple really.See you soon Mike !

6.description: I work in the area and frequent this place for lunch and am never disappointed. My favorite sandwich is probably the Dolce di Parma, but I've had quite a number of their sandwiches and panini and they're all amazing. BIG sandwiches, too, no matter what size you order!The staff is super friendly and service is very quick. Definitely one of the best delis/sandwich shops around.

22.description: Best sandwiches ever!! We love the veggie and prosciutto sandwiches. So delicious, fresh ingredients. Mike, the owner, is so welcoming and the store has great specialty items.  Worth a visit, you will come back again and again.

15.description: This place is the BOMB.  Oh my gosh.  First time eating there was today.  I ordered two sandwiches to-go: the Grainder and the Big Easy.  Both were PHENOMENAL! The chips they have are GMO free and gluten free and absolutely delicious!!!! I ordered 2 twelve inch sandwiches and a 5 oz bag of chips.  Total was like $18 for everything.  The sandwiches were incredible.  Flavorful, full of quality ingredients.  Everything tasted fresh and delicious.  Mmmmmm.I give everything I ate an A+ and the staff especially were friendly and pleasant.  I also love the selection of imported goods.  So many delicious drinks and snacks from Italia.  YUM!Definitely try this place if you are a sandwich lover. MMMMMMMM!

57.description: An excellent sandwich shop. I get the Napolitano here regularly and sometimes I'll pick up a few other grocery items while I'm there. Their deli meats and cheeses are good quality and reasonable prices. Their Italian prepared foods from the fridge (soups, lasagna, etc) are also good quality. Also some of the best cannoli I've had in Chicago. They also have grocery items like eggs and milk. It's usually a little cheaper to get those other things at a full grocery store, but for a convenient corner grocer they're pretty reasonable.

20.description: What a great little local Italian delicatessen. A wonderful selection of pasta is from Italy. There to  to go sandwiches are made fresh. Are a great way for lunch option. Mike is there to serve you. Please note closes early seven or 8 PM most days

36.description: I ordered some soups, a sandwich and some drinks. It took over 2hrs. Tried calling them, But couldn't understand them and they were very rude and standoffish. Bad customer service, unfortunately never ordering from here again.

14.description: Excellent sandwiches, Italian cheeses, olives, and more. A gem in Andersonville.

28.description: This store has been here for many years and it looks the same as it did way back then.  Over crowded shelves, too much product, narrow aisles, overworked butchers and lazy cashiers.  OK, they aren't lazy, just moving in slow motion.I like that they offer many varieties of Asian products, its a quick stop when you're in the need of something specific like chili hot sauce or a flavor of Soy.  They also offer different options when it comes to their butcher area, did you know that you can order your fish and then have them fry it for you also?I like that they have a special price on fish heads and tails. Not for me! For the dogs living at my house.  Fish is good for them and they don't charge you up the ass like some other butcher stores.  You can also usually find a good price on select meats and small fishes.  Again, I am super picky about the freshness of meat for myself, so I don't buy that from here for me.  For the dogs, sure, I'll get anything.  I picked up pork necks at 60 cents a pound the other day.  Some time ago I was in here with my Mom and we're nearing the checkout counter.  I'm thinking hmm, I wonder what Filipino candies might be waiting near the counter.  I wasn't surprised to find Nurse's uniforms on display, I knew my Ma was interested, so I let her get two new uniform tops.  She said to me, "This is the good material, it comes from Philippines.  I dunno if it does or not, these nurses uniforms were expensive.   There's a food area where you can get some everyday Filipino favorites.  Check it out if you're daring.

1.description: Went here for tamarind seasoning mix and ended up with that and a load of sweets. It hasn't set yet, a little soupy. Cassava cake was excellent, should've gotten 2. They had every kind of Skyflakes, except the original which is what I prefer. I didn't get anything in the cafe, but I will next time. The cashier was friendly.

9.description: Uni-Mart is located in my neighborhood and it's greatly convenient. I'm fan of the place. I love their home cooked food to take out. I don't know much about Filipino food but I see many similarity in Okinawan food, the ingredient, and cooked way. Especially vegetable dishes. It's Interesting.

29.description: When I'm craving some home cooking but have no desire to cook, I go here.  They have a small area in the back set up similar to a Panda Express where you order entrees ala carte.  You can almost always find lechon (roasted pork), lumpia (mini meat egg rolls), turon (banana egg rolls doused in melted sugar, TRY this!), chicken and pork bbq, and at least five other dishes.  They also have tables of other baked goods.  Never get the longonisa (sweet sausage) unless you enjoy biting into huge chunks of fat.  You're better off buying the frozen variety in the freezer (and for a lot cheaper).  The food is ok for a quick fix but definitely doesn't compare to anything my parents would cook (isn't this always the case).  Prices for the prepared food are fairly reasonable.  I've easily gotten enough food to feed 4 for roughly $20-25.Beyond the prepared foods, you can buy an assortment of other Filipino goods: prepared sauces, noodles, rice, frozen egg rolls, frozen meats, etc.  They also have a small variety of 'fresh' fish and vegetables.  The interior is fairly clean, but the aisles are a bit too close for comfort.  I tend to go on the weekends and the parking lot is always jam packed, yet it is still fairly easy to maneuver  yourself around the store.  Prices are pretty average.  Service is minimal but adequate.

23.description: Need to bring lumpias (aka FIlipino mini-eggrolls) to bring to your next family event? I'd suggest going to Uni-Mart - basically, the staple grocery store of most Filipino families living on the north side of the city.  They sell lumpias in the ready-made food section ($7.50/lb for about 25-30) as well as a variety of other Filipino dishes (turon, adobo, caldereta, lechon, bbq chicken, etc.).  If you want to place a larger order, you can always place the order a couple days ahead of time, so they can have it ready for pick-up right before your event.Plus, the grocery section basically has every FIlipino food items you could ever look for (shrimp chips, shrimp paste, pancit noodles, salted egg, pan de sal, calamansi juice, etc.). You can also buy frozen lumpias and then fry them yourself, if you're up to dealing with that daunting task.  I picked up $80 worth of food here for Thanksgiving and it was enjoyed by all! Note: They don't take Amex, but they do take personal checks. The parking lot may have the tendency to fill up on weekends and it's pretty difficult to maneuver around in because it's a little small.  Oh, and they apparently give you a free bottle of sweet and sour sauce with purchases over $50....Cute!

5.description: This place definitely fix my Filipino food cravings that I can't cook such as Laing, Chicharon Bulaklak, Okoy, Liempo, and Palabok!!!I think their Palabok is to die for... There's really not a good place to get it unless you're at your Titas or Lola's house. The chicharon bulaklak & Okoy are soooooooooo good. Reminds me of my childhood. Definitely go get some! If they don't have it they will cook it for you! The things they sell are aighttt. It's pricey so I normally get my longaniza, malungay, and wrappers at Viet hoa on argyle. Overall this place I worth going to! Do the box instead of the to go containers. So much better!

31.description: I went to the Unimart branch in Chicago, food was way to greasy and lacks flavor. Although they have the most variety of dry goods as well as they carry their own line of pastries, still does not capture the true Filipino taste I grew up with (eg. Goldilocks, Red Ribbon). I tried the Woodridge location, food was a little better but not great. Also not sure how long the mamon (sponge cake) was sitting on the shelves coz after a day I bought it was spoiled right away. Definitely not going back.

25.description: Okay, so 100th review I've reserved for sentimentality.  I love Uni-Mart and miss Uni-Mart.  It reminds me of childhood, driving to the market with Mom and Dad and picking out our favorite ingredients to make the most amazing Filipino dishes.  I can hear the clinking of pots and pans and the chopping of fresh vegetables now.  It also reminds me of my adulthood, living on my own, and feeling the perfect elation and freedom of gaining personal space, the freedom of being in my neighborhood of choice, and the freedom to do whatever I wish in my kitchen -- creating that familiar symphony of kitchen sounds with my own two hands, my own sense of taste and smell, but the tradition of family secrets.  Being walking distance from Uni-Mart was an amazing luxury that lasted a short, but much-appreciated time.  They have everything I need to mirror my mom and grandma's best.  And if I don't feel particularly kitchen savvy, they have deliciously prepared Filipino favorites in the back like pancit, kare kare, crispy pata, and humongous, tasty egg rolls!  I regret that I live so far from Uni-Mart now, but I can easily get back into the car (with me driving this time, instead of Dad).  No matter how far, it'll always be close to my heart.Salamat, po!

12.description: I have not tried the ready-to-eat food at their "restaurant" in back, but will review that when I do.  I've gone in a few times for some small items that are keeping me from making a good curry or something at home.  This is very close to me, so it's good for a quick stop for some rice vinegar, coconut milk, soy sauce...that kind of stuff.  I was looking for arugula once and the three store employees I spoke to didn't know what it was and kind of followed me around looking to be explained what I was talking about.  I'll chalk it up to their attention to pleasing the customer, but yeah...don't go there thinking you'll get some good, fresh produce.  Their frozen selection is also pretty good for wonton/pot sticker wraps and other goodies.  If you have time to go to Golden Pacific market down on Broadway, I'd go there.  If you don't, then this is your spot.  I'm sure their hot food is a great incentive for some to go in, and I'm excited to try some!

21.description: Uni-Mart is the only major Filipino food grocer in Chicago proper, and that's the primary reason why you should come here. It features fresh fish, vegetables, tropical drinks, a good assortment of Filipino/Asian snacks and chips (my favorite are the flavored shrimp crackers), prepackaged baked goods, Pocky, frozen meats (wait...they sell a chicken tocino? Really?) and...a hot food bar. It is most easily accessible by the Clark St. (#22) CTA bus or by car. There is a private parking lot....I should sound more enthused about Uni-Mart but I'm...not...because I frequent better and cheaper Filipino food marts in the suburbs.I don't like Uni-Mart's hot food items. The lumpia is bland and the saucy barbeque on a stick tastes like a dessert because they put WAY too much sugar in the sauce. I've had the other food items here and they weren't really worth mentioning.I do commend Uni-Mart for its SIOPAO (think of a bao, a white flour dough ball encasing pork adobo, chicken or red bean, that's the size of an adult man's fist). Siopao is a great "baon" (brown-bag lunch) item.

16.description: There are a few other area Filipino food marts, but this is the one i remember being dragged to as a little girl. The funny thing is that even after 15 years, this place still smells exactly the same. My husband and I come here now a least once a month to stock up on jasmine rice, seasonings, sauces, longaniza and lumpia rolls. He loves coming here. This is pretty much the only place i will ever buy my rice from. Just keep in mind that the parking lot can be hard to maneuver on busy days.

17.description: Yet another place in Chicago that I have managed to negate until recently... and I'm mad at myself for it. I stopped by this afternoon, as some friends of mine kept talking about Filipino food and the cravings slowly surfaced. There is a parking lot which is convenient. The 'market' area looks like it would be larger from the outside but it's just a couple aisles of Asian necessities - you know: halo halo mix, shrimp chips, and macapuno ice cream! lol. Definitely reminiscent of the Filipino markets back home in L.A., and it was a bit comforting for a homesick soul. I lurked around the food selection in the back for a few minutes before deciding on getting menudo (beefy dish) which was really good, but a bit pricey for a small serving (which could be split by two). I liked the fact that the menudo had bongongong (sp?! lol) as I've never had it like that; just wish there was olives in it like the recipes back home. I think there was also a hotdog in there LOL so I'm not sure if that was intentional or not. I also ordered a small side of the bisteak (beef & onions) which again was a little expensive for a small, but definitely enough to feed two. Small side of rice was marginally priced.

10.description: After stuffing myself silly during a recent trip to see family in the Philippines, one would think I'd be tired of Filipino food, right? Yeah I thought so too. I was kind of craving some treats and "close enough" home-cooked meals. I was a little disappointed to not find my favorite brand of hopia, and the ready-made meals were looking kind of blah, esp. the chicken adobo. I blame myself for getting there near closing time, which most likely counts for that. I got an order of pancit bihon. The woman behind the counter was like almost every Filipino mom I know (incl. mine). She gave me a rather hearty helping of pancit to go. Um. I guess I'll be eating that for a week? Best part of this story? I also ended up cooking a batch of adobo once I got home...as if I wouldn't have enough to eat.

11.description: Lumpia, pancit, lechon, etc. Uni-Mart is one stop shopping for all your Filipino foodie desires.  I've always had an easy time ordering for parties and other events, and the food is always delicious.

26.description: Unimart rocks!  For your longaniza cravings and addiction, Unimart comes through.  Longaniza is sometimes referred to as the filipino version of chorizo, but it's sweet instead.  About 1" in diameter, the casings are wound so that you have a bunch of 3-4" sausages bound together that you can fry up in a pan and serve with your eggs and Jasmine rice.  It makes for quite a hearty breakfast.Sorry, I know...this isn't a Food Network blog!  Unimart has a decent selection of filipino foods, candy with fun labels at the checkout, and they serve great hot food to go.  If you're lucky to be there when eggrolls are of avail, GET SOME!  They are big, full of cabbage, pork and other assorted veggies.  Generally, filipino food isn't super-spicy, so the timid sha'nt be afraid to try the various dishes...kare kare...crispy pork...fried fish...menudo...  But, if you're a vegetarian, you might have a challenge finding something at the hot food stand.  Also, many dishes are of the gnaw-on-the-bone nature.I had their pancit once and remember liking it, but never since because Jil's mom makes the best pancit ever.  Thirty Helen's agree!!!

27.description: Sometimes after my Sat morn session of bball, I'm too exhuasted (lazy) to go home and put meat between 2 pieces of bread.  So en route home, I would stop by the cafeteria in the back of uni-mart.  I usually get the lechon (roast pig), fried fish, or menudo (flip style chilli).  The lechon costs about $8 a slab and comes with I believe liver sauce.  It's quite interesting how this sweet liver sauce condiments this crispy pork (I think I made a new verb).  I don't usually bother with the lumpia and chicken adobo because it's not that great.        Since I'm already there, I pick up some items like frozen longanisa sausage and pineapple soda.  BTW, the bibingka sold here is not really bibingka.  And I always check to see if they have banana ketchup, but  they only have banana sauce.  I want to make some filipino (Jollibee) style spaghetti but they never have the thicker, sweeter ketchup I'm looking for.      Anyway, one time I checked out with lechon, a cup of rice, and some groceries.  I went home, and took a few bites.  To my dismay, I realized that I just paid $7 for plain rice because the caf lady labeled it wrong.  $7 is not much, but out of principle,  I could not enjoy my meal knowing that I paid that much for a cup of rice.  I don't think there is a single Asian person in the world that would pay that much for rice coming out of grocery store.   Besides, my mom's voice was giving me a guilt trip.  So, I did my 1 minute commute, explained the situation, got an apology, and I told them, "Just pay me the difference in lumpia."

0.description: Based solely on the Ube Sans Rival dessert that they sell here.  I WANT THIS EVERY DAY OF MY LIFE.Aside from this, the place is dingy, but has everything and anything you need to satisfy your Filipino food needs.

20.description: Their to go food bar was actually pretty good.  However, their food selection was limited.  Wish they were bigger.

19.description: Came here per recommendation of my coworker Nett B. cos I asked her where to buy Balikbayan boxes.Giving only 3 stars just because the boxes are $3.99 versus RC in Skokie's $3.29.Note: I tried going at 7:20pm on a Thursday and they looked like they were closed for some time and busy cleaning up, so the hours posted on yelp might be outdated.

2.description: A delightful spot in Edgewater. They have a full Filipino butcher meat and fish counter. They also do catering on this site. Home style kitchen for takeout and eat in. Also feature frozen Filipino imports. A lot it import beverages .Assorted bakery and candy items. Nice staff. A cut above in the Asian market game.

18.description: I was craving macapuno (baby coconut) ice cream and was pleasantly surprised to find it (in HUGE tin containers) at Uni-Mart.  Wow wow wow.  This stuff might be better than the fresh stuff I used to get at Mitchell's in San Francisco (that's saying a LOT).  The chunks of coconut are sort of sugary grated globs of coconut.  Can you spell cavities?  But it's SO worth it.One thing to note: There is a place that sells the same thing for $2 cheaper on Argyle St...though it's farther for me, so worth it to shop here.

13.description: The best time to visit Uni-Mart is a Saturday morning.  The place bustles with activity and laughter of friends gathering and shopping, and the hot food bar is packed with every Filipino dish you could ever want.  The food sells by the pound and is usually grabbed up by 2pm.   Get here later than that and all you will find is a greasy mess of leftovers, so consider yourself warned!

4.description: Definitely have a wide variety of choices and tastes! The workers are kind and prices are very affordable. I took my family here when they came to visit me from New Jersey. They liked the food. They need to bring some CEBUANO - STYLE Lechon here ! ;)

24.description: I was craving macapuno (baby coconut) ice cream and was pleasantly surprised to find it (in HUGE tin containers) at Uni-Mart.  Wow wow wow.  This stuff might be better than the fresh stuff I used to get at Mitchell's in San Francisco (that's saying a LOT).  The chunks of coconut are sort of sugary grated globs of coconut.  Can you spell cavities?  But it's SO worth it.One thing to note: There is a place that sells the same thing for $2 cheaper on Argyle St...though it's farther for me, so worth it to shop here.

6.description: They have the full assortment of Filipino groceries and bakery items, as well as an excellent take-out counter (many choices of freshly-prepared dishes).  Yes, the store looks old, and yes, you will likely wait in line for a little bit, but so what?  The place has character, the workers are friendly, the prices are reasonable, and the food is fantastic.  Do yourself a favor and try an order of their pork adobo.

22.description: Philippine treat goodbanana lumpias yumPockey for sale

15.description: Need to bring lumpias (aka FIlipino mini-eggrolls) to bring to your next family event? I'd suggest going to Uni-Mart - basically, the staple grocery store of most Filipino families living on the north side of the city.  They sell lumpias in the ready-made food section ($7.50/lb for about 25-30) as well as a variety of other Filipino dishes (turon, adobo, caldereta, lechon, bbq chicken, etc.).  If you want to place a larger order, you can always place the order a couple days ahead of time, so they can have it ready for pick-up right before your event.Plus, the grocery section basically has every FIlipino food items you could ever look for (shrimp chips, shrimp paste, pancit noodles, salted egg, pan de sal, calamansi juice, etc.). You can also buy frozen lumpias and then fry them yourself, if you're up to dealing with that daunting task.  I picked up $80 worth of food here for Thanksgiving and it was enjoyed by all! Note: They don't take Amex, but they do take personal checks. The parking lot may have the tendency to fill up on weekends and it's pretty difficult to maneuver around in because it's a little small.  Oh, and they apparently give you a free bottle of sweet and sour sauce with purchases over $50....Cute!

7.description: I tried really hard to love unimart, but there's so many things about it that annoy me. Food is great, taste is great, but service is sooooo incredibly sloooooow.  It takes any of the ladies fifteen minutes  to help one person with one order, unless you get a person ahead of the line that also happens to order the whole menu, the you're there at least half an hour.  Price wise, food is over priced compared to other restaurants in the area like isla or Ruby's.  I say if your desperate, go here, but if you want faster service and better food, look someplace else.

8.description: a few days after returning from the philippines, all i could think was, "i should have stuffed more pastries in my suitcase!" girl, i was craving ensaymada like nobody's business. enter uni-mart. i think i bought every kind of baked good they had. now a week later i have had a chance to consume most of it. quality & flavor ranged from A (amazing) to D (dry) and some in between.pandan cake- A+++ube cake- A+ube bread- Acheese roll- B (pretty good but miles away from what i had in the flips)ensaymada- C (i've had way better. and will keep searching for better.)pan de coco- D- (skip it!)also got some toron which i would totally get again. and they carry lots of the snacks i'm sure i'll need to stock up on again in the near future. i'm glad they're here, but i'm still kinda left wanting. i'll be checkin' out some other filipino joints before coming back here.

30.description: If I could be the Anthony Bourdain of Chicago, I would bring you this - the best kept eggroll secret in Chicago...BUILDING - What this place lacks in ambiance and marketing, it makes up for big food and big taste.  Okay, a non-descript building, not much parking, and you gotta wonder what they sell because this place does not look like it has much, and it vaguely smells like someone has been frying something in there.  Well this is what I grew up within some of the Filipino homes I have visited, and it is a precursor to something delicious.TAKEOUT FOOD - When you walk to the back of the store, you are greeted by a takeout counter and a long glass case only a non-muslim southeast asian could appreciate.  A large takeout counter makes up about 30% of the store, yet may make up a huge percentage of their business. Filipino food consists of 5 different food groups - starches (bread or rice variations), fried meat (mostly pork related), barbecue (chicken and pork), stews (vegetable and meat and combinations), and soups.  If you go to this place for anything at all, you should go for, and you should write this down, the LUMPIA SHANGHAI.  Lumpia Shanghai is a mini meat eggroll unlike any other eggroll adulterated with heavy cabbage.  The thin crackling filo type shell stuffed with garlic, carrot and onion-seasoned pork is appetizer perfection for meatlovers.  It comes with a sweet sour dipping sauce that is unnecessary, but adds variety.  At $6.00/lb, one pound fills a half a styrofoam takeout clamshell.  The light crunchiness of the shell, along with the garlic spicyness of the meat makes this the perfect accompaniment with beer.  Even the next day, these lumpia shanghai heat up nicely in the oven and will hold for at least 3 days, if they last 3 hours.  LUMPIA SHANGHAI WARNING: Do not go hungry when you buy these.  The smell of the cooked lumpia will torture you until you careen the car into a parking spot just to stop your incessant drooling.The pork barbecue sticks and the chicken barbecue sticks are next best (in that order).  Generously skewered pieces of meat coated in a sweet barbecue sauce, ready for another sneaky snack in the car. Other items in the glass case?  Lechon (roast pork), other stuffed meats (like chicken relleno, a chicken stuffed with a meatloaf, oh yeah), a variety of traditional fried fish, and stews. STEWS - Most of these are traditional and you should as a Filipino friend what they are.  Nothing will be too hot or spicy, just different.Adobo is combination of chicken and pork (there they go again, trying to marry the meats together) cooked in soy sauce, garlic, black pepper, bay leaves and vinegar.  The richness of the pork and the lightness of the chicken make for a nice tasty dish.  Pancit noodles are an egg noodle frenzy of chinese pork sausage, pork and chicken (see dat again?), carrots, celery and mushrooms in a rich oyster sauce flavor.  Excellent carb that is also served with white rice (you will find that almost everything in a Filipino diet is served with white rice).BREADS - If you like soft, roll type bread, try the pan de leche or the pan de sal.  Both are great.  The other products within the store are catered toward the Filipino community.  Everything is in english and you should find no problem with any of the selections. PARKING - Tough, but worth it.The food is very good, and not only is it near and dear to my heart, it is probably in my arteries as well.

3.description: Sisig supposed to be parts of pork mixed with soy sauce on a sizzling plate (that means warm and brown colored if it is in "turo turo" style.) When I ordered it it was white and cold (looked like kilawin to me.) Its my favorite filipino dish so I was hoping that it would be the real thing.Also the hours for BDO cannot be found online.Otherwise, it's your mom and pop's grocery store. A place where you can get a quick bite if your craving for filipino home cook meal.

14.description: You can make the half filipina girl move away from her filipina mom, but you can't make the half filipina girl stop missing mom's food. On the northside for something completely different. Tired after trekking from Hyde Park and have to go to Rockwell/Peterson. Passing Clark I suddenly remembered there was a filipino grocery store. I immediately jumped off the bus(ok, not quite but you get the picture) because I started to miss my mama's cooking. SInce I am not the best cook I usually rely on those seasoning packets- Mama Sita's, Mccormick's etc. to make adobo, calderata,etc. But since moving to the south side I haven't been able to pick up those packets. I guess I could get them online..but I keep forgetting. Sometimes I wish I was half Chinese instead of half filipina so that going to a nearby asian market would be more convenient! Could just hop on the red line and get off at Chinatown.Alas, my mom is one cool Filipina and I wouldnt' have it any other way. BUT it's really inconvenient for grocery shopping.I also picked up two packages of Longaniza which I am currently chomping on as I type. I seriously do not know why filipino food hasn't caught on with the American public. Longaniza would convert the masses.And darn those yummy bakery goods and the food to go.I am carb cycling and I happened to go to UNIMART on my low carb day. GRR....Although I could have picked up one of the meaty dishes which would be low carb compliant. I just knew I'd be tempted with rice. (yeah, I'm a  half asian person who eats rice maybe once a month even on my high carb days!) I almost bought me some Pan De Sal. Right now I can imagine dipping that yummy bread into my coffee, just like mommy. Of course she dipped the bread in Nescafe(ugh), I would dip it in Intelligentsia, Metropolis or Alterra. I am low carbing and trying to do Paleo because that's what my ancestors did...uh....but coming to Unimart it seems like my recent ancestors have been eating yummy breads. I did avoid the breads and picked up longaniza and upon eating it realize it might not be low carb...lol. It's sweet sausage(I highly recommend Victor's Longaniza in the frozen foods case!). But it's my high carb day, so oh well.They also have duck eggs. hee hee. Totally in line with low carb!  May have to pick them up.I did get my seasoning packets and can't wait to try them on my all meat day tomorrow.I will be back Unimart. On my high carb rice day.

3.description: This is my new go to store for unique, tasteful gifts.  Their Christmas selection was wonderful, every gift recipient has asked for their name and the shopping experience is intimate and inviting.  The value for money is excellent, compared to the cookie cutter as well as boutique options, SHOP LOCAL BUSINESSES!

1.description: Stopped by this weekend for a little preview of the store before it formally opens and wow, looks like it'll be a great place to find some unique and well thought out gifts or items for our house.  The guys opening this new spot are friendly and so willing to help it seems already.  They had some really unique items (hehe, like their name suggest I guess).Definitely look forward to stopping by after the store opens and will look to update the review a little more.  As for now, a great addition to the neighborhood and highly recommend you put this place on your list to visit if in the area looking for beautiful unique furniture or decor!

2.description: Don't miss this shop when you are strolling Andersonville, it's super cute! This is my go-to place for good smelling candles (that aren't cookie scented or whatever you get at the mall) and great host/hostess gifts. The store has great pieces for living rooms & dining rooms especially; they have a rug that I am obsessed with right now! Most importantly, the owners JT & Travis are so kind and welcoming. There are a lot of home furnishing stores on Clark now but there isn't anything with the distinct look & feel of Murray & White!

0.description: My partner and I were just strolling down Clark when we stumbled upon this GEM! I absolutely loved this gorgeously decorated shoppe! It smelled like heaven in there!{I am a Murray too... but no blood relation ;) The boys were so lovely, engaging and seemed to beam with PRIDE! They truly love to curate and bring luxurious beauty to the community. Its the perfect place for a one of a kind gift. What a beautiful addition to Andersonville! I will be definitely be back in soon!

4.description: Stopped in today for the first time with my fiance, and I cannot say enough about the spectacularly curated items and impossibly lovely experience of shopping at this elegant Andersonville gem. JT and Travis are welcoming, kind, and incredibly helpful. In their store, we felt completely at home (and also wanted to take every single thing home with us)! They could not have been more accommodating!We loved their selection of candles (and soaps... the store smells like heaven!), carefully chosen bar ware, and seriously covet-able home accessories. I think there is something here for every kind of person that I know! (Dear everyone on my holiday shopping list, put in your requests now :) ... For real though, you guys...)The perfect place to find a gift, or to spoil yourself a little bit (which I did, and my house currently smells like awesome, because yay candles)! I will definitely be back.

58.description: We visited Koval on a private group tour.  Not knowing much about distilleries, and always up for a tour of anything food or drink related, I was excited to check out Chicago's locally made spirits.  The tour is basically an hour and a half of standing in one of two rooms, the storage room and the stills where "the magic happens".  I was a little disappointed to see that operations were closed during our tour, so it was a LOT of talking and not a lot of action.  Our tour guide was the office manager, who oddly doesn't drink, so I felt like some of the passion for the process was missing.   We were able to taste (tiny pours) of nine of their whiskeys and flavored liqueurs, which would make a nice gift supporting local business.

56.description: If you should know something about me, it's that my main food groups are: beer, bourbon, burgers and meat.  Knowing this, my parents surprised me with the Groupon for Koval's whiskey workshop that went on sale back in May, I believe. Originally it's $200, but the Groupon was for $99.  Koval is very close to the Ravenswood Metra but about a mile from the Berwyn red.Craft distillery, craft breweries, arts and crafts, kraft mac and cheese...they're all so hot right now. But really, if you haven't noticed the overwhelming number of craft beers available, you must one of those people who shotguns Natty Light in the shower.  Anyway, Koval is a craft distillery and an awesome one at that. You have to ring the doorbell when you get there, but I was checked in really quickly.  I was early, so I just sat in their front room/store looking a their spirits selection. Once everyone else came we were led to some tables in the back, where Robert, the owner, started off our workshop.  He gives a presentation, and you can follow along on the packet you receive.  Learning the history, the process, etc. was great.  Let's talk about the best part though - the whiskey tastings. We started off with the white whiskeys, and Koval's was way better than the other one we tasted.  Then we got to taste the "heads" and the "tails."  The heads are the compounds that distill along with the alcohol at a lower temperature (like acetaldehyde...yeah I'm a nerd and am into the organic chemistry, too), and the tails (fusel oils) are from a higher temperature.  They were both not very pleasant, and you'd never realize that's what you were tasting when drinking some whiskeys.  There's a cup on the tables to pour out excess whiskey if you don't want to finish it, which we only did for the bad tasting things.At each part in the presentation, Robert had some relevant whiskeys for us to taste.  We tried at least 20 brands of various whiskey types. From looking at the difference in color or tasting the difference between whiskeys aged in toasted barrels vs charred barrels to blended whiskeys to sour mash vs bourbon, it was a lot.  You don't get a full shot for the tastings, but maybe 1/3 or 1/4 of a shot.  Of course I wish it was more, but otherwise everyone would be extremely drunk by the time it's over.  Koval's whiskeys are all distilled from 100% of one grain, while many use a mix, so learning what those grains taste like was pretty cool and delicious.I learned a lot - more than I realized until I was thinking about this review.  I tasted a lot, but I kind of wish we had talked more about tasting whiskey rather than just asking, "What did you guys think of that one?" Most of the answers were positive, because, we all clearly liked to drink whiskey. Although some girls seemed to be there because they were with their significant other, and they didn't really know much about whiskey. Not to hate on them, because it actually is a good learning experience no matter your knowledge level.  You can ask Robert almost anything including, "Uhhh so can we try that one?"  It was definitely more interesting than 90% of the classes I've taken. Overall a good experience that has made me more discerning about the whiskeys I drink.  By the end, we were all at least buzzed and joked around a lot.  The Groupon was a good deal for what you get and was a great birthday present for me. With my funds low, I couldn't afford to buy a bottle of whiskey afterwards, but I'll be back for the dark rye and dark wheat.  Or if I stumble upon a pile of money, all of them.

29.description: Really enjoyed the Koval distillery tour. Learned how whiskey was made for the first time. Koval is an all organic whiskey so their process differs from most whiskey distilleries. We got to sample 4 types of whiskey, 2 liquors, and got a tour of their old distillery for just $10. I would recommend this tour to others.

42.description: Loved our tour guide, Annie!!!She made the information both interesting and fun and we were really glad that we made it part of our family vacation. They have a little retail shop on location that enabled us to buy a few of our favorites and Annie allowed us to try a couple of more items before we purchased them. We expect to see and hear a lot more about them in the years to come!

23.description: Koval makes some darn good liquor and everything is organic which is fabulous. That being said, the tour is A-OK but not something I'd really recommend to others. It's interesting if you're really into hard liquor and distilling but if you're not so much (like moi), you may not be overly interested.KOVAL has some parking right outside the distillery so that part of things is nice. My tour had about 30 people on it and with just one person working (reception / tour guide / I'm sure many other duties), when people came late, it meant she kept having to stop to let them in & check them in. The tour itself is quite informative, prob just 30-45 minutes long. I've been on a couple of distillery tours before and still picked up some new information.Throughout the tour, you get samples of each liquor available. The sample, mind you, is a quick pour, each pour equal to just about 1/8 of a shot. So when all is said and done, you've maybe had what equates to one shot though I think it's even less than that. One reviewer said they got as many samples as they liked at the end, not the case for our group.I loved the dessert liquors we sampled - orange blossom & rose hip - yum, yum, yum! Good liquor, not so good tour, stick to buying their boos to go.

47.description: I took some out of town friends for the tour one Saturday afternoon. While the tour was very informative, I have a few suggestions for improvement. First, add seating. Standing for over 45 minutes before the first sample can be wearing on ones feet, it would have been much easier if there was seating. Second, maybe offer a little chaser, perhaps an Orange juice box. The liquor was good, but some of us have a harder time taking straight whiskey. My friends made some interesting faces when they drank it.  Lastly, maybe be slightly less informative. It was great to learn so much information, but our tour lasted 2.5 hours of straight information. By the end, our feet hurt from standing so long, and we just couldn't take any more info.I loved the distillery and the tour overall, but perhaps a few tweaks could make this tour amazing!

8.description: Fun and informative tour and a great quality product (although I enjoy their liqueurs and gin more than their whiskeys but I am goofy like that)  I have actually done the tour 3 times in the last few years (fun thing to do with out of town guests) and it is different every time and I have always enjoyed it.

31.description: What a cool local business! Founded by a couple of ex-academics in 2008, Koval makes organic, kosher whiskey from locally sourced grain in small batches. The tour/ tasting at their first distillery on Ravenswood is awesome! It'd be a fun date or a cool outing for a group of friends. You get a tour of the facility, learn about how whiskey is distilled, barreled, aged and bottled, and taste lots of their delicious products.  So fun. A+

34.description: I cannot speak highly enough of my experience with Koval and their staff.  For my whiskey-loving husband's birthday a while back, I was trying to think of something/anything that a big group of people would enjoy doing.  After researching breweries and distilleries around Chicago, I emailed back and forth with Koval.  I am so, so glad that this is where we ended up bringing our group.We scheduled a private tour through Annie, who has got to be one of the sweetest, most cheerful people I have ever met.  You can tell that she is passionate about their craft whiskeys and liquors, and she is equally enthusiastic to help you plan a damn good tour.  She responded promptly to all my emails and squeezed us into a busy day.  We were really pleased that she also ended up being our tour guide. Our crowd of whiskey lovers was in the perfect place.  We enjoyed the samples, hearing about their story and the process, and Annie was a true gem.  Most of us had never had Koval or Lion's Pride prior to this tour, and it was greatly enjoyed.  In our household, they have become staples in our booze stash.    Drink local, Chicago!

16.description: There are three ways to review this: The whiskey/spirits/brandy/liqueurs: across the board they are all fantastic. My top three are the gin, the plum brandy and the Toasted Oat whiskey (a little hard to find so settle for the regular oat whiskey). This is quickly becoming a go to drink for me when I go to a bar and see it on their menu. I only hope more bars start to include this in their roster of whiskeys.  The Tour: the tour of the distillery is the main pull for this location. You don't go just to buy a bottle. You can do better in pricing by going to Binnys or any local liquor store that sells Koval simply because the Koval retail store has the highest prices on their products. (Not uncommon for places like this to do that as to create good relations with the local retailers who are also selling their product). The tour is only $10 for an hour of learning all about the various products, the history of Koval and how they make their products. The place is small- if you spin in a circle in the middle of the room you have seen the whole place. Don't go expecting to see a lot and get a ton of pics. Go to learn about their process and history.  You get to sample most of their products throughout the tour which even with the thimble sized portions of each liquor is pretty great for the price. At the end of the tour you can feel free to ask to try a sample of any of their other products you didn't get to try on the tour which is very generous. The retail shop: to go to the tour you must enter their retail shop first which is the size of a large walk-in closet. It's pretty bare bones and simply has the liquor displayed on a wall. I'm not sure what is lacking but I feel a little more could go into the look and layout of this particular part of their space. One thing I thought would be great is if they had hand written descriptions from the owners about each of the products taped to the shelves. If you've ever been to Pastoral they do something similar where the staff writes about the various products and while it doesn't always influence my opinion on what I'll buy, it's just a nice personal touch.

13.description: We came for a tour on Wednesday at 7. Our tour guide, Karen, was very good. She made it interesting and she was very knowledgeable. The tour lasted about 40 minutes, and there were 6 of us there. One couple showed up just a few minutes late, and the tour guide was annoyed and they missed out on 3 tastings. So try to be early! Plus, if you are early, you can park right out in front. In total, we tried 2 white whiskeys, 2 aged whiskeys, 1 Brandy, 1 Bourbon, and 3 infused liqueurs. With everything combined, we probably had about 2 shots. Overall, the tour was very informative! I would recommend wearing comfortable shoes though, as you will be standing the entire time!They also sell teeshirts, and of course, all their alcoholic drinks. They also sell whiskey soy candles!

11.description: Knew the bourbon to be outstanding (on par with Blantons and others). Learning they were located in Chicago was an incredible bonus. And now having visited and learned the way they go about making their fine products - and tasting those with which I wasn't familiar - they've made a fan for life. Bravo!

39.description: Zooey Deschanel was our tour guide! Just kidding, looked a lot like her :)I'll keep this short bc it's pretty simple- go on this tour!!! It's informative, offers a LOT of samples, and only costs $10. GO!!P.S. Great ideas for gifts in the gift shop :)

37.description: Did the tour this past Sunday, decided on the later session (4pm) hoping for a more intimate experience and got it. I recommend doing this.Tour guide was vibrant and knowledgeable.Sample tastings of most the products Koval makes made it highly worth the money.

0.description: Nothing else like it in Chicagoland. I learned quite a bit about the process and tasted some unique samples.Advice - buy a $10 tour ticket and enjoy the tastings as well as the history of Koval (it's a memorable story). Next time friends come into town, I hope to take them and experience something fresh in our city.

38.description: We came for a tour on Wednesday at 7. Our tour guide, Karen, was very good. She made it interesting and she was very knowledgeable. The tour lasted about 40 minutes, and there were 6 of us there. One couple showed up just a few minutes late, and the tour guide was annoyed and they missed out on 3 tastings. So try to be early! Plus, if you are early, you can park right out in front. In total, we tried 2 white whiskeys, 2 aged whiskeys, 1 Brandy, 1 Bourbon, and 3 infused liqueurs. With everything combined, we probably had about 2 shots. Overall, the tour was very informative! I would recommend wearing comfortable shoes though, as you will be standing the entire time!They also sell teeshirts, and of course, all their alcoholic drinks. They also sell whiskey soy candles!

51.description: I went here for a distillery tour and tasting recently and highly recommend the experience.We started by hearing about the story of the owners - Robert and Sonnet - and why they started the distillery. Our guide brought the group on a tour of the facility, though it is quite small (which is why they are in the process of moving to a bigger space). Our guide took us through the whiskey making process and was able to answer all of the questions thrown at her. She had some great facts about whiskey and the distillery itself, and it was great to hear how sales and production keep growing. Fun fact learned on the tour: the pictures on the labels of the liqueurs were done by the owner's mother.As for the tastings, we tried the white whiskey, the dark whiskey, and a bunch of the liqueurs - rose hip, walnut, coffee, orange blossom, and more. We learned that some of their liqueurs are seasonal (like the Asian pear that they won't be making this year due to a failed crop), and some are definitely off the beaten path (like the liqueur made from failed beer from their next door neighbors, Revolution Brewing). I thought it was fun that with each liqueur, suggestions for specialty cocktails were offered, some I wouldn't think of on my own. All were delicious and we ended up taking home the rose hip for some mighty tasty Manhattans. It was a fun way to spend an hour on a Saturday morning for $10. Oh, and apparently, all of the liquor is organic and kosher. Added bonus.

27.description: Very cool local distillery.  I took a tour with some friends and we highly enjoyed it.  The tour is in their smaller "touring" distillery, complete with copper distiller and oak barrels.  I'm a big fan of their dessert liquors, not so much the whiskeys (though didn't get a chance to try the bourbon whiskey which is more my taste).  The Rose Hips liquor is excellent.  The tour guide seemed a little tired, but I had plenty of tastes.  Plus, Hopleaf is blocks away for afterwards!

32.description: We did the tour and it was pretty freaking great.Delicious booze, witty banter, and no question left unanswered.The facility is rather small overall but it has a nice small business family type of vibe.Totally worth the $10.

54.description: I visited Koval for a tasting tour.  I had already tasted Koval whiskey when a friend brought a bottle to a party, and then again at a brewery event in Lincoln Square. I hadn't made the connection when I was invited to the tour (I'm terrible at remembering names to things), but immediately recognized the bottling when I entered small shop at the front of the distillery.  I was pleasantly surprised.TOUR:PROS: It's cheap - $10.  You get to try at least 6 different types of whiskey, including white and aged, as well as the many liqueurs.  It's a real lax tour.  I've been on whiskey tours in Kentucky where they're more streamlined because they have many whiskey tours on the same day due to lots of visitors.  Here, because it's a small business, you get a more personal tour that can naturally lead into a discussion between the guide and the tourists.  The guide was 1 of the 6 staff members.  She was fun and has worked for one of the large American breweries, so was able to provide us with well rounded information.  Photography is enthusiastically welcome.If you're a Chicagoan, it's a great opportunity to check out the local distilleries, and Metropolitan brewery is right next door.  Parking is easy to find.  NOTE: The distillery is open to volunteers, so if you're interested, you can help bottle, label, or even prepare the fruits for the liqueurs.  CONS: It's a small space, and the tour is held outside of working hours so there's not much action to see.  The process is explained, though.BUT: Having already been on other tours, though, I felt like I didn't miss out on much in that regard, and in exchange I was given a lot of information that I hadn't gotten on other tours, such as how a small business is run and what it is to have a whiskey business in Chicago as part of the growing local craft beer and liquor scene.I think it's definitely worth a visit - definitely planning to spread the word among my friends!

48.description: What a gem!  The past week I have been singing the praises of Koval Distillery.  I have also been trying to figure out how many cocktails I can make with their whiskey and ginger liqueur! Last Saturday I grabbed a friend and we took the Metra down (to Union) and then out (to Ravenswood) to Koval. The walk is only .5 miles from the Metra stop and it's right along the cute homes on Ravenswood Avenue. We almost walked right past the distillery and even rang a bell to get in. We were quickly ushered inside a small waiting area and welcomed warmly by our tour guide (and the amazing aromas of whiskey and oak).The tour is a cheap $10 and includes an extremely informative tour and a small sampling. The tastings are small because they are licensed as a liquor store but I wasn't up to doing shots in the afternoon anyway; it was enough to know the quality of their product is high. The experience was a little over an hour and half and will leave you with a great education. Tips: Be sure to wear comfy shoes. There is no seating and a concrete floor.Bring your camera - they are very open to photo opportunities. Bring your wallet - you must bring home a bottle!

44.description: Who doesn't love whiskey?! Take the tour & ask for Jessica

24.description: I'm giving 2 stars because this place has cool potential & limitless free liqueur tasting at the end of the 'tour.'That being said the place was super quiet, I was afraid I was going to wake a baby or something by using my normal voice (some music playing would make a HuGe difference in ambiance). Tour guide ended up being the receptionist & didn't seem to care much about us or the products (hey we paid for this tour, at least pretend the first 2 tastings aren't a waste of money). And we pretty much saw all there was to see in the 2 little rooms while we were waiting. Overall impression-BoRing! Such a shame considering this was the only alcohol tour we paid for all week in Chicago & by far the most disappointing.

7.description: I tried their oat whiskey and coffee liquor during the Taste of Andersonville Dinner Crawl. Yum! I will definitely be back next time we need to restock our bar!

49.description: I moved to Andersonville 2 weeks ago. I was walking around with my BF and found this Distillery. I had to take the tour to find out more about this place. It's a small family owned organic distillery. They make few kinds of whiskeys  and liqueurs.  We tasted 3 different whiskeys and 5 liqueurs. Tour is $10. I don't know much about whiskey so I can't comment. I liked coffee, Jasmine and ginger liqueurs.  It was a great experience.

40.description: I agree with other reviews which have stated that this tour was incredibly boring. You do only get to sample a few drops of each whiskey, but thats due to some law prohibiting tours to blah blah blah. Anyway, the tour itself was painful. The guide went on for hours talking about the history of the brand, the life story of the owners, and the way they put labels on the bottles. It was like a college class with a boring professor. Most of the tour was spent standing in a circle listening to him yammer on and tell "jokes." There were probably 15 people in the tour and everyone was crabby and irritible by the time it was over. My advice would be to skip the tour and order the stuff at a local bar. That way you can try an adult size and not have to pay to be bored out of your mind.

53.description: Great tour!  Went here for a tour of the distillery with the boyfriend and had a great time.  It's about an hour long tour, and goes over how each spirit is made, the history of the place, the future of the company, etc.  It was a fun way to spend an hour on a Saturday afternoon, and fun to learn about this distillery right here in our neighborhood.  Worth checking out for sure!

30.description: This is a review for the tour of the distillery.What the heck happened?  We did the tour back in February of 2013 and it was fantastic.  5 stars all the way.  Great tour guide, lots of samples, learned a lot  ... it was awesome.I just did it again last week and it was terrible.  The tour guide was fine, though boring and didn't seem too interested in her job.  The samples?  Awful.  We tried 5 or 6 different products, and had about an 1/8 of a shot of each.  Horrible.I think the problem is they do a vast majority of the distilling at their new location, and this is their older, smaller place.I would highly recommend against the tour now.  What a complete let down.118/365

46.description: We had a great time at an evening tasting.  I'm not a whiskey person, but my wife swears by it all.  All the whiskeys are single grain, and she particularly liked the spelt.They also make a line of liquors, and we liked the ginger.  It's great added to iced tea.If they haven't changed since we visited, they partner with food trucks for the tastings, so you're not drinking on an empty stomach.  Also they do volunteer days, where you can help them bottle and label, and get a discount on their products.

1.description: For my recent birthday weekend, I wanted to go to a distillery before dinner with friends, and Koval was the most ideal choice. On the Koval website I learned that they offered 3 Saturday afternoon/early evening tours. Myself and one of my friends bought our tour ticket ahead of time, but one of my friends waited until a couple days before the tour to buy a ticket online, and they were sold out. Fortunately, when she called Koval directly, they told her she would be able to do a walk in since the two of us had bought tickets for the 3pm already. I am so thankful that they were able to accommodate her so she would be able to join us. The atmosphere of the Koval Distillery itself is very quaint and charming. Our tour guide went through a nice history of Koval, the distilling process, and unique features of Koval spirits. The products tasted very good and you can tell they are high quality. This would be great distillery to check out whether you have been to other distilleries, or it is your first time at one.

55.description: Came here on a Saturday for their tour/tasting. The Office manager gave the tour, and was good.  Nice little story on how the owners opened up the distillery. He said right away in the beginning, that any technical questions he may not answer well and may make up. I am guessing if you want in depth info on the process, ask when the person who makes the batches or one of the owner will be on site.  Their whiskeys/vodkas and liqueurs are all tasty.  Small place so you will be standing in one spot most of the time. Tour is at least an hour long. The  only distillery in chicago!

9.description: I love that this distillery is off the beaten pack and in a semi industrial corridor.  It also helps that their products are all high quality and unique.  While you can get their liqueur in many shops around here, I find that this small store usually has more of a selection.Do their distillery tour (You can usually get a deal on the many deal sites out there).  You will learn a lot and have a good time.  Just keep in mind that this location is more of a storefront and storage instead of the actual production facility.  They moved to a bigger space and only distill clear alcohol here now.  You get to try most of their stuff during the tour and they are gracious enough to let you sample more after the tour.  Plus you get a discount after your tour on anything they sell.I'm a big fan of their product and how they conduct their business.  And its very local - it started here before the boom in craft whiskey and still makes a quality product.

26.description: Very friendly tour guide and even better whiskey. It's great to know your supporting a local business with world class status. Great products!

25.description: Avoid the tour! Too much info, not enough samples. Information is basic whiskey knowledge that could be explained in 10 min YouTube video. I was suggested the tour by Dr. Sonet who said I would get at least $10 of samples.  Between all the samples it did not add up to full shot. It was about an hour of standing. The bourbon was not sampled. It was about 4 whiskey and 2 liquor drops in a glass. Do yourself a favor, and do not go.Was gonna buy a bottle but after the awful tour, decided not to.

12.description: The KOVAL tour in a nutshell: $10 per person, ~20 spots per session, and it lasts ~45 minutes.Mallory was our tour guide. She did a good job with her speech and answering questions, however her presentation manner was somewhat disinterested and unenthusiastic. Late-comers were allowed to join the group (Mallory clearly found it annoying to answer the door to get these people), but none of the tour was made up for their sake.During the tour, we tasted 4 whiskeys and 2 liqueurs, each of which we received a very small sample (on the order of a few milliliters). Products not shown during the tour were not available to sample afterward. There was no pressure to purchase KOVAL's products. The samples were integrated into the tour fluidly; I especially liked the head/heart/tail samples. As a chemist, I can say that the scientific details were presented well enough for a lay person. Since I have some deeper knowledge, I can say that some parts of the tour weren't quite true if taken at face value. Compared to the tour of FEW in Evanston, KOVAL's tour was much more polished and catered to a general audience. FEW's tour was given by the distillers themselves (it was unclear if our tour guide was involved in the production of KOVAL's products) and tended to be more technical and detailed.TL;DR? If you're new to the concepts of distilling and want an overview, go on KOVAL's tour. If you're more experienced and want more details, go on FEW's tour.

59.description: The tour was both interesting and informative.  The ambassador is knowledgeable and very laid back.  I enjoyed her coolness esp bc I somewhat expected the tour to be stuffy or 'stuck-up'. The tastings are generous, but I still prefer other whiskeys, vodkas and spirits over these.

21.description: Always heard about Koval but never had tried. Saw they had a tasting, grabbed a few  friends ($10/person for tasting) and headed over, they recommend RSVP. Each tasting is limited to 25 people so its smaller crowd, the brewery is very small hence the 25 limit. Instructor talked about the history of Koval, there new distillery (down the street), the process, and the equipment used  Yes, throughout the history lesson she poured a few samplers (small portions) but enough for me to pickup my own 4-Grain whiskey bottle ($40-445). The tour lasted about an hour.This review got 4 stars because the Whiskey is good. Wished we could've tried a little more of each sample though....

17.description: What a cool local business! Founded by a couple of ex-academics in 2008, Koval makes organic, kosher whiskey from locally sourced grain in small batches. The tour/ tasting at their first distillery on Ravenswood is awesome! It'd be a fun date or a cool outing for a group of friends. You get a tour of the facility, learn about how whiskey is distilled, barreled, aged and bottled, and taste lots of their delicious products.  So fun. A+

10.description: This is definitely a business I hope to never deal with or purchase products from.
