We were immediately seated even without a reservation. The fried chicken is an obvious must-order but we also tried the gumbo ya ya. It is very different from ones I have had before. It was very dark and thick, but flavors were smokey and spicy. I especially liked the mix of andouille sausage, chicken and pork. One order isn't ideal for sharing among three, unless you only want a taste of it.I had the fried chicken with dark meat, collard greens, and sweet potato. The breading is very unique and exceptional. It was not heavily salted or breaded, but there was a very good crisp without overdoing it. The meat was kept moist and tender. The collard greens and sweet potato, on the other hand, were complete opposites of each other. The greens were a bit too salty and bitter whereas the sweet potato were very sugary. Lights are pretty dim in here, but it is generally speak easy. I would most likely return for more fried chicken.

22.description: I didn't know what to expect from Big Jones as I love New Orleans and the food....when I was told by server the chicken was award winning...I was like "yeah right"....Well Folks I was wrong...the chicken was amazing, the vegetarian gumbo..unbelievable...and that pecan pie..My God!  I will be back again this week...one of my favorites in Chicago :)

15.description: There is so much hype around Big Jones and I had to try it so I finally did today. While the food was presented well and tasted like it was made with good ingredients, it completely missed the mark with providing NOLA inspired food. There was no spice, no flavor, and the complimentary beignets that we were excited for, were subpar. I am extremely disappointed with this place, which makes me sad because I was excited for authentic Cajun food.

57.description: Great ambiance, lovely service and mouth watering food.  The southern home style cooking is definitely worth the hike to the north side of the city. It is nice that they still take reservations.

20.description: Came here with my friend to celebrate my birthday during restaurant week. We were pleasantly surprised to learn the portions were the same as usual. We both wanted the half fried chicken- her dark and me white meat, but we each got the balls and veg gumbo for appetizers and the calas beignets and pecan pie desserts. Everything was amazing!! We washed it down with the 750ml stout. The service was good and the ambience was nice with small touches of cajun influence...not mardi gras colors!! Will definitely come again real soon!

36.description: I've been here twice for brunch and both times were completely different experiences. The second time was pretty terrible. So this will be two reviews and my rating is an average. The first time, the head chef was here and everything was beyond perfect. I would have given this place 20 stars that day. I have been looking for a really well done southern restaurant. Regardless of anything, they have the best bloody mary in town.The first time we had Bayou Teche, salt and pepper biscuits, and a simple cajun breakfast. We also received a set of beignets, no honey though. The Teche was just a, mazing. Smooth and deep flavor with the softest eggs ever. The sauce was mouth watering and the grits it came with were so good. The biscuits were these big awesome heavy lumps of delicious with some amazing butter to go with it. The cajun breakfast, while simple, was one of the best simple breakfasts my partner has had.The second time, was pretty bad. I would say 2 stars. First of all of our drinks were wrong the first time and my partner never got the correct drink she ordered. By the time she got the third drink we gave up and they were all bad. At least my bloody mary was good. First, we never received beignets even though everyone else did and we asked for them. The biscuits this time were tiny and extremely dry. Eugene's breakfast was decent but lacking in flavor. The roasted tomato and goat cheese omelet was pretty good but not great like last time. Part of this might be the fact they were packed and there was one waiter for the whole place.So I want to love this place but it's pretty bad when you have two entirely different experiences. I'm disappointed really. I want to go back but I'm worried it's just going to be another sad experience.

14.description: Tried it for restaurant week. Loved all he food. Excellent Cajun food. Check my photos for more detailed descriptions of the food

1.description: The owner has never been very helpful or friendly and the items I have bought have always been bad. I bought string once for candles that the owner assured me was 100% cotton, but when I tried to use it for wicks, it melted like plastic. I returned it and he first told me I couldn't, but I reminded him he had said it was cotton and that it couldn't be cotton, so grumpily he took the return. They have also cut keys for me that didn't work. Just now I called to ask if they had a product and was told they were closed, no response to whether they had the product (why answer the phone then?) I want to like them for being a "mom and pop" small business, but the service and quality has always been bad.

9.description: Matthew S, nailed this review........and as much as I want to steal the "heavy eastern European accent" wording, I'll pass as I couldn't hope to do a better job.This old school hardward store sits smack dab in the middle of Andersonville on Clark and is what could be considered a traditional hardward store....in otherwords, nothing in here is sexy like in a Lowes or Home Depot.  This place is where you go when you need good ol' hardward items....and by the looks of it, some of the items have been sitting on the shelf a long time.Prices are inexpensive and the store has only a few aisles.  The woman manning the store the day I was there showed me exactly to the items I was seeking.   Lighting is reminiscent of my grandmother's house....just bright enough to see what you are looking at but dim enough to make sure the power bill isn't any bigger than it has to be.  Also, this is a cash only store and they make sure you know it at the register with a big homemade sign to the left.  It is a great little store in a great little part of town.

23.description: Matthew S, nailed this review........and as much as I want to steal the "heavy eastern European accent" wording, I'll pass as I couldn't hope to do a better job.This old school hardward store sits smack dab in the middle of Andersonville on Clark and is what could be considered a traditional hardward store....in otherwords, nothing in here is sexy like in a Lowes or Home Depot.  This place is where you go when you need good ol' hardward items....and by the looks of it, some of the items have been sitting on the shelf a long time.Prices are inexpensive and the store has only a few aisles.  The woman manning the store the day I was there showed me exactly to the items I was seeking.   Lighting is reminiscent of my grandmother's house....just bright enough to see what you are looking at but dim enough to make sure the power bill isn't any bigger than it has to be.  Also, this is a cash only store and they make sure you know it at the register with a big homemade sign to the left.  It is a great little store in a great little part of town.

12.description: Honestly, this store is magic. They've always had what I needed, and the prices are often lower than what I'm prepared to pay.ALSO, have a lamp or appliance that needs rewiring? They'll do that too. Just brought them an old lamp with a broken switch and they had it fixed in a day. For $8. Where can you find that anymore?And yes, the couple that own the place are adorable.

21.description: I went in here to get a set of keys made. When I say "set" I mean copies of half-a-dozen keys, keys of all sizes and shapes (well, maybe not shapes - but the keys definitely included a padlock key and a mailbox key). I was beaten to the key duplicator by another customer, but that didn't stop one of the helpful employees from pulling me aside, asking what I needed, and getting my key duplication going right away. The awful sound that the key machine made aside, I was very pleased with my experience. While waiting for my keys, I walked around the shop. It's been around forever - dozens of years, family-owned and operated - and has the hardware relics to prove it. They sell all sorts of devices that were probably useful in the 1980s (e.g. a small plastic thing that plugs into your corded phone that allows you to turn without twisting the cable into knots), as well as modern tools. They even have a small selection of kitchen gear (can-openers, bottle-openers, etc). I couldn't really tell if the prices on tools and parts were great - I'm no expert - but the keys were a buck-and-a-half each, and done with great speed. I went home and tested them all and had no problems. Had I any issues, I could have taken them back to be re-cut, free of charge. The most important thing to remember about Cas(h) Hardware is that it is Cas(h) only. Luckily, I read up on this place here. I could see some plastic-only people being really disappointed.

16.description: Great little neighborhood hardware store!I've gone to make copies of keys a couple times, and it was cheap, quick, and painless.  Once I got a key that ended up not working when I got home, but they were fine about recutting it for me.  I'm a happy customer so far, and if I find myself in need of any hardware store related goods, I'll definitely check out Cas Hardware before stopping anywhere else.

17.description: This week while cleaning my apartment I took down off the wall a professionally framed HUGE Andy Warhol Brillo Poster from 1970 that had been hanging in my kitchen ever since...while scrubbing it clean and using windex on the glass I applied too much pressure and the glass broke in half ....looking on Yelp for frame services I came across the positive reviews for Cas Hardware... I am so HAPPY that I went up there!  Cornell the owner not only cut me a new piece of 26" X 30" glass but he also took out the old glass and installed the new ....I was expecting to spend at least $50-$100...when I picked it up the bill was $16.00 tax included !! AMAZING SERVICE.  I went back the next day with a ripped screen that had been on my back door and Cornel removed the screen then installed a new one...the cost for that service was $14. Super Nice Mom & Pop Store in Andersonville! I will be back very soon!

10.description: Love this place! Mom and Pop shop (literally) both of them are always there and are always helpful. I have never walked out of there without what I need. Sign inside says it all "if we don't have it, you don't need it"

5.description: A fantastic store, with helpful proprietors who know the stock intimately. Despite the small size the selection is very good. Of course, it's not as broad as the much larger Clark-Devon Hardware a mile north, but unlike at Clark-Devon, you won't have to wander around looking for a staff member for twenty minutes, and I've been happily surprised at how often a quick stop at Cas has been able to save me a trip to the larger store.The lamp repair service is fast, reasonable-priced, and good. I brought in a globe lamp, probably thirty or forty years old at least, with a broken rotary switch and was dismayed to learn that I'd have to replace the entire socket assembly--but it turned out that Cas had a suitable socket in stock and they were able to have it fixed by the next day for $20 parts and labor. (I hear that ordinary rewiring is even less expensive.)

11.description: These are old Chicago buildings and they have occasional break downs. No need to tear the building down just a few small fixes here and there. With these old buildings, sometimes old parts needed and they are hard to find now and days. That's where these old school mom and pop places come in handy. They usually have anything and everything, old and new, to fix your place right up. Cas Hardware is just this sort of place. There is even an old European couple who runs it, they are super nice and helpful. I grew up in places like this so I'm used to the flow of things. You just tell them what you need and they will find it for you. Looking around won't do you any good, trust me they know better then anyone where things are. The only two others things you need to know is that things are cheap here and that their hours vary. At their age I think they deserve to decided when to go to work. I hope places like this stay around forever and they will with your help.

22.description: This little hardware store takes me back to the one I used to walk to with my grandfather years ago.  They have all sorts of special screws, picture hangers, etc. that will NOT be at Home Depot or if they are good luck finding them or getting one of the surly workers to help you find them.  I was thrilled when I found they had the little tiny low voltage halogen light bulbs that are forever burning out on me.  I'm a big fan of patronizing our neighborhood stores whenever possible and this one sure comes in handy.

0.description: This is the second time I've had a lamp repaired at Cas.  This time was a very old brass floor lamp with complicated switches.  It was fixed before I made it home and the price $20 is a fraction of what a lamp store would charge.I am very pleased that a client told me about them after she had mat good experiences.  This is the kind of service that hardware stores provided years ago.

20.description: I went here last summer to find a way to fix my clogged drain (ah, the days of living with roommates).  I had already tried several liquid plumbers, bleach, plunging out the tub, a coat hanger to fish out hair... All of the classic quick fixes.  I went here for the big guns, folks.The store was organized in a way only someone who grew up around hardware stores would know how to navigate, so fortunately, the owner (who looks like a total grandfather-type) is more than willing to hear your hardware ails and offer a solution or three.I went in with a look of determination and a few dollars in my pocket, and left the store with some plastic hook device, a drain snake (a nice addition to my lesbian tool-box, if I might say so myself), and a few dollars still in my pocket.

19.description: Quintessential neighborhood hardware store.  Super helpful service.  Prices fair for mom.and pop place.  Open until 6 which is later than Ace on Broadway

2.description: Old fashioned mom-and-pop hardware store. You don't see stores like this as much anymore, and the owners (well, I assume they were the owners) were genuinely knowledgeable about their wares and about general DIY. I can say this from my experience there, as well as overhearing (eavesdropping?) other customers' inquiries. Great little place. Nice selection of merchandise, too. More merch selection than the chain store down the street. Wish I would have taken a picture of the inside of this quaint hardware store gem.

18.description: me: "Hello! I just moved into my apartment, and want to change the shower head.  The one I bought doesn't fit on the old stem!"Cas Hardware "Oh-kee.  Brink with you de shower head, we fix you up goot!" (should be read with heavy eastern European accent!)me "Super!" (to be read with a heavy fag accent!)And they did fix me up good. He asked me for the shower head, and he went into the back for about 1 minute, and came out smiling, he had found the perfect fitting nut.They treated me so well.  I felt like their gay Grandson.   With the plumbers tape, and washer, my total was $1.78.  He explained  how I should wrap the stem with plumbers tape, and  even provided me with a small drawing on a little sheet of paper, because I obviously seemed inept.  At the cluttered, and well worn check out counter, I realized I only had a $10, and I hate breaking a bill for this sort of thing.  I DID however have an Altoids tin full of change in my murse (that's a man purse, for the uninitiated).  The woman at the register said to me:"Eeets oh-kee.  Just pour eet on the counter. Take you time" and smiled.  And further, encouraged me to use pennies.  And I did take my time.  Counting has never been a forte of mine.She rang me out, and even put my purchases in a tiny little brown paper bag, smiled and told me to "call eef I have more questions". awww.I love this shop. I like it because I don't have to shop when I go in. I tell them what I want, and they go and get it. This was just the best experience I've had here.  It's a total Mom & Pop shop - and I also think that you time warp to 1950 when you go in.AND, I fixed my shower head when I got home. Now I can shower with several water spray options:  Alone, or with company.  Thanks for helping me get laid Cas Hardware store!

13.description: There aren't too many options I found in the city of a hardware store that would do repairs, so this store truly is a gem!I'm so glad I found this place.Sure I can rewire that vintage lamp myself, I'm pretty handy..but then of course I'd have to find brown lamp cord, new socket, and plug, in some ways that's just too much trouble. Why would you need to when Cas Hardware is there to help!

4.description: Thank you, Yelpers! I never would've found this place, if not for the reviews here. I needed a vintage Stiffel lamp switch replaced, as I busted it in too vigorous detarnishing. The owners were incredibly fantastic. I, of course, ripped off all the felt on the bottom, to try and open it myself and "just tighten up a loose wire". I have no idea about electrical! So, I was just creating more problems, haha. Came in to pick up the lamp - new switch replaced, a perfect matching brass exterior switch (which he said he only had black the day before), felt replaced on bottom, plus he made it a 3 way, which it had not been in many years! All this work? $20! Seriously? What a wonderful and lovely pair of owners! I had fun talking to them on both days. Very, very happy to patronize such a great, little business.

24.description: me: "Hello! I just moved into my apartment, and want to change the shower head.  The one I bought doesn't fit on the old stem!"Cas Hardware "Oh-kee.  Brink with you de shower head, we fix you up goot!" (should be read with heavy eastern European accent!)me "Super!" (to be read with a heavy fag accent!)And they did fix me up good. He asked me for the shower head, and he went into the back for about 1 minute, and came out smiling, he had found the perfect fitting nut.They treated me so well.  I felt like their gay Grandson.   With the plumbers tape, and washer, my total was $1.78.  He explained  how I should wrap the stem with plumbers tape, and  even provided me with a small drawing on a little sheet of paper, because I obviously seemed inept.  At the cluttered, and well worn check out counter, I realized I only had a $10, and I hate breaking a bill for this sort of thing.  I DID however have an Altoids tin full of change in my murse (that's a man purse, for the uninitiated).  The woman at the register said to me:"Eeets oh-kee.  Just pour eet on the counter. Take you time" and smiled.  And further, encouraged me to use pennies.  And I did take my time.  Counting has never been a forte of mine.She rang me out, and even put my purchases in a tiny little brown paper bag, smiled and told me to "call eef I have more questions". awww.I love this shop. I like it because I don't have to shop when I go in. I tell them what I want, and they go and get it. This was just the best experience I've had here.  It's a total Mom & Pop shop - and I also think that you time warp to 1950 when you go in.AND, I fixed my shower head when I got home. Now I can shower with several water spray options:  Alone, or with company.  Thanks for helping me get laid Cas Hardware store!

6.description: Pretty cute place.  They are obviously doing something right to have survived the test of time (and with high ratings at that).  Service here is excellent... as a guy who wants to feel handy but lacks the experience and knowledge to buy the right thing at a hardware store, I appreciate the staff's knowledge.One drawback is that they are CASH ONLY.  There is a US Bank across the street and an ATM around the corner, but this limitation means you're probably not going to go on a huge shopping spree here.  More likely, this is a neighborhood hardware store that you probably go to when you just need one or two items.  For that purpose, it's excellent.

15.description: I went here last summer to find a way to fix my clogged drain (ah, the days of living with roommates).  I had already tried several liquid plumbers, bleach, plunging out the tub, a coat hanger to fish out hair... All of the classic quick fixes.  I went here for the big guns, folks.The store was organized in a way only someone who grew up around hardware stores would know how to navigate, so fortunately, the owner (who looks like a total grandfather-type) is more than willing to hear your hardware ails and offer a solution or three.I went in with a look of determination and a few dollars in my pocket, and left the store with some plastic hook device, a drain snake (a nice addition to my lesbian tool-box, if I might say so myself), and a few dollars still in my pocket.

7.description: I run an appliance repair business and sometimes this hardware store is closer than the other ones in the area. Unfortunately, their selection, and knowledge, is very limited so this is not the place to go with any less common problems. On the upside, if you do have a common problem this place is cheaper than the other hardware stores in the area.

8.description: We love this little mom & pop shop. They aren't open very late so we have to make a note not to put off picking up what we need (and they can't bail you out if you blow something up late at night), but otherwise it's incredibly nice to shop at a store with friendly owners. They cram most of the usual hardware stock into this little place and are very helpful if you have questions. They're also pet friendly. When the boyfriend popped in while walking the pooch he poked his head in the door to ask if it was ok to bring the her in. They responded with something along the lines of:"Yes, yes! We for WHOLE family!" :)

3.description: Came in to have a duplicate key made and they did it in less than 2 minutes for less than $2! Key worked perfectly when tried at my apartment! (And I didn't even have to take it off the key ring)

14.description: I went in here to get a set of keys made. When I say "set" I mean copies of half-a-dozen keys, keys of all sizes and shapes (well, maybe not shapes - but the keys definitely included a padlock key and a mailbox key). I was beaten to the key duplicator by another customer, but that didn't stop one of the helpful employees from pulling me aside, asking what I needed, and getting my key duplication going right away. The awful sound that the key machine made aside, I was very pleased with my experience. While waiting for my keys, I walked around the shop. It's been around forever - dozens of years, family-owned and operated - and has the hardware relics to prove it. They sell all sorts of devices that were probably useful in the 1980s (e.g. a small plastic thing that plugs into your corded phone that allows you to turn without twisting the cable into knots), as well as modern tools. They even have a small selection of kitchen gear (can-openers, bottle-openers, etc). I couldn't really tell if the prices on tools and parts were great - I'm no expert - but the keys were a buck-and-a-half each, and done with great speed. I went home and tested them all and had no problems. Had I any issues, I could have taken them back to be re-cut, free of charge. The most important thing to remember about Cas(h) Hardware is that it is Cas(h) only. Luckily, I read up on this place here. I could see some plastic-only people being really disappointed.

58.description: I stopped by to kill time on late Sunday morning.  Well I always want to support business in my neighborhood, even though they are a chain coffee shop.  I left my wallet in the car but managed to get a cup of coffee and a piece of pastry for $5 something.  I told Corey, the barista, that I owe him some tip money.  His response was very courteous and friendly.  I asked for a cup of dark roast coffee and It was delicious, aromatic and flavorful.  I take my coffee black so I don't care for any sweeteners or cream and etc.  I rate this place a 5 star review based on my experience today - quality of the service, Corey, and coffee.  I will definitely come back and try other things.

56.description: I like it here. It's quiet, spacious and the coffee is delicious. Definitely a breath of fresh air for this area.

29.description: Great coffee and atmosphere, but no wifi really takes away from the greatness. What kind of coffee shop doesn't have wifi in Chicago?

42.description: I can never decide if I feel like I'm in New York City or Italy again when I'm here, and I mean that in a good way. I do not find this place even a tiny bit pretentious. I do find it sophisticated, beautiful, friendly and with a great choice of seating. Best of all, the design of the space means it can never be dominated by people on computers. It's primarily a cafe, not a library with coffee. I even love the coffee cups, whereas I prefer to-go cups at other cafes. It's just a classy, European style cafe with amazing coffee, great people-watching windows and well trained staff. Perfect. Plus, I tried an almond milk drink sweetened with honey and it's my favorite new treat. Last but not least, how unpredictably, unfathomably lucky is Andersonville to have landed this place? If this is the future, the future is looking good.

23.description: great Coffee but no Wifi for you.....

47.description: The line was almost out the door with people waiting to order their Sunday morning coffee. Either they were shorted staffed or their work flow needs to be improved. Besides the frustrating wait for a cup of coffee the space is wonderful and the coffee is tasty. Will I return? Only if I don't see a line 10 deep .

8.description: Great place, staff is awesome. Straight  forward coffee, it's all about the coffee here. Best coffee beans I've ever had can not go back drinking others this coffee blows Starbucks out of the world.

31.description: I'm a big coffee snob and I gotta say, there aren't many places better than La Colombe. I encourage you to try their Flat White, it's the best in the city!

34.description: This place needs donuts.

16.description: I go here often, and I love this place. They are not some snobby place that refuses to serve syrups and sugars; they are a place that love coffee SO MUCH that they honor the bean and just that. If you want an extra large frappe, go to Starbucks or wherever you please because there they make beautifully crafted specialty drinks. Just know that people who want a coffee shop that just respects the bean need a place to go as well and it's nothing personal. I typically just get a black coffee and read my book at La Colombe. I always feel very welcome by the staff and always get quality coffee. One time I got the bacon chive scone and they warmed it for me and everything. I was very satisfied- it had a strong bacon taste with the perfect crumbly scone texture. My favorite thing about this place is that they sell their coffee beans and have the best way to prepare the coffee on the bag. I personally am a big french-presser so it was awesome to buy a bean that is perfect for that. Not to mention, they grind the beans to your liking and even talk coffee with you for a bit.If you enjoy a house-roasted bean, this is the place to be.

13.description: I love La Colombe coffee anywhere they serve it, but have to say this location is the best/ my favorite! Espresso drinks are made with both love and expertise. There are plenty of stools and table space to post up and get work done (bring electronics charged!) or bench seating for groups. Oh, and there is wifi!

11.description: It's a great location, cool space, and solid coffee. It's good for people watching. My reservations are that there is no wifi and it is incredibly loud.

39.description: Darn great coffee.   And truly professional barristas.   Yes, the place is a little uncomfortable, sterile and bare (sorry, I don't consider it minimalist) ... but that coffee ... my caffeine habit just got worse.

37.description: Not my favorite espresso,  but it definitely belongs in the "much better" category when compared to Starbucks. Unfortunately,  this location suffers from halitosis.  WTF, am I the only one who gets this? Plus, the minimalist floor plan gives the impression of a store going out of business rather than whatever they were going for. Having said that,  I bought a bag of beans because it isn't the roaster's fault the place smells strongly of something other than coffee.  No doubt for some people this coffee will be perfection. I'm giving the beans 4.5 stars, and since I don't live in the neighborhood and don't have to subject myself to "the horror," I'm only rounding down .5. If I lived around there,  I would have to be there all the time,  and this review would be 1 or 2 stars.

0.description: This is the best coffee in Andersonville! The pastries are fabulous too. It's spacious and comfortable inside. Forget Starbucks, it doesn't compare. This is what coffee should taste like, unburnt. Please frequent this place! I'd love to see if jam packed so that they never leave the neighborhood. Suggestion to La Colombe: Maybe you should install more seating to attract more customers?

38.description: Let me preface my review by telling you what I want in a coffeehouse:  really good coffee and pleasant efficient service, period. Wi-Fi? I carry a smartphone and a cellular tablet, and I have a home wi-fi network, thank you very much. My goodness, whatever did those Greenwich Village and North Beach beatniks do during the daytime back in the 1950s without wi-fi? The poor things must have had to make do with making conversation...and drinking coffee. And communicating by--oh, the horror!--landline phone, written mail, or in person.Coffee. Actual coffee. Serious coffee, as in the Pre-Starbucks era (before Starbucks sold drinks), when a drip was a drip, an espresso an espresso, a cappuccino a cappuccino and "latte" was Italian for "milk" (the drink was called a "caffe latte").  And for anything flavored, sweeter, creamier, or icier-blended you went to the ancient facility called (variously) a "soda fountain," "malt shop" or "ice cream parlor."I popped into La Colombe because: I'd seen the name mentioned in the Yelp section of the EveryBlock Chicago digest; I'd just finished my hair appointment and still had 15 min. left on my parking meter; and I wanted some coffee, not necessarily food, before my next errand. There it was, right where I'd parked. Surprised to find it was a coffeehouse and not a restaurant, given its corner location at A'ville's major intersection. Nice cool dark granite-wood-steel-brick vibe balanced by massive windows to let in the light. Walked up to the bar, and to my delight saw "cortado" listed on the drink menu. I'd discovered those in Spain a few weeks ago: bigger than a macchiato, smaller than a flat white, less foamy than a cappuccino. Two strengths (single & dbl. shot) and two sizes (classic and "workshop," whatever that was) for all their coffee drinks. No rainbow array of syrup bottles, no huge display of pastries, sandwiches, and whatever--just a couple of what they were featuring that day.My decaf cortado was perfect (the barista gladly made it a "breve"--with half & half--at no extra charge; will check out hemp milk later on, as I'm always looking for a low-carb alternative). There was a lovely bit of latte art, it was hot but not scalding, the taste was smooth and balanced and the texture nicely uniform. Music? So unobtrusive I didn't even notice it--which is the way I want it when I'm not going out specifically to hear live music.Drank my cortado, watched the world go by, and was on my way in under 10 minutes. Which is as it should be. Need wi-fi for free? There is a marvelous invention called a PUBLIC LIBRARY. Check it out.Note: I say "coffeehouse" and not "coffee shop" because to me--after growing up in Brooklyn and  37 years living in Chicago--"coffee shops" are those luncheonettes ("diners" without the real or faux rail car exteriors) run by a seemingly extended clan of Greek restaurant owners.

51.description: I think just for the flavor of the coffee, it's 5 stars. Hands down, the best coffee I have ever had. I've had Dark Matter, Intelligentsia, Starbucks, Metropolis, etc. and every coffee drink at this place is superior...For my tastes...I guess the only reason I don't give it 5 stars is that it really is only about coffee and therefore should probably smell like coffee when you walk in...It still kind of smells like the Vitamin store or possibly even the construction from the Vitamin store to the coffee shop...I like the smell of coffee at a coffee shop. Also, they are very limited on decorations and food items but I guess I don't actually care about that.I do like that how Starbucks put Coffee Chicago out when they came to the neighborhood that this place opens a couple blocks from the Starbucks.They were out of Hemp Milk the other day but replaced it with Almond milk and as it turns out, I liked that better for a latte...And in the past, I always added sweeteners or syrups to my latte, there is no need for that here.

27.description: I want to love this place, and I did when it first opened. It HAD great coffee. It is close to me. It still has a great sense of space and interior design. Light and airy.People complaining about the choice the cafe makes to NOT have wifi, need to relax ... close your computer ... put down your smart phone ... and talk to people.Knowing La Colombe from Philly, it is not about wifi and pastries, it is all about the coffee.But then the coffee should be great. It always was in Philly. But at this Andersonville incarnation, on three consecutive days with three different baristas, I have three bitter burnt lattes in a row. Get your act together.

32.description: I enjoy this place...immensely.  The atmosphere is simple.  I feel like everything they offer is bare minimum but top shelf.  You're going to get better than good coffee.  Don't come here if you enjoy starbucks, you won't know how to order as they don't offer the syrup laced drinks.  Friendly staff.  good location.  Its a winner.

54.description: I enjoyed the layout and vibe of this La Colombe location, the space is open and airy with lots of windows. Plenty of seats and outlets. My dark roast coffee was delicious, deep and flavorful. My scone was also super tasty. I do understand why the lack of wifi and beverage/food options may be a turn off for some, but I think La Columbe is being purposeful in their offerings. So if you're looking for a place to sit all day and get some work done, maybe not the best place for you. This would be a great spot to catch up with a friend. And, contrary to other reviewers, I found the staff to be super friendly and welcoming.

48.description: Coffee has incredible flavor.  I'm no aficionado but everything I have had (three or four of the coffee options) is simply richer and more enjoyable than your typical coffee shop Joe.  We tried a couple of the croissants which were equally flavorful if not a little on the flaky side.Nice atmosphere.  Simple but timeless.  Comfortable and welcoming.  Also, the water 'with gas' in the tap is a nice touch.

44.description: Such a beautiful coffee shop.I liked that there was a lot of natural light that streamed in from the abundance of windows. It is dog-friendly  as there was a treat jar and a watering bowl near the front door).I am really impressed at the size of this space. Many coffee shops are quite small and intimate with packed in tables. This place has high ceilings and a lot of space to move about with ease. I am also glad that I was able to sit and hang for a while as I got my latte for there, so it came in an adorable blue ceramic cup and saucer.What I know about coffee: triple-sugar-frothy-coolatta-diabetes type drinks are the devil to me. I cannot say that I am a coffee snob by any means, so I cannot attest to the roast but I really appreciated the fact that it is not super-sweetened right out of the gate. I put a smidge of sugar (if at all) in my coffee and I prefer to do it myself (which I was able to do).

24.description: I've been drinking coffee since i was 2 years old in a baby bottle...yes this is true my mom use to give it to me don't ask why... Any hoot without a shadow of a doubt this is the best coffee I've ever drink hands down I love this place I honestly don't know if I could drink any other coffee from henceforth ! P.s. and I consider myself a coffee aficionado !

7.description: This cafe is located on Clark St in the center of all the Andersonville action.  Love love love.  You are merely steps away from Hopleaf and a short walking distance from the Swedish Bakery, the Bongo Room, Big Jones and cute boutiques for humans and for pets (i.e. Jameson Loves Danger).  If you haven't been to the aforementioned places, do bookmark them!La Colombe (at this particular location and the one on Damen) is listed on the Indie Coffee Passport (#ICPChicago). This was my first time here and it's the perfect place to get a HIGH QUALITY cup of coffee.They pride themselves on their coffee's simplicity and that's how it shines. I recommend "dining in" for your coffee.  Order "for here," sit and enjoy the space.  They have large, open windows all along Clark and Foster which lets in life-saving amounts of sunlight during the winter.Just for funsies (and I've never actually used that word out loud), this is how La Colombe is described on Google:      1) "sleek cafe serving artisanal coffee"      2) "trendy minimalist coffeehouse"Google Maps said so and I agree 100%.Some things to consider:They do not have wi-fi here. It's so that people don't loiter but the lack of wi-fi here didn't seem the detract from the ambiance at all.  It seems to remove all distractions from a focused agenda: to enjoy the coffee and/or the people you came with.I ordered the "Gibraltar" which is equal parts espresso and milk.  It had beautiful latte art and their cups/plates here are also gorgeous: navy floral and Victorian-esque.  Delicious, especially if you like strong coffee.  The cafe was full but not crowded on a Sunday afternoon. I won't come here if I need to use the internet, but it was kind of nice to be in a place where wifi "didn't exist."  The lack of wifi is made up by the seriousness La Colombe takes in the purity of their coffee.  They let their coffee take center stage.

49.description: i can only speak to my experience, and my experience was lovely.  came in on a weekday around 11:30, was worried it might get crowded so close to the lunch hour but there was always an open seat while i was there.  saw that other reviewers complained about the lack of wifi but i brought a book and was perfectly happy to drink my coffee and read in peace.ordered a latte with dairy alternative.  i don't prefer syrups or sweeteners so i didn't ask.  the service was kind and quick and it was honestly the best latte i've ever had.  sat at one of the spots with bench seats around the walls... loved the minimalist, industrial design and the beautiful woodwork... all around enjoyable coffeehouse

40.description: I adore this place. It is a very relaxing environment and everything served is of the highest of quality. I have dreams about their pastries. And I love that they don't offer Wifi -- there are plenty of other places in the city to go for that, La Colombe offers something different and something much needed.

53.description: Seriously one of the best espresso-based drinks I've ever had. Super cute place, very friendly staff, and affordable prices. Cheaper than Starbucks and much, much better quality. Win win.

30.description: After working for a particular giant coffee chain for almost a decade, it is so refreshing to get my morning cup at La Colombe! Their main focus? Coffee. The employees are friendly and knowledgeable, the cafe is clean and beautifully simple. I love that there's no wifi, and sparkling water on tap. They have a beautiful variety of whole beans to offer, without all the other crap that most coffee chains push. Their pastry case is simple and appropriate, always well displayed. The handoff with saucers and spoons for your beverage is classy. Everything about this place makes me want to alter my route to work daily, so I can stop by.

46.description: Hello Yelpers I am here with an update! Colombe has acquired a small menu that sits on the counter next to the cash register. Yay Colombe!

1.description: I'm seriously torn about this review.  My first impression was the nice space.  Bright, open, moderately quiet, generally inviting.  Next was my annoyance at standing in line for 5 minutes waiting to place my order, not because the person in front of me was actually ordering coffee, but because they were bullshitting with the cashier about some mutual friend.  And it's not like I was the only person in line either.After that, came smell.  Delicious, roasting coffee and even some yummy-looking snacky cakes.  Just remembering that smell makes me want coffee.  Then came my double espresso.  Smaller than a single.  So much so, my wife went up to make sure she had grabbed the right drink.  Confirmed.  I wasn't looking for a fish bowl full of coffee here.  But when I'm licking the little espresso spoon and the inside of the cup to try to get get the part clinging to the walls of the cup (entailing about 20% of the total volume), something is seriously wrong.Next, try to find a seat.  I only partially blame the business for this.  Tables were mostly taken up by a single person with their books and computer and crap strewn all over the place, with three other chairs sitting empty around their table.  But there could definitely be more tables, and bigger tables, that would allow better utilization.  Take a hint from some other local coffee shops regarding seating.That being said, the espresso was so very, very tasty.  Maybe I could drink a fish bowl of that stuff after all.  Yeah, I'd have a heart attack, but it might be worth it.  And lastly, the price was right.  Cheaper than any other local coffee places.  What a nice surprise.Despite the issues, I actually really like La Colombe.  I'll definitely give it another shot, maybe just not for the micro-espresso.

55.description: This cafe is located on Clark St in the center of all the Andersonville action.  Love love love.  You are merely steps away from Hopleaf and a short walking distance from the Swedish Bakery, the Bongo Room, Big Jones and cute boutiques for humans and for pets (i.e. Jameson Loves Danger).  If you haven't been to the aforementioned places, do bookmark them!La Colombe (at this particular location and the one on Damen) is listed on the Indie Coffee Passport (#ICPChicago). This was my first time here and it's the perfect place to get a HIGH QUALITY cup of coffee.They pride themselves on their coffee's simplicity and that's how it shines. I recommend "dining in" for your coffee.  Order "for here," sit and enjoy the space.  They have large, open windows all along Clark and Foster which lets in life-saving amounts of sunlight during the winter.Just for funsies (and I've never actually used that word out loud), this is how La Colombe is described on Google:      1) "sleek cafe serving artisanal coffee"      2) "trendy minimalist coffeehouse"Google Maps said so and I agree 100%.Some things to consider:They do not have wi-fi here. It's so that people don't loiter but the lack of wi-fi here didn't seem the detract from the ambiance at all.  It seems to remove all distractions from a focused agenda: to enjoy the coffee and/or the people you came with.I ordered the "Gibraltar" which is equal parts espresso and milk.  It had beautiful latte art and their cups/plates here are also gorgeous: navy floral and Victorian-esque.  Delicious, especially if you like strong coffee.  The cafe was full but not crowded on a Sunday afternoon. I won't come here if I need to use the internet, but it was kind of nice to be in a place where wifi "didn't exist."  The lack of wifi is made up by the seriousness La Colombe takes in the purity of their coffee.  They let their coffee take center stage.

9.description: Wooo Hooo a coffee shop that doesn't provide wifi.  I laugh at the people who think they are supporting a business by planting their butt in a seat for hours on end sipping their small cup of $2 drip coffee.  News flash...you are only supporting yourself.Came in here and was able to get a seat, warm up and enjoy some coffee.  There was a decent flow of people in and out while we were there, I am sure it will become increasingly busy as their opening gets out.  They remodeled the place nicely and are a great addition to the neighborhood.

26.description: I ordered a chai latte and got a cupful of very weak milky tea water. It cost the same as at Metropolis, it just tasted terrible.

25.description: Great quality coffee and espresso. Love the new draft lattes. Took off two stars because of the baristas' snotty purist attitudes. Asked for whipped cream in my espresso once, barista said they didn't carry whipped cream. I said "hm, that's weird you don't have whipped cream" and he replied "that's weird you're asking for whipped cream in your espresso". Hah, as if that was such a bizarre, outrageous request.

12.description: Amazing coffee, super friendly staff that know their shit, and a really neutral ambiance! I love this place and I try to go as often before class as I can! I love the branding on the to-go cups as well...real nice, and the in-house cups are really fancy and fun!

59.description: This place is like a wanna be Intelligentsia (in a good way), but their customer service skills are way better. The minimalist decor and atmosphere fits nicely with their menu choices - it screams "this is a coffee joint, dammit."  They definitely are no Starbucks -which is quite refreshing. One will not find a low-fat, hold the whip, mocha Frapaccino here.  One really nice touch - they place their to go order lids on a plate with a stir thingy. Loved that!

21.description: Very nice place spacious and open plan, coffee good, prices not so much..... It's to mainstream for the regular human, but then again I'm not a coffee expert, but I am more of a fan of those coffeeshops with heart warming vibes, and lost of treats to choose from and syrups!

17.description: Walking into La Colombe is like entering the Fortress of Solitude - giant, empty, lonely and cold. If only there were wifi so I could tap into the crystals and hear Marlon Brando's hologram expound on the glory days of Krypton. But alas. I've thrown multiple Yelp tantrums about coffee shops with no comfortable seating. If I wanted to hang out in prison, I'd loiter on 89th and Halsted while wearing a hoodie. Coffee shops should be cozy and welcoming. La Colombe is frigid and sterile. However, their coffee is pretty darn delicious. The almond milk latte is rich and airy all at once. Pastry selection is slim but generally tasty. I will continue to grudgingly suffer through five minutes of environment-induced depression to collect my scrumptious hipster beverage.

10.description: Great coffee.  Great space.  Nice service.  It's a coffee shop.  The only reason I can't give it a 5 is because it doesn't have wifi, and that's not made apparent to the customers until after a coffee has been ordered and they've sat down and pulled out their device to try and do some work...  If you're not going to offer wifi (who doesn't these days?!) at least make sure customers know in advance.This is the perfect coffee shop to go to read or write though.

5.description: Pleasantly surprised that they have wifi for customers now. Thank you very much. I will gladly spend my money here.

3.description: Amazing coffee in a relaxed, albeit overtly hipster, atmosphere.I first learned about La Colombe while watching co-founder Todd Carmichael's show "Dangerous Grounds" on the Travel Channel. It was amazing to see the passion he put into sourcing the finest ingredients from around the world. When he opened a shop just down the street in Andersonville, we were itching to give his coffee a shot. I was not prepared for what we found.I'll admit, that 9/10 I'll lean towards Starbuck's over any other coffee shops -- not that there's generally that much of a choice. I know a small handful of independent coffee shops in various cities that outclass the Seattle juggernaut, but those are far and few between, in my humble opinion.But when we walked into Colombe, that list just widened. It's obvious that not only do they source amazing coffee, but they put a lot of emphasis into teaching their baristas to prepare it the right way. Every brew I've tasted gives you so much unique flavor, never with any bitterness or excess acidity. They just KNOW how to take the best ingredients, use them in the right way to make the perfect brew.I especially love the pull taps for the cold coffee. I highly recommend trying a "Black and Tan" (cold brew coffee with whole milk). I'm generally a "straight black" drinker, but when I come to La Colombe, that rich, milky concoction is just too much to pass up. What I love is that they don't mess with the coffee flavor... no stupid peppermint sugar spiked bullshit. Just delicious coffee and the highest quality ingredients.If you're looking for the perfect spot for a cuppa Joe in the Andersonville neighborhood, skip the massive chain and come down to La Colombe.

35.description: Oh man, I love this coffee shop! I love the interior design, it makes me so inspired, I love how there's a lot of windows so when I need a break I could just look out and people watch in the eclectic Andersonville. They're not expensive at all, I got my drip coffee for only about $2, not bad! I am quite guilty though, because I'm one of those people who sit on a spot for hours on end sipping my drip coffee while I'm working on something in my laptop.. well that didn't really happen in this coffee shop because they didn't have wi-fi, and I love that idea. It controls the flow, people in, people out, and especially the fact that it makes you actually socialize with friends (when you bring friends with you ofc).

19.description: La Colombe is pretentious as fuck.Let me explain.One size only.  And it's very small.  What if I want a big-ass coffee the size of my head?  Nope.  Take it to Starbucks, sister.Flavored syrups?  Nope.  You will drink a plain latte and and you'll like it!Wifi?  Negative.  WTF?  This is a coffee shop!Worst of all, I don't like that there isn't a variety of sweeteners or even half and half.  You can add some milk.  Or sugar in the raw or stevia.  But what about people like me that like equal and cream?  Also - Not impressed with the flavor of the coffee.  It's not delicious.So yeah.  I'll take my business elsewhere.  I don't take my coffee that seriously.

28.description: Had a beautiful, delicious latte. Strong, smooth, rich coffee flavor. No syrups, but not a problem for me. I just want to taste a good coffee. La Colombe nailed it.Also tried a cherry scone, as recommended by the friendly barista. Amazing. Everything a scone should be, and you could actually taste the dried cherries.Will make it a regular stop for sure.

45.description: This place is what it advertises. They serve coffee and they take it pretty seriously. Their employees are always nice and helpful. They didn't have a menu at first but now they do. Yes there is no Wifi and the seating is designed so you don't stay there all day. If you want a place where you can get Wifi and camp out all day, go to Starbucks. It's right down the street. Starbucks is open for longer hours as well.However if you're more about coffee and less about the actual "extras" of a coffeehouse, then come here.

33.description: Trendy, sophisticated, and dedicated to the details.  I was very impressed with the setup while on our little shopping visit to Andersonville.

43.description: It can be a little pretentious, yes. No, they don't have wi-fi. But God damnit if I'm not in there daily for a great latte or Americano.  La colombe is exactly what this neighbourhood needed- great coffee without the high price point and attempts to take advantage of you (ahem, Kopi- I'm looking at you). Additionally, Half of the staff is friendly and half is merely polite, but all of them are professional and good at what they do. I feel good coming in to support this business.Also, free sparkling water. I can't get over that. Yes, yes and yes. :)

2.description: Great coffee, pastries, staff, and ambience! The coffee items are always served beautifully, the pastries are fresh, delicious, and pair well with the drinks. The staff members are also all very knowledgable on the coffee! The space itself is also very beautiful and open. My friend ordered the Cold Draft Coffee and the chocolate croissant, the Draft Coffee was strong yet fresh. The croissant was flaky and delectable!I ordered the hot classic latte and the Ham and Cheese Croissant. Both were spectacular as well!

18.description: I've only been in and out for coffee to go but the space looks very inviting. Cappuccinos here are fantastic. Parking is convenient due to the building being on a corner. Great coffee spot in Andersonville with very quick service.

41.description: I've been dying to try this place forever, but they don't open until 7am, and I have to be at work by 7am. Lame, but I get it. The only shop open early is Starbucks...but I'm trying to find a local business to support. I got to go into work late last Friday so I stopped in here for a latte. I couldn't find the menu, and finally spotted a small one next to the register...but I didn't see Vanilla syrup. I asked if they had vanilla syrup and they said no, but that they could make me a sweetened latte. Okay, that sounds good! Fine.  I get it, we're hip, we're different, we don't use syrup, whatever. I'm okay with that. I get my latte, and I can't even taste coffee is this thing. Is there any coffee in it? I have no idea. All I can taste is sour milk. Not impressed but I like to give businesses the benefit of the doubt and try them out at least twice. Maybe they have good hot chocolate! The latte here obviously isn't doing it for me so a few days later I stop in for a hot chocolate. Nope. Again, I'm not sure where the chocolate is. It tastes like sour milk with a teaspoon of bitter coco powder mixed in. It's not even brown...I couldn't even finish it. It was so gross I had to throw it away after a few sips. Maybe I just don't understand this place, but it's definitely not for me.

52.description: Just moved in down the street and was looking forward to a new coffee place. Came here with my GF on a Saturday morning to get some caffeine before we hit the gym.No line. Available seats. Quiet atmosphere. I'm not a fan of cashiers making a forced conversation. They do that here.We had read reviews that said they had hemp milk. We asked, they didn't. We both ordered lattes ($9 total) and sipped them away as we enjoyed each others company. The drinks were nothing special in my opinion.I prefer Starbucks but my GF say's everything is bitter there. We might come back if she is in the mood.

50.description: Not really a fan of this coffee shop. They offer dairy or hemp milk, personally I think hemp milk leaves an awful taste. Also they have a variety of pastries but nothing was labeled in the case so I had to ask what each item was ...

4.description: This place is a coffee Mecca in Andersonville for purists located in the heart of the restaurant district. Great service and a beautiful industrial type decor that I love in these type of low key coffee haunts. Great spot !

6.description: Such a beautiful coffee shop.I liked that there was a lot of natural light that streamed in from the abundance of windows. It is dog-friendly  as there was a treat jar and a watering bowl near the front door).I am really impressed at the size of this space. Many coffee shops are quite small and intimate with packed in tables. This place has high ceilings and a lot of space to move about with ease. I am also glad that I was able to sit and hang for a while as I got my latte for there, so it came in an adorable blue ceramic cup and saucer.What I know about coffee: triple-sugar-frothy-coolatta-diabetes type drinks are the devil to me. I cannot say that I am a coffee snob by any means, so I cannot attest to the roast but I really appreciated the fact that it is not super-sweetened right out of the gate. I put a smidge of sugar (if at all) in my coffee and I prefer to do it myself (which I was able to do).

22.description: Great place for a cup of coffee. Offers pour over and other specialties.  Pour over is overpriced though at $5 or $6 a cup.

15.description: Ok I have to say this about La columbe...it smells awful in there. I don't know if it's the remnants of the vitamin store that used to be in that same space or what. But smell is important to me and I'm immediately taken aback when I walk in. The atmosphere  is pretty but not at all inviting. The tables look like they are for elementary students. And the last coffee I had here was terrible and tasted burnt. I'm only giving this place 3 stars because the service is good and the barista are very nice and warm.

57.description: Friendly, kind customer service. The barista was very patient when I had a few questions about the menu. There are a variety of drinks: various espresso beverages including flat whites, brewed coffee, hot chocolate, hot tea etc. Excellent espresso beverages--the coffee stands on its own without needing to add a ton of crap. Great natural light inside, cosy, good calm ambience, and tons of seating. Excellent alternative in Andersonville to places like Starbucks. We are from the PNW and this is how we love our coffee!

20.description: Amazing coffee beans, with caffeine served up as fit for the gods - roasted perfectly and served with clean artistic simplicity and talent by genuine pros.  No Frappaslurpees or pumpkin Franken-coffee here.  You want that or free wi-fi?  There's probably a Starbucks somewhere around the next corner.  La Colombe is for people who appreciate quality java and know what coffee is actually supposed to taste like.  On the iced coffee alone you could fly to Guam.  Pure rocket fuel and 100% delicious.  That more than makes up for the slightly better than mediocre pastries they serve.  Nobody's perfect...

36.description: First time customer today. Really great coffee, but no WIFI??  Really??  I'm not a 3 hour lounger in a coffee shop, but at least offer an hour to your customers complimentary.

14.description: Brand new coffee and pastry place located in the heart of Andersonville at Clark and Foster. Very cozy feeling, wood tables, stools, exposed brick, and very spacious set up makes this place quite welcoming. Grabbed two coffees, light roast, which was delicious. Menu hasn't yet been posted so we were a bit blind in ordering, but service was fast and attentive at this location. Some tables are very near electric outlets and several patrons were here working, I would assume they have wifi but am not completely sure.The coffee was awesome, the place was welcoming and cozy, I'll definitely be back.

28.description: I agree with Nicoletta on this one.  I love that the place is packed with stuff, never know what you will find.  I have four great finds in my house from this place.  But still I cannot give it a four or five star.  Sometimes the store owners are nice and sometimes they are down right rude.  Some of their prices are fantastic and other times you question how the hell they came up with it.  Still, I keep going back when I'm doing the andersonville furniture circuit.

1.description: I called in and the gentleman who answered the phone was very helpful and went above and beyond to help me. I have been inside and while it is a bit overwhelming, it is very cool. I will be back!

39.description: Seriously, if you see something you like, BUY IT RIGHT THEN.  I cant tell you how many times I saw just the perfect thing and came back the next day to buy it and it was gone.  Shop is dirty, way too small and one hot mess, like trying to shop in someones storage unit, but the prices are really good for Andersonville.

9.description: This is one of the classiest joints in the neighborhood, and that is saying a lot. I'm going to go give them some more money now.  Ttyl.

29.description: Brownstone is one of the few antique shops I actually check out on a regular basis. Yes, it is....well, haphazard, I guess is the best word. But how often do you go into an antique shop and leave empty handed because all the beautifully displayed objects are overpriced? It's like a much more upscale Brown Elephant. I've found some great little pieces here and friends have found some awesome mid-century furniture for under $50 (I never have and I'm extremely jello of the fact!). I think this is a great little shop, with pieces priced to move. Unpretentious and fun!

42.description: I scored a pretty cool desk from this place. Not all that expensive, either. It's a fairly small second-hand store disguised as an "antique" place, with items ranging from black spiral columns to Port glasses. For odd-sized items, they'll even deliver for a small fee.NOTE: They're now located in a small storefront on Clark. Look for the stuff on the sidewalk.

23.description: eh... I allowed Yelp Reviews to guide me to Brownstone and I'm sure I'll never go back. Any Salvation Army location is cleaner than Brownstone. Shit is piled on top of shit in this store and everything is dusty. How can you even tell if you are looking at a decent item underneath huge piles of dust?I did find a vintage vanity table with a chair that I was mildly interested in. On top of the vanity was a pile of shit piled with dust and I'm convinced it would have taken me at least an hour to dig the vanity out. I quickly decided I wasn't going to do that and I left.

5.description: Yay:  I have bought a ton of stuff here.   These guys WANT their merchandise to move!.  The prices are generally lower than average for Chicago.  But yeah, it's kinda gnarly I like that.  I don't mind the mess at all.  A least they are not precious.  And the prices are arbitrary a bit, but they do bargain.  How do I know?  I have been shopping here for 15 years and 4 apartments.Boo:  after 15 years of regular shopping the owner is like a crabby Lion 87% of the time I visit.  Only under extreme duress will he deign to acknowledge that he recognizes me. or that I'm a longtime customer.  Except the 13% of the time that he is a goddam prince to me.  So there's that.

31.description: Now this is my kind of place!  You have to be ready to get your hands dirty here, but it is well worth it.  They have a ton of really gorgeous stuff that just needs the first few layers of dust and maybe a little grime stripped away and you have yourself a beautiful new piece of (insert what you're looking for).  I've been on a search for some shabby chic/vintage/basically not from Target dishes or decor.  I am hosting my first Thanksgiving for my family this year and my kitchen is bare bones.  So I was on the hunt for some pieces that bring it all together and allow me to still afford to eat.  This place was just perfect.  My mom and I dug through piles of china, furniture, light fixtures, furniture, clothing and general knick knackery and came out with a beautiful bone china cream and sugar bowl set and some hand painted plates of different shapes and sizes.  The cream and sugar set was priced at $15 but  was able to talk him down to $12 and the plates were a dollar a piece.  $15 cash, out the door.  There was other beautiful items that I would have scooped up if I had the cash such as a purple upholstered wing back chair that had me drooling but was priced around $200.  Worth the money...  Someone else's money.  Next time!

25.description: I've bought furniture here twice. The 1st time was a huge pottery barn sofa that they delivered. I mention the delivery part because they went over and above the usual service required. I mean that literally! My roommate at the time could not get the back gate opened so the deliverymen (who are also the store owners) climbed the gate, passed the huge sofa over it and then hiked it up to the 3rd floor for us! Thanks again! The most recent purchase was an art deco highboy I purchased for a $100 plus delivery, which they delivered that same day. This store is always worth a stop to check out what they have. It is overcrowded with stuff but when you find that one gem at that perfect price, it's all worth it!

12.description: Always a great time visiting the shop and the guys working there. They have great prices and interesting finds. Tons of lighting fixtures, china and crystals. We always find what we need in regards to crystals.

37.description: I am a huge fan of this store! It has to be my favorite "antique" place in my hood.It's a hot mess, but the dig is the most fun! The staff is so helpful and nice. I scored a few pieces for my store there, and I am usually in there a couple of times a month! :)

21.description: If you are looking for a classy elegant antiquing experience, go elsewhere.  This place is crammed with stuff. It's dirty. It's fun.If you love rooting through things looking for a fabulous find, reasonably priced, then you should head here.  It's the thrill of the hunt!

16.description: This is such a great shop! Really clever and carefully collected vintage furniture, prints, china, periodicals, and more. Well organized and friendly greeting from the shop owners. These guys have a great eye, and really well chosen and beautifully displayed things. Why go to tar-jey to decorate an apartment when there's places like this? Great stuff, nice place, priced right, interesting things, I'll be bahhhckkkk!

17.description: If you browse carefully you can find some really great things here.

10.description: This place has a really decent selection most of the time, and fairly good prices. The people who work here (I assume the owners?) are always very nice, but sometimes not the most helpful. Once I asked about the price of a shelf that was toward the north wall, beyond a pile of other stuff, and was told, "oh, we won't be getting that down today." The guy wasn't rude at all. It just seemed like he was very okay with not making that sale, which is fine, I suppose. I do like this place and have found many unique items.

11.description: If I could give a ten star, I would.  I have been coming to Brownstone for years and years, and what can I say, this is a gem and a half.  Bob and Tim are the most genuinely kind people I have ever met in my life.  They care beyond belief.  The only complaint I would ever have is that I get nervous walking into this place because I want everything and anything.  This is my happy place.  They are family to me, and I guess they are family to most people that walk in the door.  These gentlemen make running a business look like it is so easy, and let me tell you it is not.  They are open every single day, with the exception of Thanksgiving and Christmas Day.  Who does that? Well, they do.  The inventory changes every day.  They are more than fair.  The prices are amazing, and the quality is better than amazing.  They know about the history of most of their items, but also know about the quality, the year, how to use the different treasures.  They will even be so honest as to tell you if you actually need the item or not.  Again, who does that?  They do.  These two gentlemen are an inspiration.  They have helped me get my own business off the ground, and they talk me off the ledge at least once a week when I am freaking out.  The best thing is the therapy is free.  I thank the heavens that I stumbled into this place years ago, and I have been skipping into this place at least once a week ever since.  In fact, if I miss a week or two, they will call, not because they are looking for business, but because they actually care and want to make sure that I am ok.  Thank you thank you thank you God, for introducing me to Brownstone Antiques.  I would be lost without this treasure.

26.description: I come in here only twice a year and I am always reminded, immediately upon arrival, why it is so much better to keep it that way.  The owner of this store finds the most beautiful vintage armchairs, desks and chandeliers.  They are usually somewhere between $150-$400 and therefore out of my price range, but my god, even looking at them is a treat.  He's got an intriguing pile of vintage jewelry in the glass counter, but it's super disorganized and I have yet to come by when I have time to sort through it all.  Definitely on my to-do list.The good news is that every now and then he'll mark stuff down to under $100, generally things with some minor damage, and put them on the sidewalk for folks to see.  I always hope I'll by passing by at just the right moment.  That's how I scored my cream-colored, vintage loveseat, a little glass coffeetable, and most recently a few days ago: a darling, comfy, green-and-yellow-striped rocking armchair for my boyfriend.  Currently contemplating the $150 vintage wooden desk in there.  Sigh.

27.description: Now this is my kind of place! Sure, it's cramped and dirty, but very rarely do I leave empty-handed. I've come across two wonderful books (one about silent films and another about talkies) and one had several pictures of a delectable 24-year-old Dean Stockwell! Happy days! And, best of all, it had loads and loads of all pictures for me to complete the scrapbook to go along with the trilogy I'm writing. Huzzah! And they were CHEAP, too! I even found a creepy funeral one and some hillbilly wedding pictures. How can you NOT want to buy that if you're a writer looking for folks to represent your characters?All in all, this store is amazing. I pop in there more often than I should, but that's okay.Update: I recently scored a 1940's Royal typewriter for $35. It still works, too! I guess some folks are selling the same typewriter for $250 on Ebay, so I got a deal! Huzzah!

35.description: Yesterday I was looking for a chair I could reupholster for a class I'm  starting tonight. I found some great furniture and inspiration in here. It's stuffed to the gills but almost everything had a clearly marked price. The prices were decent too. Some stuff made me say 'Ooh' out loud. Pity I don't have the room for any of it. I ended up buying a chair up the street at Brown Elephant but I'll be back at this place I'm sure.

8.description: Some really great antiques in here... I really enjoyed browsing and if it had been another time, and I didn't have to transport said antiques all the way back to the 'burbs, I probably would have made some purchases.

0.description: Really like this spot, the proprietors are quiet yet friendly, letting you browse without being overbearing. Prices are great here - a whole hodgepodge of things from furniture to kitchenware to completely random knickknacks (last time I went there was a wicker basket full of creepy doll odds and ends). You can definitely find a bunch of hidden diamonds in the rough here, and the prices are very reasonable (if not downright cheap). I've noticed it's especially great for finding affordable mirrors (most large mirrors I saw were around $20). Definitely my favorite antique/thrift shop to pop into on this stretch of Clark Street.

38.description: I love this store.  It is dirty and almost overwhelmingly crowded, but they have great stuff for great prices.  (they rival most thrift shops in town.) The owners are nice, too, which is an added bonus.  I second the suggestion of snatching something up when you see it, because things turn over really fast. Great spot!

20.description: Unique finds at reasonable prices! They always have new merchandise arriving, so check them out when you are in Andersonville!

19.description: This is what I want out of an antique store.  Stuffed piled onto stuff, which means you have dig sometimes to find treasures.  But that's part of the fun right?  You can pretend you're on American Pickers.  Wife dug through a plastic bin and found a fabulous vintage hat.  Owners are friendly and knowledgeable and will help you find what you're looking for.  Prices are extremely reasonable too.

33.description: Man, i wish i was more loquacious so i could do my LOVE for Brownstone justice with flowery adjectives.  Quite frankly, this is my happy place. I walk by the storefront all the time, and whether they are open and have funky wares out on the street, or it's late at night and i'm left to admire the narrative display in their window, there is always something to see and a story to imagine.  Going inside is a slightly different experience.  That the story isn't laid out for you in normal fashion.  You have to comb trough and find what's there.  This place is also my secret weapon for any occasion gifts.  I have no idea what their return policy is, i just tell people i give gifts to that they can return it to me and i'll give them cash.  In fact, every gift i've ever given from here i was loath to part with, but to give is better than to receive, yes? At any rate, this store is magnificent.  Everything is reasonably priced, more like a thrift store than an antique store, and they have stuff as covetable as Scout and White Attic.  I wish i were there right now.

2.description: This place is packed to the gills, slightly dirty and shabby, but packed with treasures. I've purchased several things here over the years, and it's always been something really unique. Lots of stuff. I can never stay in here too long 'cos hoarder anxiety starts to set in, but it fun to rummage around every now and then. There are a LOT of treasures here. Heavy on dishes/glassware, so if you are into vintage that, this is worth a visit. The prices seem a lot better than some of the more pristine stores on Clark.

34.description: You should check it out. It's reliably stocked and reliably surprising. Some stuff is ridiculously over-priced or could be worth what they're asking. You never know. The staff could be saccharine or surly. Gotta go in to find out!Always good for a gander, a $45 milk glass candy dish, a piece to re-varnish and re-purpose, a papasan frame, and a steel filing cabinet. You don't know what it will be, but you'll be far too curious to keep walking.

32.description: I love this place. The owners are really nice guys and I think the taste level/quality of their offerings is pretty high. Also, their delivery charge is so cheap compared to other furniture stores. The store is crowded and there are some items that read more junk shop than antique store, but overall, I am so happy with the furniture I've bought from here and I check back frequently for more.

18.description: This place is crazy, it's still a clusterf**k of stuff but there are lots of great furniture pieces at decent prices if you're willing to dig.  They have trays and trays of jewelry all crammed in the front case, although everything is so jumbled together and the owner isn't the happiest to dig through it.  The rest of the store is really reasonably priced, but the jewelry is expensive.  At least, I think jewelry should be cheap if it's shoved in a bin with some broken pieces and next to an old Butterfinger wrapper.  But if you like the thrill of the hunt, this place is for you.

41.description: I have never left empty handed.The overhead is low, so the prices are too.  No pretense here, but be prepared to dig, and don't wear anything you don't want to get dirty.  The shop needs a good dusting - but again, less over head, lower prices.I have literally furnished my apartment (used to live right upstairs) with this place.  The pieces are in good shape, and the guys that own it have good eyes for style.  Once you get the piece(s) home,  give them a good polish or wash.  Its easy!There are bargains to be had, and the stock changes VERY frequently.  They put stuff out on the sidewalk in the mornings, but it goes fast.  If you like it, buy it. It won't be there later.I purchased a deco dresser set there, and they polished it up before I came back to pick it up.  They don't bother you and ask if they can help you find things - know what you are looking for and DIG!  This is totally my favourite antique shop in the city. It is affordable, and in a great location.   An Andersonville gem.

13.description: If you are looking for a classy elegant antiquing experience, go elsewhere.  This place is crammed with stuff. It's dirty. It's fun.If you love rooting through things looking for a fabulous find, reasonably priced, then you should head here.  It's the thrill of the hunt!

4.description: This place is great!I work just down the street, so I walk past here everyday. I've been looking for a small dresser for my studio apt. Went in several times. Found many items I wanted ( but out of my budget)Last week, I went in & found the perfect little oak dresser for only $65 in great condition. I told the owner I would be back for it (if it was still there next time I was in).As luck would have it, I stopped in to see what else they may have gotten in. The dresser was still there! I walked right up to counter & bought it. I asked the owner if they could deliver tomorrow. He asked other owner if he wanted to deliver it tonight after they closed @ 6.Great!  They arrived about 6:10. Carried it up the 6 steps to my apt, & placed in right where I wanted it.Very nice guys. I will definitely be a repeat customer! Thanks.

24.description: I love this store.  It's filled with treasures ranging in price from a few bucks up into the hundreds. You'll find vintage jewelry, clothing, art, furniture ranging from fine antiques to second hand but usable, and the occasional my God that's weird I have to have it item. The owners Tim and Bob are great guys who are willing to deal on certain items, and will deliver what you can't manage to get home on your own.New things come in most everyday. This really is a store you want to keep dropping by at least once or more a week. Everyday if it were possible would be the best. You really never know what these guys are going to come up with next.

6.description: Short version: great variety of stuff from books to furniture, you will always find a treasure, helpful and nice owners, incredibly reasonable delivery charges.Long version: my partner and I found a set of amazing Deco dressers here that we really wanted, but it seemed like it would be a major hassle to get them to our apartment. When I expressed this to the owner, not only was he willing to store the dressers for us until we were ready, the delivery was only $30. SOLD.I ended up having to leave the dressers with them for longer than anticipated, but they had no problems with that. Then the day of delivery they were late...and it turned out their truck broke down. Instead of reschedule, they got an SUV and brought the dressers one at a time! No extra charge! They were so fantastic.Love everything!
