The food was warm, not hot. It looked as if all the cheese hadn't melted. Did I do anything about it? No, I was hungry, and I chowed down. It was good, but nothing spectacular.My friend Mary O. ordered Bistec Mexicana. It looked like enough food to serve Santa Ana's army, but she was really hungry, too. She said it was delicous, but very spicy. (She had been forewarned about the spiciness, so no fault to the server there). She really liked it, but she had to blow her nose about every third bite, and eat the tortillas to absorb the heat. Again, she really liked it, just was a little blown away by the heat. Well, it was a miserably cold day after all, and having clear sinuses in February can be a good thing.I expected to have a check brought around eventually, but that never happened. My friend explained to me that, in Mexico, the customer is expected to go to the counter and ask for the bill, and that's what we did. To sum it up, it was a good experience, nothing special. The waitress was very pleasant, albeit, to my mind, kind of slow and inattentive. Oh well. The place doesn't pretend to be the Pump Room. For what it is, it's probably a good deal. If it were a choice between this place and one of the three places we tried to go to, I would go to one of the others.

2.description: I was told when I dined there in the summer that they were getting a new menu soon and a rewards program. Every time I check to see if they have a new menu, they say no. Old menu is average.

18.description: Great for what you pay! Food is cheap, well flavored, and usually great service. Atmosphere is a hit or miss depending on if they have karaoke or large parties in there.

41.description: We were pleasantly surprised!   The place was empty, but the food was actually really good!  The chips were chips...   The salsa/sauces were spicy!We had the queso fundido with poblanos.  Just the perfect spice... and a huge portion!!Our meals - VERY large!!   My wife had the Combinacion - which was a huge plate of food.  She couldn't believe how much food was on the plate!I had the tilapia - which was delicious - smothered in a crushed tomato and poblano mixture.... Again - so much food.They are in the entertainment book (save $6).... and we would go back!

52.description: This restaurant has a little appeal to my 5-yr-old son and I:  it is across from the jewel (easy) and it is filled with wagon wheels and old guns (the Spanish Colonial theme, perfect for families.) We have come here quite a few times. There are two dishes I like. The enchiladas suizas, and the chicken tacos. Today I was told they were "out" of chicken.  How is that even possible? Edgewater Market is next door. The carne asada, carne al pastor, all that, is completely average. The salsa on the tables is the kind restaurants purchase by the gallon -- not fresh, all filler. The service is usually pretty bad. Not that the waitresses are unpleasant, but they get so enmeshed talking to male clients at the diner-style counter, it's hard to get their attention. It takes a cartwheel or mad waving of the arms, if that even works. Sometimes there are telenovelas interrupting our meal with gut-wrenching screams and acts of violence, as well. That's far from agreeable. It might dawn on them that possibly such inconsideration loses them business?Furthermore, there is a $10 credit-card minimum, which is so inconvenient. (And illegal.) Somehow, everytime I come here, a HUGE mexican family comes in to sit down for a joyous meal. And I can't help but wonder....What exactly are they ordering? Do they have a secret menu full of REAL Mexican food, especially for these patrons? In fact, almost all of the customers are Mexican. So I am very confused. Why...How...What?  Where are all these Mexicans coming from and why do they keep coming back to eat this marginal food? Up in Rogers Park there are  10 places along Clark that blow this place out of the water.

50.description: Me: [text] "Moving sale was a bust. I think I'm going to get a burrito."Matt: [text] "Do it!"I've passed Los Arcos for years now ...Usually opting to pick up a large horchata at Las Paraditas (now "Real Azteca") or further up at El Norte ...I'd spent the better part of my last day off from work, running errands throughout the neighborhood, stopping here or there + browsing a yard sale or two. My stomach started to grumble + having skipped breakfast, passed at lunch ...I decided why not have my major meal of the day a bit early. I was out, it was a nice day and well, you get the picture. I was surprised by the decor inside Los Arcos, which greatly outshines the exterior. It was surprisingly comfy + I quickly seated myself at far table. I was the second customer ...I glanced over to the other occupied table ...A Mother + infant, both covered in refried beans + spilled soda. Fantastic. I was soon greeted by my waitress, a basket of tortilla chips, two squeeze bottles of red/ green salsa + a small bowl of the refried beans that I had a preview of thanks to the baby nearby. Amusing enough, the beans resembled the wall color.  Orange + rusty. Though given the sun shining through the front window, I think the walls were warmer than the beans. I ordered my usual: veggie burrito w/ no cream, no cheese + extra avocado, large horchata. I actually ordered this twice, since my waitress came back to double-check. Me: [text] "You're here in spirit." Matt: [text] "What am I doing?"Me: [text] "Ordering goat stew, amazed by the beans that come with the chips + wondering why I'm reading Hoy! when I don't know Spanish."Matt: [text] "I'm awesome. Why ARE you reading Hoy?"Me: [text] "I didn't bring a book + I'm all alone!"The first thing I noticed as my plate made it's way to the table were those all too familiar (by now) beans. My burrito was oozing with them ...Have you ever seen footage of the sunken Titanic? The decks, the mast, the various gadgets of yesteryear ...Corroded/covered in barnacles + discolored sea algae ...My burrito sort of looked like that. Me: [text] "Oo my this place loves their beans! Major beanage!"It was a good size, sort of Titanic-like, I suppose ...I took a bit + grabbed the salsa verde. All I tasted was pasty beans ...My next bite, I found some lettuce + onion. NO tomato, hmm ...And after a few more bites I found a chunk of avocado. I drizzled a little bit of red ...Which tasted like dirt (I was a champion mud-pie maker in my heyday so I can make such expert comparisons). I made it through half of my burrito, slurping down my horchata (which was the highlight of my meal) ...For the second half of my burrito, I decided to fish out the remaining avocado (I was paying an extra 30 cents for it, afterall) + eat it plain. That's as far as I could make it ...I tidied up my plate, finished my horchata, gathered my bag (I coughed a few times but my waitress was very intent on cleaning the beans off of the nearby table) ...I went up to the counter, paid my check ($8.20 + tip) + off I went. Me: [text] "Oo boy was it not good. What have I done!? It's times like this I wish I were bulimic." Matt: [text] "I'll avoid it. Bad burrito. No thank you."Me: [text] "I'm so bummed."Matt: [text] "It's ok. Next time, slugger!" I think from now on I'll just continue walking.

4.description: Ok - I can only speak to a few things on their menu:Tacos - Steak, Chorizo and Pastor - my husband LOVES these tacos.  I always get those three for him.For me - I love their steak chilaquiles with red sauce - they are so satisfying and spicy!!! The red sauce is sooo hot but so good.  I usually request for extra sour cream to help with the heat levels.

6.description: For the price, it was good, but nothing special. Wish the server was a bit more attentive. Didn't receive a drink refill, and took 10 min to get a check when there was only 4 people total eating.  Wish the chips came with salsa too, not canned refried beans.

22.description: To be honest I am not  sure how this place remains open.  Every time we are here we are the only ones there.  Either way this is your typical taco joint that has been serving Aville for many years.  Friendly service brings traditional Mexican fare.  Burritos, chips, salsa, quesidillas and enchiladas have all been consumed.  The food is decent and falls into the not gonna blow your socks off nor induce vomiting.  They do not server alcohol here but have a BYOB sign in the window.

15.description: This is a quick eat & run Mexican food place.  They serve typical American's favorite Mexican food like taco, burritos, quesadillas and etc.  they serve decent food and the service is excellent.  The two waitresses are very friendly and attentive.  They made me want to patronize their business.Keep in mind although this is not a fancy place, they do serve decent food with affordable prices.  I strongly recommend!!!!

57.description: If not for the warm bean dip served with the basket of tortilla chips, this place probably would have been a 1-star review.  So, I know I shouldn't have high expectations for cheap Mexican food, but I do.  At $5.35, their Burrito Suizo is over-priced. Ouch.  All that said, I would still go back.  It's really fine for what it is...inexpensive Mexican food that doesn't taste all that great...provided you can live without a Margarita or cerveza...they don't appear to have a liquor license.  So wait, why did I say I would come back here again...? Hmm...

20.description: The food was AMAZING! We ordered 2 carnitas tacos, a carnitas gordita, and horchata. Every thing was EXCELLENT. Good carnitas are SO hard to find and theirs were outstanding. The portions were large, everything was cooked how it was supposed to be, and the price was decent. Delivery was through GrubHub and it was right on time. I would give it SIX stars if I could!

36.description: Have been here a few times.  It's not "fine mexican cuisine" near as I can tell.  It's decent Mexican food as far as I'm concerned.  I don't understand how they stay open, I never see people in here.  Last night went in and had dinner.  Started with a cheese quesadilla.  It was not what I was expecting, but it was pretty good.  Plenty of cheese and corn tortilla it was served on was nice and warm and kind of stiff. For dinner I had the Chicken with Mole Sauce.  It was pretty good.  The sauce was pretty spicy--- I love spice.  I know mole is subject to change batch to batch and house to house, so that's great.  I had a glass of horchata with it.  Service was pretty decent (better than I've had before).  Overall, its one of the better times I have been here. (Been 4 times before).  Seems there is a bit more passion in the food than before as far as flavors and presentation.  More attentive service than what I have received previously from here and priced well.I am giving a total of 3 stars on this one because of previous experience and their chips and salsa is not really my thing.  I like chips and chunky salsa and these peeps do something closer to a picante sauce.

14.description: Love their food and service... They're open late which is an added benefit for someone like me... They also have delivery service... I like the place mainly because it's very casual... The staff is very friendly... Their tortillas are absolutely fresh.. I like to grab a jarritos every time I come here..

58.description: Finally made a trip to this bookstore...every other time I've been to Chicago, I've been unable to visit.  Something about the time it takes to get here from the downtown area.  I am so glad we stopped here!  Truly women and children first, very welcoming and helpful and overrun with amazing books.  Lots of books on parenting and culture.  One suggestion would be more 'zines! There was only a small shelf dedicated to these and graphic novels.Wish I could have been able to buy more from them, I was overwhelmed and my wallet was nearing empty.  I always like to support local bookstores!

56.description: It pains me to give this place such a bad review. I have tried multiple times to like this store or be impressed by their selection or staff and have come up sorely disappointed each time. Let's start with their selection. It makes no sense and doesn't seem to be governed (or arranged) by reason. I could not find the majority of the authors I was looking for (such as Le Guin, Barrie, and Lennox) but then turned the corner to find titles such as Twilight. :/ Really? Twilight? I don't think I've ever seen a modern fiction series so inherently sexist and damaging. Yet it is offered here? In calling yourself 'Women & Children First", you are inherently making a judgment call and signifying that *your* books will be more accessible and suited for women and children. You also suggest that you will possess books that are less exclusionary and sexist. The Faludi books they had were, for some reason, cataloged under women and gender studies. You do her a great disservice by not placing her in politics where she belongs. She is an author who writes about politics and criticizes politics, government, and popular media. Their ecology section possessed no ecofeminist authors of note and was instead a hodgepodge of uninformed backyard theorists with no discernible experience or knowledge in or of ecology. You won't find many good children's and young adult titles here either. But, rest assured, there is plenty of smut. Sigh. Then there is the staff. Unfriendly every time I have gone in with my little sister and nieces. The only time I have gotten even remotely good service is when I went with my female friend and my girlfriend. Each time, a (presumably) lesbian attendant materialized right behind us upon the moment of entry to be overly attentive and creepy. Ignore the fact that I was clearly *with* my girlfriend and mull this over. This should be a safer space for women to shop without being leered at or creeped on like they could do at any other store. Again, your NAME implies this should be a less uncomfortable type of place for them. My mind is literally boggled by this place. Quite honestly, it seems as if it some self-satisfied second-waver's half-assed attempt at being 'inclusive'. But it fails miserably and the only thing they offer here that is different from other book stores is higher prices and a mostly female staff. A thoroughly disgusting place that has disappointed me this entire year. Sorry, I tried to like you guys but you seem hellbent on alienating anyone who is educated in the field you suggest you cater to and who isn't okay with their friends, TEENAGE sister, and girlfriend being creeped on.

29.description: It's a good store, but every time I go in or pass by, I can't stop thinking about ''women and women first'' bookstore from Portlandia.

42.description: I have yet to purchase anything (poverty is rough) but I absolutely love this store. Having been partly raised in a local bookstore that my mother managed, I have an affinity for such places. Women & Children First know how to do a small bookstore right. The place is well lit, with more books than you could possibly look through in one afternoon. The staff are friendly and they have a lovely selection of common bookstore knick-knacks near the front if you happen to be waiting for a friend to make her purchase. I'd like to come back with funds and support the place, but until then I'll keep stopping by to browse and talking it up to everyone I know.

23.description: Too bad this place is closing. Although it is not the type of bookstore that has a wide range of autors and titles to choose from, it does have a lot of interesting books and not only on feminist topics.

47.description: Love, love, love this bookstore.  I live in Andersonville and have frequented WCF for years.  The staff could not be more friendly and helpful.  They have a fantastic kids section.

8.description: Don't let the name deter you, this is an amazing book shop for folks of all gender and age identities. The selection is terrific for both young adult and classic fic/nonfic reading. The staff is not only knowledgeable, but also personable and passionate about the service they provide. I've bought a number of books from this shop (as well as stationary) and have yet to be disappointed. I also really like that there are more books than toys or gadgets or notions or whatever. Many big box stores you walk in and can't tell immediately if it's a book store or a toy store, a computer store, a café or what, which is irritating. That said, if you're like many book nerds and feel sudden, unexplainable urges to be surrounded by books, this is a great place to do it. My only complaint is the floor plan is difficult to navigate and kind of wonky.

31.description: The difference between an independent bookseller and Amazon/B&N/etc is the incredibly knowledgeable staff. I went to W&CF in search of picture book with multiracial characters as a gift for my friend's son. I spoke with a woman at the front register and within five minutes, she handed me several beautifully illustrated books with characters that reflected my friend and her family. My friend was thrilled when she saw the interracial couple featured in the book as the main character's parents. Children's literature is rife with a few themes: princesses,  heteronormative families, and white characters. Women and Children First has an incredible selection of books to help you break out of those limits. Bravo!

34.description: I often find myself stopping in "just for a minute" only to spend an hour browsing. They have a great New Releases section, and shelves peppered with staff reviews and recommendations. I've never had a problem with service here; they're available when you need them, and otherwise they leave you to browse. I've also found perfect gifts here: a tongue-in-cheek psychology activity book for my counselor sister, a gorgeous ballet coffee table book for a dancer friend, and a photography collection of destroyed chew toys for my dog-loving mother. Of course many of their wares can be found online for cheaper, but for more unique offerings, this is still a go-to store.

16.description: The difference between an independent bookseller and Amazon/B&N/etc is the incredibly knowledgeable staff. I went to W&CF in search of picture book with multiracial characters as a gift for my friend's son. I spoke with a woman at the front register and within five minutes, she handed me several beautifully illustrated books with characters that reflected my friend and her family. My friend was thrilled when she saw the interracial couple featured in the book as the main character's parents. Children's literature is rife with a few themes: princesses,  heteronormative families, and white characters. Women and Children First has an incredible selection of books to help you break out of those limits. Bravo!

13.description: Once again we find ourselves as a family wandering  in to Women and Children First just to see what they will recommend. Over the past two decades we come here to pick up children's books to travel books, and bestsellers to obscure titles.  This place is a gem and certainly a source of pride for the community and city.

11.description: Everyone was so nice and friendly! They have a wide selection of books and a great children's section.

39.description: here's what i love: great, local readers and community events. a well curated staff picks section. excellent historical fiction, lgbt books, cards, cookbooks that make me dream of spending all day in the kitchen. best of all - helpful staff that never bothers you when you feel like reading half a book in the store. thanks neighborhood feminist bookstore!

37.description: WCF is one of only seven feminist bookstores left in the US so no matter how holier-than-thou, rude and snobbish the staff becomes, I will continue to shop here. But seriously, the staff is the worst. That being said, it's a locally owned independent progressive business that deserves to be supported. When I'm there, I like to pretend that it's like a fun rude staff themed event or that I'm actually in Paris where everyone is stuck up, which really puts the fun back into being ignored and/or dismissed. I'm willing to ignore being ignored because I love supporting an independent progressive business, which just happens to staffed with the worst bookstore employees since the invention of moveable type.

0.description: I love this place, and I'm neither a woman nor a child!  This has been a fixture in Andersonville for ages, and I'm so glad it exists; we need more places like it.  It's not only an excellent indie bookstore, with a terrifically curated selection and a super-helpful and accommodating staff, but also a business that caters to a particular audience (one that often gets short shrift in other ways).  I've been coming here for shopping and for readings for over a decade, and I'm never disappointed with their choice of books, their service, or their determination to be an important part of the community.  Here's hoping it sticks around for many more decades to come.

38.description: I like this place. I like it a lot. Maybe because I'm a woman and  I was once a child and I stepped foot into a place where their sign spoke to me. It's your typical bookstore atmosphere on the outside...but look deeper and you will see the most unique cards, books, and knickknacks for your gift-giving needs to your fellow girlfriends, mothers, daughters, aunts, and female friends. Oh, and children. Men, don't think this place isn't for you.  I have seen plenty of Andersonville males looking for Mother's Day presents and cards here. In fact, I got my mama a card here....it made her cry. Tears of happiness. Go to this store! You won't be disappointed!

51.description: I really love this store. If I lived over in this area I would frequent it much more but as it is, it is a "once in awhile" treat to get books and other merch from here. No matter as it is always worth the trip!I really like the children's literature section as it is quite extensive and includes a lot of titles you might not see in other bookstores like "King & King" and "And Tango Makes Three." It's something really special when you can find those hard-to-find books without a problem!What really makes this place special is the atmosphere. The employees are always nice and not only willing to show you to the book you are looking for, they are also full of suggestions of books you might like as well. To me, that makes me feel very welcomed.It's easy now to go to Amazon and buy books, everyone knows that. Places like this, although few and far between, make it worth your while to come in and talk to your bookseller.

27.description: I love, love, love this indie bookstore and plan to visit often.  The staff was engaging and fun.  The book selection was wonderful!!!  I never walk out without purchasing several items. Most are books, but they also carry fun games and gift items.If you are a bookstore junkie...don't miss this one!

32.description: Just wanted to give a quick shout out to Women and Children First - in addition to being always generally awesome, I just got the brand new Chicagoland Vampires book a day earlier and a dollar cheaper than I would have through Amazon. Go independent local booksellers!!

54.description: I have been going to this bookstore for years and it really is the best! They have a great selection of books for everyone of all interests and on the off chance that they don't have a book you are looking for, they will order it for you on the spot. The staff is incredibly helpful and knowledgeable and have always been able to answer whatever question I come in with. I can't tell you how many times over the years I have gone in there wanting to buy girl positive books for my young nieces and have never left disappointed or empty handed. The parking lot behind the store is a great bonus in a neighborhood that can be tricky to find parking, but it's also super convenient to access via public trans. Make a trip to Women and Children First and just like the bumper sticker says, "Support Your Local Feminist Bookstore!"

48.description: Every time I enter this store, I feel like I'm not welcome--probably because, as a lady friend of mine puts it, "you have a shaft."But it's a great store for those who are women.  Or children.  I guess.  :)

44.description: Love this place. I buy textbooks here whenever I can.

24.description: Looking for good feminist books?  Stop into this place.  The staff is very knowledgeable about what they have on hand.  The store is also well laid out, making it easier to find subjects.  From time to time, they have events where authors come by to do book signings and sometimes have discussions.

7.description: So, this store totally reminds me of the feminist bookstore in portlandia - like they might have actually filmed a few episodes here.  :)That being said, I really enjoy this bookstore - it has a decent selection, friendly staff and from what I can tell they're really involved in the neighborhood. Going in at various times and days throughout the week, they have had book clubs going on. A large selection of feminist, lesbian and gay literature as well. Definitely a must stop in for any book lover.

49.description: A tremendous resource to the community, and a real asset to the neighborhood. Andersonville: Don't take your local independent bookstore for granted! Take advantage of all Women & Children First has to offer.

40.description: I had heard about this store via the internet and finally found time during a visit to Chicago to check it out.  I went into the store intending to browse for maybe an hour and came out... almost three hours later.  Mostly this had to do with their awesome children's section, which had a ton of books about women and girls of color (and some boys of color) succeeding in various fields.  I am always on the lookout for such books, as it pertains to my day job, and I rarely find so many all in one place.  So that was excellent.Like other reviewers, I was sad to see Twilight on the shelves, but I'm also a realist who understands that booksellers need to make a living like everyone else.  Also, a lot of women read those books so that they understand the message their daughters/other young women in their lives might be picking up from the hype, so there is a feminist angle to stocking them (know thy enemy).I didn't interact with the staff, but conversely, they didn't seem at all concerned that I was browsing/reading through their store for hours without buying anything (and, yes, I'm a woman, but a very feminine one whom everyone assumes is straight).There were several children there with their families when I was there, which was nice.  (See!  Kids still read!)  I liked the women and gender studies sections.  I agree with other reviewers that the selection isn't comprehensive the way that, say, the selection at the University of Michigan graduate library's is, but it's a bookstore, not a huge academic library.  I would argue that it is significantly, substantially better than the selection at Barnes and Noble.  Mostly, I had a really pleasant time perusing a women and children centered, independent bookstore, and maybe next time I visit, I'll have the cash and luggage-space to actually buy things!

53.description: This is my favorite bookstore ever. I love the suggestions and they have never steered me wrong. Some of my favorite books were found here based on the staff recs. Just a really lovely place to visit.

30.description: I have mixed feelings about this store, hence the 3 stars. Like lots of commenters, I want to support independent bookstores, and have gone in here many times. Usually I leave with something interesting to read. The staff seem to be well-informed about the books, and a couple of times the person who helped me was able to come up with some very good suggestions. (One of these people was one of the owners.) I find browsing difficult, partly because of the layout. There doesn't seem to be much effort to make an enticing display, which is a shame. The lighting is rather glaring and there are really *no* comfortable chairs for browsing through your stack of potential purchases. The staff (aside from the owners) is very uninterested in the (potential) customers, though, and most of the staff who I've encountered are so standoffish that it's a severe shortcoming of the store. (I hope the owners will think more about this, as several reviewers have made the same comment!!) While I don't want someone to hover, I would like them to say hello or welcome, and ask if they can help me find something, and then to seem genuinely happy that I made a purchase. (I mean, customers are making your job possible, and you aren't being asked to do anything beyond basic good customer service!) And if I'm wandering around browsing forever, how about if a staff member comes over to ask if she can find something or suggest something for me? This is a big reason for going to an indie store instead of buying from Amazon. They have some interesting author events, and good book clubs.

46.description: I've learned this is best for perusing aimlessly or picking up something just released and bound to be at any bookstore... not for heading in with your heart set on any certain title. This isn't a bad thing, just set expectations. They have plenty of options to catch your eye and most of the highly anticipated releases are regularly on display. It's definitely my go-to bookstore and I always find something to feed my lit lust.

1.description: Nice little independent bookstore. I prefer to support bookstores like this. I enjoyed the personally written recommendation notes. It helped me to pick a new book to add to my collection. I also enjoyed their magazine variety as it can be hard to find some of the magazines that I read in actual print (usually just read online).

55.description: I have tried so, so hard to like this place because there just aren't enough independent feminist bookstores in the U.S. But I've been in here more times than I can count and it's always an awful experience.Their selection is outdated and, well, very poor. The environment is not particularly warm or inviting and every time I'm there at night, the bare fluorescent bulbs suck the juice right out my eyeballs.The service is horrible and the employees have zero social skills. Seriously, if you hate people so much, maybe you shouldn't be in customer service. And y'know what, I get that I'm not an obvious member of the crunchy vegan queer kid club, but I am your neighbor, and I've been supporting this place for three years. It really would not kill you to crack a smile and pretend to tolerate the people who shell out the money that keeps your doors open. It might even help the business and benefit the Andersonville community in general.I appreciate that this place is competing with Amazon -- hence the truly absurd 200% mark-ups. But being independently owned is just not a good enough reason to support a mediocre business. They're not going to last long unless they can engage customers with a unique and positive experience that can't be got anywhere else.

9.description: I love, love, love this indie bookstore and plan to visit often.  The staff was engaging and fun.  The book selection was wonderful!!!  I never walk out without purchasing several items. Most are books, but they also carry fun games and gift items.If you are a bookstore junkie...don't miss this one!

26.description: This bookstore speaks to EVERY aspect of my identity. I have yet to find a multicultural feminist bookstore that provides me with dopeness outside of academic suggestions, until now! Luckily this gem was within walking distance of my summer home. I spent more than I anticipated; I regret nothing. Simply put, I love this joint.

25.description: I love this book store!  Man I spend a lot of money here because I like the staff any book I want is available here. Also I live really close right on Balmoral.  But I guess that's kind of a bonus because I am able to frequent this book store.With that being said the store is close to my home, any book I want is available here I also feel they have more to offer.  I enjoy the diversity.  The store is clean the employees are there if you need help I do not see them hovering me as I shop.  If I need help I ask, if I do not need help they let me shop therefore this is a good shopping experience for me, that's the way I like to shop.I would definitely highly suggest to go to this bookstore.  Employees are very nice even the customers.  The customer seem to be very friendly and I have met a few friends there.  So when I see negative reviews on this bookstore it definitely confuses me because there's nothing more I can ask for great people, great books and  great shopping experience!

12.description: This bookstore speaks to EVERY aspect of my identity. I have yet to find a multicultural feminist bookstore that provides me with dopeness outside of academic suggestions, until now! Luckily this gem was within walking distance of my summer home. I spent more than I anticipated; I regret nothing. Simply put, I love this joint.

59.description: This is one of my favorite bookstores in Chicago. They have a fantastic selection of books and the staff is wonderful. I felt so welcome and at home there. I found up two amazing books there, my favorite of which was A Return To Innocence by Kathleen Beales. A great book found at a great bookstore.

21.description: Will probably write a follow-up review once the store switches owners, but as is, this place is fabulous. Despite its independent status, the selection is great - no, not all the books here are die-hard feminist treatises. They have plenty of best-sellers, literary fiction, and non-fiction. As a fan of paper products, I also appreciate their great selection of notecards. My sister and I were just looking around and were asked if we needed help finding something, but we didn't feel pressured to buy anything. Well organized and open space- definitely worth a visit!

17.description: I love bookstores! And this one has an amazing selection of feminist literature and nonfiction, and an entire section of lesbian fiction!! It's probably a good thing that I don't live anywhere remotely nearby this store, otherwise I'd be in here all the time spending my money.

10.description: They've remodeled and the store has a more upbeat attitude. You know what you're getting with the selection, but they definitely go beyond what you expect.

5.description: The greatest collection of feminist books I have ever come across. An entire wall is dedicated to gender studies. They have magazines and postcards and magnets and more. Also a really great children's section, with books that I wish were around when I was a child. I almost want to have kids just to read them these books. But in the meantime I will stick to the hundreds of fiction/nonfiction/collections/poetry/biography/etc that this store has to offer.

3.description: This is a great bookstore!  They provide a welcoming place and even have book groups for those looking to meet with people once per month and discuss their current selections.  If you'd like something they don't have, they can order it for you and get it within a couple of days.  Great selection, great suggestions, great space!

35.description: So I am all for buying local.  I called W&C First to order a book for a friend as a holiday present.  The nice elderly woman looked it up and was happy to tell me they could get the book in by 12/20.  Great!  Just in time for the holiday.  Well, 12/20 comes and goes and no phone call to let me know the book arrived.  I called today to see if it was arriving late or maybe they just forgot to call.  Nope, after 10 minutes on hold I am told that the book was not ordered.  Strange..because not only did the woman tell me it was ordered but she called me back that same day to confirm the number I left.  Now I am scrambling to find the book.  Guess I should have went with the chain or mail order afterall.  Disappointing that all I got was a "sorry" and not any offer on a future purchase or something to bring me back.  I hate giving a bad review this time of year...but I think when we hear so much about buy local, shop local, shop independent stores...people need to know that isn't always easy.

19.description: I love this place and try to go to their events whenever I can make it. The events and their book recommendations are truly a gift to Chicago. I wish I could support them more but full price books are too expensive for my budget.

28.description: I love bookstores! And this one has an amazing selection of feminist literature and nonfiction, and an entire section of lesbian fiction!! It's probably a good thing that I don't live anywhere remotely nearby this store, otherwise I'd be in here all the time spending my money.

45.description: I love this place, for it's service, for it's author's readings, and for it's politics! Also, they now sell e-books through all forums but Kindles. Go 21st century, and still support your local bookstore. See their website.

33.description: This independent bookstore is really lovely. It's actually been a really long time since I went into a bookstore other than Barnes and Nobles, but the staff here is super friendly. I went to a Zine Fest reading here last night, which my friend was participating in, and it was a really good space and ambiance for the readings. It seems like they hold a lot of those types of events at this store. They have a great selection of books, and it is reasonably priced. I would definitely come here the next time I purchase a book.

43.description: Great gem of a store in Andersonville. Excellent selection of books and a friendly, helpful staff.

2.description: Yelp didn't even exist when I first starting coming to this bookstore. In fact, I think the Internet was just a reflected photon in someone's eye at that point.People: This is a BOOKSTORE. "Women and Kids" has stood the test of time. It has long-time, loyal, local customers as well as customers in galaxies far, far away. I used to live near this store--when it was on Armitage. And years later, coincidentally, both the store and I moved to Andersonville. Through the years, every staff member I've ever met has been professional, interested in helping, and interested in books.Now I'm in the 'burbs. I NEVER buy books online. I still make the drive to buy books at this wonderful, independent bookstore and attend author readings/signings. Check it out!

18.description: Will probably write a follow-up review once the store switches owners, but as is, this place is fabulous. Despite its independent status, the selection is great - no, not all the books here are die-hard feminist treatises. They have plenty of best-sellers, literary fiction, and non-fiction. As a fan of paper products, I also appreciate their great selection of notecards. My sister and I were just looking around and were asked if we needed help finding something, but we didn't feel pressured to buy anything. Well organized and open space- definitely worth a visit!

41.description: This bookstore is a godsend. Fabulous selection, super-friendly service and interesting items tucked into every corner. They have taken full advantage of their window space to display so many wonderful books. I have fallen in love with their charm and their staff. Bravo!

52.description: I love Women and Children First, so much so that I actually became a member and now I get 10% off all my purchases - nice! They are my go-to place for ordering books and I also love to browse in the store.  I wish the store was a little bigger, and I really, really wish they stayed open later (I love a good late night book browsing visit) but I know it's hard for small businesses to do that kind of thing.  The employees are also super friendly and helpful - shopping here is a pleasure and I'm really pleased to be able to support a woman-owned business.

50.description: Boyfriend (Can you spot the Clockhead in this relationship?): "Baby, WHERE ARE YOU? You are an Hour and a Half LATE!" Moi: "I have been in Target for the past Hour and a half wandering the children's toy, book and DVD aisles trying to find something remotely appropriate for a 6 year old! It's like a cornucopia of what NOT to give:I found A werewolf Barbie with a waxing fixation who wears lower-cut tops than J.Lo. Multiple Female Disney Characters who get married before being of legal (blue state) age. Pop albums where the male performer wears more eyeliner than I do (this is saying something)... speaking of which, they are also playing the same Jonas Brothers song over and over again...holy crap... I think I am going insane! Like Defense-for-multiple-homicide-insane...and Werewolf Barbie is going first!"Boyfriend: "Baby, get out of there. Target Security trained TSA, you won't get away with retail terrorism. I'm going to take you somewhere to shop fast."Moi: "Who are you and what the He!! have you done with my shopping-averse boyfriend?!?" As usual, Boyfriend was right. And no, he was not kidnapped by pod people for the purpose of gratifying my retail needs. We promptly go to Women and Children First, which is open magnificently late on Wednesdays, Thursdays and Friday... which is fantastic, as I am a workaholic who is profoundly unwilling to take time off to shop. They have coffee- always a plus. They have the most exquisitely-helpful staff who can help with finding something for ANYONE. Like moi: I need a book for a karate-obsessed tomboy niece that will also simultaneously please her Mom who is so punk-rock she will stab me with one of her multiple piercings if my gift displeases either. They also gift-wrap. Brilliant!

4.description: This is a great little local book shop and I enjoy supporting it. They've ordered me several books over the years and the staff has always been friendly and helpful. They even have a story time for the kids at 11am on Wednesdays. I always took my charge there when I was a Nanny. Linda is great with the little ones and very animated. I had fun! I hope this place is around for a very long time. I'll pay more for a book when I can get it here. Support Local!

6.description: Came to find a unique journal for my daughter's Bon Voyage party before she travels the world.Was greeted by a very cool, trendy sweet young woman, sameish age as my daughter. Got a cool Keith Haring journal that my daughter lived & will use to document her journey through Europe.THEN she dug through the shelves in search for the perfect gift. She showed me a simple children's book about friendship. With black backgrounds, each page featured one word (laughter, embarrassed, scared, excited, crying) accompanied by a bright, colorful drawing of awesome characters. At the party, my daughter's friends had a blast  documenting some of their fav moments with my daughter using a silver Sharpie against the black background on each page. Coolest idea ever.Thank you Women & Children First. Girls Def Rock!!

22.description: I ordered 2 books for the Jimmy Carter appearance.  I was unable to attend and called to inform them ahead of time.  The woman I spoke with said they would try to get them signed although it seemed unlikely.  I called to and they said they were unable to get them signed. About 2 months later I get call asking when I can pick them up. Sort of annoying. Anyway, this is a great neighborhood store, was just an odd experience.

15.description: Women and Children First is a small store, so they obviously don't have the selection of a book superstore. However, my interests align so well with the types of books stocked at WCF that I walk out with a pile of books every time I stop by. WCF is a nice niche bookstore for the neighborhood.

57.description: It's not Unabridged Books (aka, the best bookstore in the city) but it's a charming independent bookstore and I try to buy books from here if I'm in Andersonville and need a book that they might carry.CLOUD ATLAS is one of my favorite books and I noticed they had it featured as a staff recommendation the last time I was in there. It's fun to look around.  I hope they stay in business.  It's unique places like this that keep me up at night worrying about globalization.

20.description: I have been to this bookstore twice in the last two months; the first time I went in, I asked a sales clerk for her recommendations on some books for my goddaughter; suffice it to say, I was treated rudely.  Obviously, I was inconveniencing her in her busy day (I was only one of a couple of customers in the store, but, oh well).  I left without buying anything, and chalked it up to her having a bad day.  I went in again a few days ago, and this time was ignored by a completely different sales person.  Perhaps the fact that I'm a guy has something to do with this, I'm not sure.  I was with a buddy of mine and he asked me, very quietly, what the clerk's problem was and why was I bothering coming into a store that obviously didn't want or need my business.  I find this strange:  perhaps this independent store is making money hand over fist and doesn't care if it loses a sale, but in a day and age when such stores are becoming rare I would have thought anyone's business would be welcome.  Again, left without making a purchase.  i don't know what the female version of a misogynist is, but it seems to be alive and well at this store.

36.description: Amazing kids' book section. As a first grade teacher I find myself wandering into WACF every weekend, and I can never manage to leave empty handed. Everything is always organized, the staff is super helpful, and they have great events happening regularly.

14.description: Fantastic concept and very friendly staff. They carry all sorts of books, but if you're into social sciences or nonfiction, this place is a true gem. Love their comfy couches and the warm vibe in the bookstore.

58.description: Been here a few times for both lunch and dinner. They have great mussels and there sandwiches are well done. There bar can be kinda unwelcoming with the crowd that's there but the upstairs bar is really neat and inviting. It can get busy bit it's a nice lively environment to have dinner and a drink.

56.description: Given Hopleaf's perpetual hype and quoted two-hour wait times, I was so, so ready to dislike this place. And actually, the first two times I went, I did! I chose two Saturday evenings (unwise) and spent most of the time in the hectic first room with the sour-smelling bar (equally unwise). But as soon as I chose some weeknights to head into the restaurant area for after-work drinks and a quick dinner, Hopleaf's stengths and charm were on full display. The beer selection is always varied, exciting, and new, and the food menu is reliably curated. The CB&J is fried to a different degree every time I order it, but that's actually fine since it's literally impossible to ruin cashew butter, fig jam, and brie. Side salad is so good that they should offer it as a full meal. The service is hit-or-miss in terms of warmth, but efficiency is their strong suit.

29.description: I loved the wood burning fire stove in the back since it's one of my favorite smells in the winter. We lucked out and were seated right next to it!The food is solid and they have every type of beer imaginable here. My Duck Reuben was tasty and I surprisingly didn't need ketchup for the fries since the dipping mayo that comes with was decent.They let you sample the drinks before you commit. I enjoyed the Virtue cider and one if their Belgian beers La Trappe Puur which came in the purrrfect glass. Order the Kwak beer and you won't be disappointed in the presentation of it!This is a solid restaurant with the most unique and biggest selection of beer that I've encountered in the Midwest.

42.description: GREAT BEER SELECTION AND SUPERB FOOD!! Bartenders and servers are actually knowledgeable in regards to the craft brews and meal preparations! I'll be back for the monkey bread and any one of the seasonal small batch beers. Love this place, it's a must visit place while in chicago!

23.description: Excellent beer list, and perhaps the best beer-drinking environment in Chicago.   The tap list is more than enough to keep the serious beer consumer interested, and there is also a very deep bottle list.Belgian frites and mussels (get the Belgian-style) are the very best you'll find.   I believe the compare favorably to what you'll find in Brussels, and I speak from personal experience.    The other food here is unfortunately hit or miss.  The sandwiches are soggy.The expansion into the space next door, as well as the outdoor patio in the summer, has made Hopleaf a realistic group option, even during busy times.   Back when this place was smaller, you had to carefully time your visits to avoid the crowds.   Not really a problem anymore.If you are with a group and plan to order food, get a table in the back room for a calmer experience.   If it's cold out, ask for a table near the fireplace.

47.description: I feel like a jerk writing this review because everyone loves it here, but I've been here a handful of times just hoping it's going to be as good as all the other reviews say it is.  The food has never blown me away.   Mussels are ok, the charcuterie plate is pretty tasty, and the sandwiches have just been ok.  I feel like it's overpriced and it's just more hype than anything.

8.description: Thanksgiving weekend in Chicago is generally dead. In a good way. Nobody around, which means...no waits at typical hotspots like Hopleaf! Erin J. and I came in around 8:00 on a Saturday and were given the option to sit at the bar that overlooks the kitchen. We nabbed the seats and it was pretty awesome to see the chefs at work while we dined. Hopleaf is known for their beer list and they did not disappoint. I started with an awesome ginger peach cider and also enjoyed a 5 Rabbit brew I had never tried! Our server was extremely knowledgeable about the draft list and was helpful in our decision-making.To start for dinner, we shared the charcuterie plate and fall Cobb salad. Big warning! The charcuterie plate is definitely for adventurous charcuterie eaters! We enjoyed most of what we ordered, but some of the items were a bit out of our comfort zone. To follow, we shared the mussels and mac n' cheese. Both were a hit, the mussels for one was definitely enough for us to share. While tasty, the dish was extremely salty and the bread that accompanied the dish was too hard to eat. These are basically my only complaints about Hopleaf. Mac n' cheese was creamy, tasty, and super rich. I highly recommend sharing a bunch of things so you can try multiple items!Overall, Hopleaf lived up to the hype. Truly enjoyed the warm atmosphere, impressive beer list, variety of menu items, and solid service. I can't speak to the long waits on typical weekend nights, but seems as though going at off-hours and in small groups will absolutely reduce the wait time.

31.description: Six words: Incredible beer menu, delicious brisket sandwichHopleaf is the kind of place that I wished I was a regular at, mainly because they have the most incredible beer menu I've ever seen. Four densely packed pages of beers of all different varieties with the most incredible descriptions. This is the kind of place where you could learn so much. If only it wasn't an hour away by bus. If only!I was here with a bunch of friends because it was the midway point between all of us. Two lived in Evanston, one lived in Uptown, and I live in Noble Square. Midway. We made reservations in advance and were seated once everyone arrived. And then we were given the most incredible beer menu ever.Pages upon pages. The waiter came by multiple times and we just couldn't make up our minds. He gave us recommendations. We'd ponder them. And still no decision. We were horrible - I'm so sorry we were so indecisive. I ended up picking a beer at random - the BOM Brewery Triporteur Full Moon. I wish I had saved the menu description - it basically described the beer as a witches brew - with something about mountains, and dark and something else. It was the most delicious beer I've ever tried and I don't think it's on tap anymore. Dinner was slightly easier. I went with the Grass-fed Brisket mainly because it sounded good and because I had never had brisket before. No idea what it was but it was amazing. It was normal sandwich sized and was on two slices of bread. But the meat inside was moist but not too moist. And incredibly flavorful. I practically inhaled my sandwich. And the pomme frites attack on my plate was so delicious. Most of plate was covered in them and I still finished them all. I definitely want to go back. I definitely will go back.

34.description: Let me start off by saying that Hopleaf is truly a great place to go no matter what you are in the mood for. If you want to go on a first date (or 100th date), grab a truly nice lunch or dinner, grab a beer with friends, get drunk with friends, or wander in alone at 1pm on a Thursday looking for salted meats, Hopleaf will not disappoint. I met Mark (he cuts the meat at Hopleaf) last week. Turns out that he lives across the street from me (small world) in Ravenswood and told me I have to go try the Charcuterie at Hopleaf. Thanks for the baller tip Mark. Does anyone else know the feeling of being "in" a meal? That's my test for how the meal was. Was I "in" it? Were the flavors, textures, ambiance, service and drink so wonderfully harmonized that I was able to escape this temporary and mundane existence by going "in?" Oh yes, I was "in" this Charcuterie experience all right, and I hope one day you get to dive in too. Just make sure that you don't eat for at least 30 minutes before entering the beer soaked waters. I asked my server, who was perfect by the way, to please have the kitchen choose which 3 meats I would try. (Note: Just start doing this guys, it makes SO much sense.) I, however, chose Three Floyd's Zombie Dust (they have it on draft people!) as my drink of choice. I thought it would pair quite well. I was quite right. For my board, the kitchen selected Tonno Di Maiale (olive oil cured in ham), the Pork Belly Rillette and sliced duck (it was off menu, and I forgot exactly what it was called). The presentation was beautiful, the portions perfect and the tastes all grabbed my shirt collar. Even the mustard was good. The Tonno Di Maiale was so tender and just the right amount of salty that I almost ordered more. Good lord was it good on toasted baguette with mustard and a quail egg. The pickled beats were also a nice addition. NOT TO BE MISSED are the white wine mussels. They are very good (although freshness/flavor fluctuates) but the sauce at the bottom is so god damn good I don't even know what to do sometimes. The bread they give you is some of the best bread you'll get in Chicago restaurants and it soaks up all that deliciousness so efficiently I wanted to find out where the bread baker lives and go rake his yard (not a euphemism) for him.  I also have to plug the salmon: wonderful.Guys and gals: You need to just go try this place, plain and simple.

16.description: I don't know why I waited so long to come to this place. I live just around the corner and everyone I know raves about the food. For some reason, I just went for the first time recently and I'm kicking myself for getting mediocre food and beer from other places in the neighborhood for so long. I went on a Monday night and there was no wait. I'm told that there's often a long wait but maybe that's just on the weekends. We were seated immediately at an upstairs table overlooking the back patio. This place is really huge inside. I had no idea how big the space was from the outside. It's quite deceptive. Our waitress was very helpful in deciding what to order. I forget her name but she was awesome! I had the special--fried chicken and waffles with Kwak. I love that they do beer pairings with their food. I love that Kwak was used in the fried chicken. It was a great combination and it should be on the regular menu. My husband had the CB&J and it was decadent. It's a cashew butter and fig jam sandwich grilled with raclette cheese. My visiting mother had the steak with herb butter. That herb butter is like crack. I wanted some on everything. In short, don't spend three years living in Andersonville without trying this place!

13.description: Six words: Incredible beer menu, delicious brisket sandwichHopleaf is the kind of place that I wished I was a regular at, mainly because they have the most incredible beer menu I've ever seen. Four densely packed pages of beers of all different varieties with the most incredible descriptions. This is the kind of place where you could learn so much. If only it wasn't an hour away by bus. If only!I was here with a bunch of friends because it was the midway point between all of us. Two lived in Evanston, one lived in Uptown, and I live in Noble Square. Midway. We made reservations in advance and were seated once everyone arrived. And then we were given the most incredible beer menu ever.Pages upon pages. The waiter came by multiple times and we just couldn't make up our minds. He gave us recommendations. We'd ponder them. And still no decision. We were horrible - I'm so sorry we were so indecisive. I ended up picking a beer at random - the BOM Brewery Triporteur Full Moon. I wish I had saved the menu description - it basically described the beer as a witches brew - with something about mountains, and dark and something else. It was the most delicious beer I've ever tried and I don't think it's on tap anymore. Dinner was slightly easier. I went with the Grass-fed Brisket mainly because it sounded good and because I had never had brisket before. No idea what it was but it was amazing. It was normal sandwich sized and was on two slices of bread. But the meat inside was moist but not too moist. And incredibly flavorful. I practically inhaled my sandwich. And the pomme frites attack on my plate was so delicious. Most of plate was covered in them and I still finished them all. I definitely want to go back. I definitely will go back.

11.description: The tap list is incredible and that should be the main reason you're here. You shouldn't need me to tell you that and you probably didn't.  But we also got food here (you've no doubt noticed that I spend too much of my time eating in bars) and that is worth a few brief comments: Some of the items seem like a perfect match to a beer hall with pretensions -- the sandwiches, the brussels sprouts sides, and probably the other sides too, though I didn't try them.  Other items seem to be longer on pretension, shorter on beer hall -- steak frites, rabbit confit salad, short ribs, etc.  Some of the items in the second category were great (the rabbit confit was a big hit), but most were disappointing and I would be inclined to stick to the safer bar fare here.  With one caveat -- most of my table was annoyed by the fact that our french fries were all lukewarm.  (I didn't actually mind, I was just grateful that they weren't limp and soggy.)Still, did I mention the tap list?

39.description: Had the maple duck and the venison, along with Kwak and depth-charged double bastard beers. Everything was cooked perfectly, and everything we hoped for and more. Will definitely be coming back.

37.description: Sprouts and frites are enough to leave anyone satisfied.  You have to come here when you and in Andersonville.

0.description: Honest review:venison:this was one of the best dishes of the night.Must order!I never had venison so this was a first for me picture a richer tasting beef flavor.The venison was cooked to perfection u do not need a knife to cut it.It was so flavorful that i didnt need to put salt or nothing on it it was perfect.The celery root puree was amaizin ask for more of it!It was so rich that it made the venison taste orgasmic.Like im gonna buy celery root when i go to the grocery store.The currant sauce added a nice sweatness to the dish that complimented the venison well.The pickled vegetables really made this dish great nothing goes great with something rich then something vinegary eat everything harmoniously to get the perfect bite that will be exceptional Charcuterie:(even though this appetizer was good out of this wasnt amaizin as everything else)head cheese i never been fond of this i think it smells n looks disgusting when u buy it at the grocery store and it tastes funky but here it tastes so good.The texture wasnt off either.It was kind of spicy picture like a spicy italian sausage but tastes better this is a must order.The pork belly was phenomenal idk what was on top of it but it added a nice texture.If u love pork belly youll love this.The bacon wasnt overly salty or didnt have a strong smokey flavor to it.Picture like a mild bacon it wasnt greasy either.This was the least favorite just had no wow factor to it.The head cheese was the best. The accompaniments were really good like i loved the mustard!The bread was actually toasty thank u jesus m theres alot!Then the quail egg yum great added bonusBrisket:omg one of the best briskets i ever had dont tell mannys i said that!It was really tender n not dry or Old like alot of briskets can be!It isnt overly pickled which is really important cause that overpowers the taste of the beef.My only complaints was the bread wasnt toasted!Why?!!!This ruins a sandwhich!Theres mustard in it but i wish there was a lil more in it so more on the side plz.I would recommend that u dip the sandwhich in the fries sauce. The fries let me tell u about the fries omg!There thin like mcondalds and fried to perfection.There not greasy or burnt n their crispy.The only thing is i wish it had some salt and pepper on it.The dipping sauce is phenomenal one of the bests things i ever ate in my life i would just come back here for this dishMacaroni and cheese:nobody liked this.It wasnt creamy it needed more cheese it was really dry n the pasta was hard I hated the cheese they used in this.I love cheese but this had a funky taste to it.They used stilton cheese it did not taste good.Then theres no bacon or bread crumbs.This was a waste of money one of the worst macaroni and cheeses i ever hadMaple brined Duck:(eat everything together delicious) the duck was tender cooked to perfection. The duck is seasoned perfectly.The only thing about the duck was the skin wasnt crispy plz fix that!The puree was really good its like gormea mashed potatoes.Really flavorful and fluffy.I didnt like the romanesco it was just boiled thats wasting a vegetable jus boiling it.The vegetable bread pudding didnt taste good like i took one bite n thats it jus tasted like soggy bread no flavor at all plz fix this change it to something else.The best part of this dish were these little red currants they were to die for so good! there the perfect balance of sweet and tart just complimented the duck beutifully i wanna go to the store just to buy these currants there that good so put more.I wish there was a sauce to bring everything together so add a sauceBeef short ribs:(eat everything together delicious)short ribs are my favorite and these were so tender.This litterly melted in ur mouth cause it was so tender. It was really flavorful so no complaints.The polenta was phenomenal so flavorful i dont like polenta but this tasted so good and went perfectly with the short ribs. They had a perfect texture to not really hard really creamy the collard greens were amaizin i couldnt stop eating it then there were the pickled vegetables i love how this restaurant always has something vinegary it cuts down the richness n makes it taste better.One complaint was the bread was amaizin but it was under everything so it got soggy fix that an add more bread n add more of the braising liquid from the short ribs n itll be perfectSalmon:(eat everything together delicious)Crunchy Salmon skin tastes better then pork rinds!The fish was cooked perfectly no complaints over seasoning.The components in this dish are really interesting the sauce was rich but had a really interesting flavor to it idk how to describe it.There are grapes in it i wish there was more because it added a really flavorful note to. The mushrooms were a nice earthy note but were a lil overcooked Donut:one of the best donut dishes i ever had.plz order thisCranberry breadpudding: amaizin tastes like thanksgivin order this!Brownie:not fav idaddmorebutcantwritemore

38.description: The tap list is incredible and that should be the main reason you're here. You shouldn't need me to tell you that and you probably didn't.  But we also got food here (you've no doubt noticed that I spend too much of my time eating in bars) and that is worth a few brief comments: Some of the items seem like a perfect match to a beer hall with pretensions -- the sandwiches, the brussels sprouts sides, and probably the other sides too, though I didn't try them.  Other items seem to be longer on pretension, shorter on beer hall -- steak frites, rabbit confit salad, short ribs, etc.  Some of the items in the second category were great (the rabbit confit was a big hit), but most were disappointing and I would be inclined to stick to the safer bar fare here.  With one caveat -- most of my table was annoyed by the fact that our french fries were all lukewarm.  (I didn't actually mind, I was just grateful that they weren't limp and soggy.)Still, did I mention the tap list?

51.description: Wow! What a wonderful restaurant. From the eclectic and expansive beer menu to the similarly quirky and vast food menu, there is something for everyone here. I've had several beers and two meals here. My duck reuben was my favorite meal. The flavors were outstanding and utterly original. I also enjoyed my ham and cheese sandwich. It was very tasty, but not as original as the reuben. And the fries...oh the fries. They are worth every individual fry...and boy are there lots of them. They do not go skimpy on the portions, especially with the fries. The staff were friendly and the huge venue is fun to explore. Each room has its own unique vibe. I can't wait to return in the future!

27.description: The waitress decided to cuss two of my friends out. Enough said. Won't be back. There's plenty of other places to eat and drink in the area. It could just be the late crew but I wouldn't give them the benefit of the doubt.

32.description: This place remains one of my favorite spots in Chicago. Great food, genuinely friendly staff, unpretentiously beautiful space, and interesting food options. Get the mussels and fries ("frites"). Mussels for One is actually great for 2 or 3 people. Only complaint is that a lot of the food is too salty for my taste.

54.description: Lots of good reviews here so permit me to provide some perspective.  I ate here last night for dinner with my beautiful wife. We had all the classic hopleaf favorites like the Frites aka fries, the duck Reuben, the sausage trio, and of course the famous clams.  This place is always busy and the manager of the place clearly makes a point to get people in and out.  A bus lady asked us at least 4 times if we were finished with our fries when there were clearly many fries still in there.  The fries by the way came cold.  The famous clams.  Still tasty but way too much salt in the broth and very little meat on these things.The duck Reuben was good.  A little unhealthy with a slathering of butter on the bread but clearly the safest most popular choice here for $13.  It's also a cheaper option.The sausage trio was boring and amounted to perhaps a sausage and a half maybe. The lamb sausage was the best and the most un-hot dog like.The huge German beer for $6 was the highlight. So 3/5.  It's still a cool place but some of that magic I remember is missing.

48.description: Honestly...disappointed and trying to keep as "objective" as possible with this review.  I have constantly been told that the mussels at Hopleaf are "the thing" to get, and I had really high expectations.  So, when I finally got a chance to go there recently I ordered the mussels.  The broth was good, and the bread was good, but the actual mussels themselves were definitely over cooked, and all seemed very withered and dry.  I know this is the Midwest, and that I shouldn't have particularly high expectations for things like mussels, but after hearing how great it was at Hopleaf and being presented with what I had... I know I've had better in the city at other places.  The fries that came with it were also really not that spectacular, they were fine, they were fries after all, but nothing that really made me want to go back.  Definitely not somewhere I plan on going back to visit any time soon.Three stars because service was fine, the patio was nice, and honestly I might have just been there on an off day.

44.description: Hopleaf has been a go-to place for years for me. It has the best beer selection in the city, it's open everyday of the year, and the food compliments the beer just right.I partook in the monthly fried chicken special today, and it was well executed with a flavorful crust and moist, tender inside. Past delights of mine include the duck reuben sandwich and the Cashew Butter and Fig Jam with Raclette Cheese sandwich served with pomme frites.Late closing kitchen (12am) and bar, I suggest dashing there.

24.description: Great beer list. CB &J is one of my favorite sandwiches. Normally has a long wait but highly recommended!

7.description: Excellent beer list, and perhaps the best beer-drinking environment in Chicago.   The tap list is more than enough to keep the serious beer consumer interested, and there is also a very deep bottle list.Belgian frites and mussels (get the Belgian-style) are the very best you'll find.   I believe the compare favorably to what you'll find in Brussels, and I speak from personal experience.    The other food here is unfortunately hit or miss.  The sandwiches are soggy.The expansion into the space next door, as well as the outdoor patio in the summer, has made Hopleaf a realistic group option, even during busy times.   Back when this place was smaller, you had to carefully time your visits to avoid the crowds.   Not really a problem anymore.If you are with a group and plan to order food, get a table in the back room for a calmer experience.   If it's cold out, ask for a table near the fireplace.

49.description: Oh hopleaf, I love you. I can always count on you for a delicious, refreshing cerveza. Just so you know, the Belgian flag on your menu is backwards in half the Belgian beers. But that's ok cause I'm more of an american beer kinda gal.

40.description: Good stuff - all the way from the beer to the food.Hell, even the wine is tasty!  Great place to get toasted on a lazy Sunday afternoon!

53.description: This is my go-to spot in the neighborhood. It's never dead empty, which is a testament to how much they do right. The beer selection cannot be beat. If you are a beer geek or know one, then Hopleaf is the place to go. There's an overwhelming amount of stuff on tap, and even more available in bottles, including some rare beers. They specialize in Belgian & Belgian style beers, which I absolutely love. The food is also top notch. Hopleaf does a great job of providing a certain level of consistency in menu items - there are always mussels, there are always salads - but they tweak the offerings to fit with what's in season. For mussels, there are always two options: a Belgian style & a special style, with the special being a rotating & unique offering that is never repeated. Currently, the special is lobster, and it might be the best type of mussels I've ever had. It's like a lobster bisque, but with corn & fennel, some heat...just tons of good flavors. The charcuterie trio is out of control. I recommend the nduja, duck liver mousse, and the pork belly rillette. The onion rings are another great bar snack. The service at Hopleaf is always on point & servers are happy to help you navigate the massive beer list. I come here a few times a month and am continually delighted by Hopleaf. What a great place!

30.description: Found this place thanks to Yelp. I had to kill a few hours while my kid attended a concert at the Aragon Ballroom.  This place is less than a mile away.  Parking is in the street and for 2 hours max.  You enter the restaurant through the bar, and head up a ramp in the back to be seated.  My first impression was kind of a dive bar feel, but that changes quickly when you get to the back.  We were seated right away and welcomed warmly by Val. They have a great selection of draught beers and bottled.  The menu is eclectic, but everything looked intriguing.  My wife had the Duck Rueben which she raved about. I had the brisket which was pretty good (think corned beef, not BBQ). The Frites were very good as was the aioli that accompanied them. I got a side of Stilton Mac and Cheese. It was unique and very good.  The next time my kid wants to attend a concert at the Aragon, I'll say yes, just so I can go back to Hopleaf!

46.description: 3 girls shared the Belgian-style mussels (for 2) and the CB&J sandwich. Mussels are on the small side but fresh. the broth was only okay...I actually wanted to try the lobster based broth but gave in to what was considered popular. The fries and the aioli was addictive. The CB&J was rather tasty...not something I would have ordered on my own. The Stilton mac and cheese that accompanied it was a bit overwhelming though (the cheese had a strong goat/sheep cheese flavor). The beer selection is extensive. I am not much of a beer drinker ...I like the less hoppy wheat beers usually. Upon our waitress's recommendation, I ordered the Tripel Karmeliet which as not hoppy and it came in it's own glass.  Great place to grab a bite on a Sunday at 5:30pm as there was no wait and perfectly located before catching the Neo-futurist show nearby.

1.description: Great atmosphere, beer, and not too long of a wait.Cauliflower appetizer tastes great but isn't really described well. It's like a buffalo chicken ball with ranch, delicious. Somewhat small serving.Salmon is really good.  Cooked well with a flavorful and salty skin on top, heart of palm and a mustard like dip with mushrooms.  Mushrooms have a pungent taste and smell.  Duck roast was... For those that like game!  A bit fatty and chewy at parts.  I'm sure this is one of the better cooked duck meals out there - I'm not a game fan so I won't comment.

55.description: Never disappointed here. Great beer selection. Love the patio. Brisket sandwich with fries is to die for. So are there charcuterie and mussels.

9.description: 3 girls shared the Belgian-style mussels (for 2) and the CB&J sandwich. Mussels are on the small side but fresh. the broth was only okay...I actually wanted to try the lobster based broth but gave in to what was considered popular. The fries and the aioli was addictive. The CB&J was rather tasty...not something I would have ordered on my own. The Stilton mac and cheese that accompanied it was a bit overwhelming though (the cheese had a strong goat/sheep cheese flavor). The beer selection is extensive. I am not much of a beer drinker ...I like the less hoppy wheat beers usually. Upon our waitress's recommendation, I ordered the Tripel Karmeliet which as not hoppy and it came in it's own glass.  Great place to grab a bite on a Sunday at 5:30pm as there was no wait and perfectly located before catching the Neo-futurist show nearby.

26.description: Service can make or break your impression of a restaurant which accounts for Hopleaf's dismal rating.  Believe me, if no stars were allowed, they'd deserve it.  What Medicare card carrying person on this globe looks like they should be carded for age at a bar; especially one that primarily just moves beer?  Answer: None.  But that is exactly what happened a few hours ago when this creature asked to see my ID when I stopped in for lunch.  No I did not take it as a compliment because I don't believe it was intended as one.  The message was people who look like you aren't welcome here.  I gave no verbal response to the man and just did a "how dare you" about face, left and went up to Lady Gregory's.  A much better venue that was completely pleasant from beginning to end.  Hopleaf could do the world a favor and disappear.

25.description: I have been to the Hopleaf perhaps fifty times in the 8 years I've lived in Chicago. I was surprised to see they have only 4 stars. After reading many reviews, I have some advice for the disgruntled few:You're doing it wrong.1. They I.D. everyone. Everyone. You are not a special snowflake, get your i.d. out. 2. They do not allow anyone under the age of 21 to enter. Not 6 days old, not 20.9 years old. Just know this. You may not like the policy; go somewhere else.3. This is a bar first, then a restaurant. Do not come for a fine dining experience. Come in a group of no more than 4, show your i.d., grab a space in the first room for the most authentic experience, or continue to the "new" bar on the first floor and score a booth (my preference.) There is no table service in these areas, which means you can sit alllll night and no one will rush you out. Go to the bar (have someone stay behind to hold the table.) Order a Kwak, a Maredsous, and two other beers/wines/ciders. Order mussels for two and a CB&J with fries instead of chips. Order the Brussels sprouts. Now go sit down.You are welcome.

12.description: Decided on Hopleaf because I know they're always well stocked with Zombie Dust. It has a sharp balance of citrus hops that puts a smile on every sip. Its brightness paired very well with my charcuterie. It was a trio of nduja, pork belly rillette, and tasso bacon. Njuda is a spreadable spicy pork sausage that has a mild spice with a bold pate like flavor and consistency. It paired best with the whole mustard on toast. The bar in the back was a bit loud with a big party near us, so I couldn't hear the entire plate. The berry on the pork belly rillette cut the fattiness of the pork belly and helped bring out the pork flavor. The star on the board was the tasso bacon. It was soft, fatty bacon that had the essentials of crispy bacon with strong smoky flavor, but instead melted in your mouth. Once melted, the bacon flavor shines through and bliss arrives. The bacon tastes so right.I noticed the tiny quail egg, but didn't hear that it was pickled! It had a med-well vinegar taste and worked out really well, because it cleaned my palette of that greasy feeling. The plate was well organized and would definitely have again. This isn't my first time really enjoying their food and would gladly come back. Side note: On my way out, there was a sign above a beer fridge that said "Off-Menu Specialties. Please ask your server!" How did I not see this before?!? I guess i'll find out on my next visit.

59.description: I've been to this place a few times and I always forget to leave a review while I'm there because I can't stop talking about their mussels!!Mussels for 1 or 2 -- They serve it with two different broths (I always get the Belgian one with onions), it also comes with bread (which you can dip in this delicious broth) and a generous side of fries. The fries are delicious. They're not too thick and seasoned just right. The onion rings are very, very thin (which personally I love!). I'm not in the habit or ordering fried food but someone else at the table ordered these and I ate about a quarter of the plate -- that good!
