41.description: Okay but not as stellar as the 2x10 on Montrose, primarily because the chairs are not equipped for massages.  I'm sure I'll go back, but I don't know that it will measure up.

52.description: 2X10 in Andersonville got a face list in January and the newly decorated salon feels much more upscale than it did before and the new look is very pretty.  Everyone in the store was commenting on it.  Unfortunately, the experience didn't match the classy new look.  I went on a slow day (Monday) and it was nice and quiet until a woman came in wanting a mani-pedi and proceeded to talk very loudly on her cell phone for at least 15 minutes while everyone else tried to read.  No one that worked there seeme to think this was a problem.  One of the nail technicans had a very bad cold and was coughing and sneezing all over her customer.  She did not belong in a place that needs to be very sanitary and obviously felt terrible and should have been at home resting.  One of the other staff members was sitting around texting her friends and then at one point was trying to fix her nail clippers by bending them with her mouth.  I realize these are sterilized before use, but I don't want to see that and I don't expect to see that in a place that appears so nice.  The phone rang a lot and my nail guy had to get up to answer it constantly in the middle of my pedicure because no one was watching the desk.  When I was paying I noticed a sign on the cash machine reminding people to smile when they talk to the customers and tell them about the promotions.  They didn't do either!  It was not a friendly experience.  I was willing to deal with not haveing the massaging pedicure chairs for a nicer mani/pedi experience but really I didn't have either.  The man that worked on my nails did a nice job but the rest of the experience was disappointing.

50.description: This place is awesome!  Good prices and excellent service!  Not to mention, it has a very cute and clean interior.  The receptionist was so nice and Margie did a great job on my nails!  I ended up smearing one of them before I left and Kim gladly fixed it for me.  All around it is a great place to go :)

4.description: It's ok.  Good Top Chef programming on TV.

6.description: I've only recently begun regular nail maintenance, and my regular go-to is ZaZaZoo in Bucktown. However, as I don't want to be limited to a time-consuming commute whenever I need a great mani-pedi, I decided to expand my mind to trying another place. I chose 2x10 based on the fact that it was named Chicago's Best of 2014 and was apprehensive after checking out the reviews.The truth? 2x10 is a good nail salon. Let me tell you why.I called ahead about two hours for an appointment, which seems like it might be essential on weekends. During the hour I was there they were extremely busy and kept getting walk-ins, most of whom they told to come back later in the day. I arrived a little early for my appointment and was welcomed right away. They offer a broad selection of OPI and Essie polishes and even do waxing, which I didn't experience but is nice to know.My technician, Yuna, was finishing up a mani when I arrived, so I waited a while for her in the massage chair with my feet soaking, which I didn't mind. Yuna did very good work, which included satisfying foot, hand and shoulder massages.  She did not rush the process at all and asked me whether I wanted my nails trimmed or filed, what shapes I wanted, etc. The service was nearly faultless, and I'd definitely recommend coming here if you want a good mani-pedi at a good price ($40).Where 2x10 falls short is in atmosphere and presentation. The space is very small and the dark brown decor makes it feel cavelike and drab. My suggestion would be to whitewash the whole place (or choose a nice, clean light blue) and get rid of the vases and other decorative items that just add to the cluttered appearance. I think these small changes would do wonders in making the space feel larger and more modern. Also, I am not a fan of a TV in a nail salon -- it just adds to the noise. Today during my service the football game was on (with sound) and it detracted from the relaxing environment. No one seemed to be watching it.Also, many of the bottles of polish had paint all over the outside, and I think this looks a little sloppy. This is the first point of contact that the customer has with the salon, and I think presentation in this area is important. Is it better than ZaZaZoo? I have to say no. ZaZaZoo is more spacious and attractive, and the service is slightly better in little ways (they offer you a beverage during the service and a pedi includes a stone massage, for example). However, 2x10 is not a bad choice by any means, and is a fine alternative considering the more convenient location for me.

22.description: For the price ($40 mani/pedi) I expect at least a little pampering (read: massage) and an impeccable paint-job. I received neither. The technician actually painted my cuticles red and then cleaned with a polish remover. Hmmm, I can paint my own nails that way, thank you very much. Also, the place wasn't the cleanest and their color selection was outdated. Needless to say, the polish barely lasted a week, and I usually don't have a problem going close to two weeks without a mani. So sad.

15.description: While 2x10 is very nice, it's also expensive for a basic manicure.  I like my manis cheap and dirty.  Tis not the case with 2x10.

57.description: I stumbled across this place  looking for a different salon that i never found; and I couldnt be happier with them.  The technician was friendly, and quiet (which I prefer) very detailed and professional.  Lovely place... very clean, small but they manage to make it stress free as busy as they are; took me in right away and i was out within 1 hour.  For $15 bucks the mani was well worth it.   I will definitely be back!!

20.description: I went back to 2 x 10 today and was again impressed.  It's the little things when it comes to a good mani/pedi, and these ladies really pay attention well.  Details:- The technician didn't rush through the food or shoulder massages.- They have added a hot stone massage to the legs, in addition to the exfoliating scrub.- Hot towels clean your hands and feet of lotion (no awkward walk to a sink for you).- And...a sign of a really great manicure: the technician used a paintbrush with nail polish remover to clean my nails before applying the base coat, which ensures that your polish will last longer.  Nicely done.They have since added new massage chairs which are less pretty than the colorful cushions, but are probably more comfortable.  I'll keep coming back for more...

36.description: I don't get my nails done very often, and it's usually for a special occasion.  That said, I've been to 2x10 three times in the last year.  All three times were the same sitch, where I had left my hand-grooming til the last minute and walked in hoping for the best (appointment) but preparing for the worst (no soup for you!).  Each time they accommodated me graciously; the procrastinator survives another day.My three manicures were done by different employees, but the technique and quality were equal each time.  They treat you to a shoulder rub during the hands-in-praying-position-under-steaming-hot-towel segment, which is always appreciated.  During manicure #2, the tech skipped this part (gurrrl) but then did it when I was at the drying station (okaaay!).  I haven't gotten a pedicure there but the cushion-seats are attractive and look comfortable.  Also, there is a flat-screen TV but it's hard to see from some of the manicure stations.  Not a big deal.  Oh, and prepare to tip in cash.  I've had only credit cards, which they will do if necessary, but there is a sign asking for gratuity to be cash only.  Plus I just told you too, so you have no excuse.I can see myself coming back with some regularity now that they've proven to be consistently good to my hands and courteous service-providers.  Plus I recently acquired some special new finger-bling so I need to have hands that are up to snuff.  I'll be back.

14.description: Great little place. I headed over here a couple days ago to mix it up and see if there is another contender for Favorite Pedicure Place besides Magic Nails on Broadway.This place is it! Friendly nail technician made my toes look flawless. Foot and leg massage AND a shoulder rub while my toes were drying. I was in there for a long time, and it was very relaxing. Friendly, nice owner as well. The price - $30 for a pedicure, is standard. I was there on a Wednesday, and didn't take advantage of the $35 mani/pedi special, but I will in the future.Clean shop, and not an overwhelming polish smell. Oh, and they had NEWS on, instead of some insipid chick flick (not to say I don't enjoy on occasion) playing. For news-obsessed me, this was a good thing on this day.I will be back.

3.description: I have been going to Marilyn for many years and reasons. I love her healing touch and concern as well as the bonus of her energy work and studies.She is always ahead of her time in learning new techniques as well as offering anti aging Face Lift Massage.Marilyn is magic, present and intuitive combining massage, muscle release and pranic healing energy to her technique of healing one from aches and pains, stress, injuries as well as boosting one to vibrant health.

1.description: I asked my iPhone, "Who's the best massage therapist in Edgewater?" It said, "Marilyn Fumagalli." The phone was right. After a 90 minute massage, I feel more relaxed than I have in years. And my sore back--I don't feel like I even have a back.

2.description: I have seen Marilyn for both body work and the best facial I have ever experienced.One day I arrived at her office very upset about whatever, when my massage was over I was in perfect shape both physically and mentally.  Thank you, Marilyn

5.description: Marilyn is magical with magical healing hands.  She makes one feel instantly comfortable and at ease.  I have been getting the Belavi Facial Massages for the past year and have gotten so many compliments on my complexion.  She can't make you younger but she will make you feel soooo beautiful.

6.description: I have been seeing Marilyn for years. I cannot even remember when I started, that's how long it has been. Marilyn is the most wonderful, nurturing, kind and peaceful person you will ever meet. She radiates good energy. Marilyn has truly golden hands. Her massages are wonderful. I see her once a month (I would see her weekly, if my budget  and my schedule allowed) and I am always looking forward to my massage the way people are  excited about going on vacation! Marilyn works in Andersonville, so you have the extra advantage of being in a hip, wonderful neighborhood full of great restaurants and stores. Marilyn's massage room is in a very well kept professional building that has air conditioning. Her room is always comfortable, clean, super cozy. I cannot rave enough about the massage I get. I always float away from her as if being on a cloud. I have lower back pains and sometimes stiff shoulder muscles too and Marilyn keeps me up and running. But she also infuses the massage with her wonderful energy and that is an incredible bonus! You will see what I mean when you try it. At this point, I consider Marilyn a great friend. I recommend her very highly. I might give myself a special treat this summer for my birthday - her Belavi facial massage. Oh, and I almost forgot, Marilyn is also a specialist in prenatal massage therapy. What a wonderful way to go through your pregnancy - I have done it too.

0.description: I've been getting treatments from Marilyn for years and hopefully many more years to come.  She has a calm, healing and caring way about her that touches not only your sore body, but your spirit as well.  She is very knowledgeable about musculature  and anatomy of the human body, but also is very knowledgeable on homeopathy.  Go and get a facial lift and/or massage.  You will be hooked!

4.description: Marilyn has a palpable healing energy. After one Bellanina Facelift Massage Treatment, I felt balanced, calm and looked very well rested. My skin glowed and my forehead "stress lines"  faded. In addition to having your face massaged, your feet, shoulders, chest, arms and back also benefit from Marilyn's expert massage technique and healing touch The products  Marilyn uses are nontoxic and noninvasive I liked the use of honey which is pulled and lifted off the face in fast strokes. There are so many options on where to spend your hard earned self pampering dollars and this treatment is well worth it. Anyone can get a good massage or a good facial but Marilyn's healing mojo adds a unique soul satisfying component to the treatment.

28.description: Definitely a terrific place to get bulk tea in Andersonville  At $14.99 a pound for most, it's a steal.  They have the black tea on one stand and the green teas on the other.  My brother purchased close to three pounds of tea here.  Do you know how much three pounds of tea is?  I'm pretty sure that's about how much they were dealing with at the Boston Tea Party, i think.  They keep a good selection of tea accessories (pots, cups, etc.)  There are some hookas up front, a selection of oils and pickled what nots in the back, jewelry in the cases up front, but definitely a store where you aren't sure what you may uncover.With its location, its a great place to duck into and see what's available.

1.description: I accidentally stumbled upon this place while I was on my way to another store in andersonville. I am always looking for places that carry loose leaf tea and there was a sign in the window for it.First of all, the variety was surprisingly large. I prefer black tea and there were many to choose from. Secondly, they sell in (reasonable) bulk quantities. I also drink tea every day, so buying smaller amounts is ridiculous for me. In fact, after having been back a couple of times and asking for larger bags, the store owner started carrying bigger bags in which to fill with larger quantities of tea.Third, on my most recent visit, the store owner came and told me what kinds of tea were in each blend. He also made sure that I got a good mixture of the tea, giving me tips on stirring the leaves before I bagged them. He is SUPER nice.They also sell bulk spices and a variety of bulk nuts, as well as coffee and tea brewing items. It is a hidden gem.

9.description: I received a Christmas gift of an assortment of tea from Pars. So far, I've had two varities and both were just delicious. I can't wait to visit and to explore more of this store's offerings.

29.description: A great place to get tea!  They have a whole wall of different kinds of tea (both bagged and loose)  and about 30 different bins of loose tea.They are also a great place to get cooking oil.  Some of their specialty products (sauces and stuff) aren't particularly  cheap, but they're not really any more expensive than when I've seen the same stuff elsewhere.Also the owners are really nice, always helpful, and they don't bat an eyelash about using a credit card.  All in all, its a great place to poke around in and to come out with something tasty.

23.description: This is a great place to shop for tea and oddball dry goods. They are very friendly and answer any questions thoughtfully and seem glad to have you there. What a neat place to still have in the neighborhood!

5.description: I've become obsessed with Moroccan Mint tea since having it in Dubai, and I was so excited upon seeing this shop on a weekend stroll down Clark street. The selection of tea is huge, and the gentleman running the store was very kind and helpful. Very unique store with Persian jewelry, art, tea, coffee and also food and snacks. There was a really neat section in the back with old books in Arabic which was awesome.

31.description: I've been stopping in Pars more frequently this year than in years past. It's more pleasant than it used to be. Their staples- rice, jams, spices, tea, pickles, oils- can be a little pricey, but they are remarkably fresher than places that have similar products in the neighborhood, and which also tend to charge a premium. I think they get away with it because it sure beats walking to Devon & Western from Andersonville and carrying a 15 lb bag of basmati back with you.Pars's incense, soap and confection selections have improved dramatically. They also have loads of jewelry. There are a couple of nice pieces among many pretty standard ones. If you check it out, could you please explain to me what is up with the painting of three women leading a man on a leash? You can't miss it. It's right in front, and maybe four feet high.

25.description: I love their tea selection here. I haven't purchased anything but tea here. But their tea is amazing. If you get a chance to stop in check out the fancy hooka selection as well. Kind of a crowded place but worth a scan.

12.description: I really like this place for loose leaf teas.  The selection is unbeatable and the prices are very reasonable--unlike some uppity, chain stores that charge an arm and a leg for a mere few ounces.  They also have tons of tea and coffee brewing paraphernalia, which also reasonably priced.  I bought a small, stove-top espresso maker and a French press from here--brand names you'd pay more elsewhere.This is definitely my go-to place to stock up on teas, coffees and other goods.

21.description: Wow!  Such a remarkable transformation since the move.  The new store is very open and bright.  I assume this transformation means they are doing well, and I am really glad to see Pars benefiting from the growth around Andersonville.  Why do I come here?  Pars has the Best loose tea selection in Andersonville (or really anywhere on the north side) and the prices are more than reasonable.  My wife is a huge tea drinker and is never disappointed with the selection or quality.Pars also has all your Persian staples, including many bottled/jarred items, spices and seasonings and relatively cheap Basmati rice.   They sell all of the tea and coffee supplies you could need short of an espresso maker and they carry Bodum products which are top notch (though a bit fragile.)  The guy at the counter (the owner?) is very nice, but not overly friendly.  This is perfect for me as I like to peruse the store in search of new finds.  I always seem to have a good experience when I step in the door.

16.description: Love it.  Fantastic tea selection, as well as bulk spices.

17.description: Ah, this little authentic Persian market.....I love it.  Absolutely charming in every way and they carry my favorite Persian ice cream in the universe.  Made and packaged in Westwood, Los Angeles, I am convinced that this ice cream is karmically imported solely for MY benefit.  No, but really, you MUST try it.  This market and its owners/workers make my heart happy and I'm sure they will do the same for yours.

10.description: Looks like a great place to get loose and bagged tea along with seasonings and spices if you know what you're looking for. They also have lots of knickknacky stuff and unique mini pots and hookahs.I walked in here with my sister and although there seemed to be a few people either working there or possibly just hanging out, we weren't acknowledged in the slightest bit. I walked in to find some saffron and as I walked through the place and didn't notice any, I walked back out. Had someone said hello, I would of felt less intimidated about asking about the wonderful spice. They didn't even look at us. Were we were invisible? I don't think I had my invisibility cloak on at the time so it didn't make much sense. Oh well, I may return, only if I cannot find saffron anywhere else since I know they do carry it from previous reviews.

11.description: I am in love with this store! I passed by it constantly for almost a year until I finally decided to go in. The sapphron and rose ice cream was the most delicious, unusual thing i've ever tasted. It's one of my favorites now and I thank Pars for having it there.

26.description: In recent months, the tea selection has expanded to include an even larger stockpile of well-priced loose green and black teas. I spent about $6 recently and more than filled up two 100-gram tins. Then there's the wall of packaged teas ...Should you need a device to make your tea (or coffee or espresso), they have an extensive selection of french presses, moka pots, and tea paraphernalia.Pars sells other prepackaged and bulk, especially Middle Eastern cooking and food products. While you're there, check out the jewelry, CDs, belly-dancing outfits, soaps, and so forth.What has always surprised me is how pleasant the owners are to everyone, including the neighborhood interlopers.

27.description: A very unique store, no joke!  Step in here and you think, WOOW!  Your eyes become dizzy from not being sure of what to look at.  Yet, you don't faint due to the peaceful scent of fresh teas.  They have hooka items, belly dancing outfits, furniture, foreign food products, pots and the TEA SELECTION!  Jeeez!  That's what reeled me in here.  They have a full wall of it and all at great prices.  They also have large plastic canisters of loose-leaf tea for $14.99 a pound (can't say I'd ever be able to drink that).  However, I disliked how these teas were not in air-sealed canisters, yet they did smell tea-licious.I mean the best teas origins do come from the Middle East, get yours here!

0.description: Pars Persian store, sells authentic Saffron, Persian tea,Turkish coffee, dried fruits, persian sweets, basmati rice, and middle eastern seasonings.  I usually get Persian tea Ahmad brand or Sadaf with cardamom flavor which has a very unique taste.  Mr. Haghighi, the owner, is such a friendly person, he is always kind and helpful. He also sells beautiful tea cup sets with middle eastern designs, fancy brewing pots, Persian rugs and all sort of amazing goods. It is a place to find a unique gift for a especial person.

20.description: What a hidden little gem! I guess it's on Clark so it's not that hidden, but it's certainly not ostentatious, and I've never seen any advertising.  Anyway, I'm glad I decided to take a stroll down Clark to see what I've been missing b/c I would have never found this place otherwise. There are so many loose teas, and they're all so inexpensive!! I got some mixed fruit tea (you just take a pouch and pour some out of a bin candystore style) and my mom got a green tea and a lavander one. Mine was delish. There are also many interesting spices which I know nothing about, but they're pretty cool to study nonetheless. I'm also considering getting a teapot since you can get them as cheap as $10. So great!

19.description: Wow!  Such a remarkable transformation since the move.  The new store is very open and bright.  I assume this transformation means they are doing well, and I am really glad to see Pars benefiting from the growth around Andersonville.  Why do I come here?  Pars has the Best loose tea selection in Andersonville (or really anywhere on the north side) and the prices are more than reasonable.  My wife is a huge tea drinker and is never disappointed with the selection or quality.Pars also has all your Persian staples, including many bottled/jarred items, spices and seasonings and relatively cheap Basmati rice.   They sell all of the tea and coffee supplies you could need short of an espresso maker and they carry Bodum products which are top notch (though a bit fragile.)  The guy at the counter (the owner?) is very nice, but not overly friendly.  This is perfect for me as I like to peruse the store in search of new finds.  I always seem to have a good experience when I step in the door.

33.description: This is a very interesting store with an unusual assortment of goods.  The upstairs is filled with pictures and gorgeous Persian rugs.  The downstairs  is filled with groceries and household goods.  There are some good deals in this store, while other items seem a bit pricey.  It is a great place to stroll through.

2.description: Really fun shop with a big collection of items and some great teas. Definitely worth a stop to browse around.

32.description: Interesting. Is getting more well organized, but is still sort of haphazard.The belly dancing costumes are crap - tourist quality, very poorly made. Watch out for the bulk chocolates - some I bought here had worms.What's good are the teas, and the Persian pop CDs.

18.description: A fantastic little hidden gem that has some of the best teas ive ever had. The tea selection is amazing and while not cheap, the quality is excellent. They also have a nice selection of spices and nuts.

13.description: Awesome selection of teas at great prices. Lots of unique spices also.

4.description: I love this store! So many wonderful varies of loose tea & other goods. The owner is very friendly. I've moved out of the area but every chance I get to return, I still stop by to shop & visit!

24.description: Holy crap, the tea. I'm drinking some pouchong right now. Best I've had. Better than Ten Ren in Chinatown. I tried one of their lighter greens yesterday and it was also great; paid about $3 for a few ounces of it in bulk, and it was comparable to a cup - just one cup - that I had at Intelligentsia for $4.50.  Also, Bodum and Bialetti coffee and tea gear everywhere. This is a good place.

6.description: I love Pars Persian for its selection of affordable loose-leaf teas. They have pre-mixed selections such as Vanilla Raspberry Rooibos, Fruit of Pearls, and Apple Cinnamon, but they also have bulk selections of varietials of black, green, and rooibos teas, with jars where you can get other items (dried flowers, etc) to create your own tea blends. I go back about 4x a year to stock up!

22.description: If you're looking for the necessary ingredients to cook a Persian meal, this should be your go-to grocer. They have a great selection of staples for the pantry - starches, spices, tea, etc. If they don't have enough of what you need on hand, the owner will gladly order extra for you. Call ahead to check if they have what you need in stock.Also, if you're into middle eastern trinkets this place is stocked.

15.description: A very unique store, no joke!  Step in here and you think, WOOW!  Your eyes become dizzy from not being sure of what to look at.  Yet, you don't faint due to the peaceful scent of fresh teas.  They have hooka items, belly dancing outfits, furniture, foreign food products, pots and the TEA SELECTION!  Jeeez!  That's what reeled me in here.  They have a full wall of it and all at great prices.  They also have large plastic canisters of loose-leaf tea for $14.99 a pound (can't say I'd ever be able to drink that).  However, I disliked how these teas were not in air-sealed canisters, yet they did smell tea-licious.I mean the best teas origins do come from the Middle East, get yours here!

7.description: Today I visited this store for the third time with my partner. We are tea addicts! I also use a lot of spices in my ethnic cooking, so this place is perfect for us. The reviewers are right -  EXCELLENT assortment of bulk teas, cheap bulk spices, and fair prices overall. We've also purchased the nuts - the roasted and unsalted ones, YUMMY! You're not hassled, they're not pushy. So why only 2 stars? While we love their merchandise, the customer service is sub-par. Today, we went to the register with two teas and the total only came up to around $2. I was surprised it was so cheap and turned to my partner to see if he had cash. I didn't want to pay for such a paltry sum using my card. We didn't have cash. I asked the older man behind the register if he would take the card (I didn't see a sign for a minimum card purchase), and proceeded to get YELLED at! "NO THIS IS RIDICULOUS. $8 MINIMUM! CASH FOR THIS." I turned to my partner and told him to get more tea, while I grabbed some nuts. Our new total was $18, we paid with card, and left without saying a word. No apology, nothing.My White American and very culturally-competent partner played devil's advocate and attributed the interaction to a language barrier. But I've interacted with my fair share of middle easterners and Muslims in America because I'm one myself. I saw it for what it is: rudeness. Not sure if we'll come back here again...

8.description: Great place for unique teas and persian specialties.  I like how no one hassles you here and let you browse to your content.

30.description: This place has good deals on bread, coffee, dried fruit (the miniature figs look like some kind of avant garde ceramic scultpure), and spices, and a very calming atmosphere.  The owner remembers his customers and is gracious, with a lovely self-deprecating sense of humor.  The cluttered loft arrangement is cool and the Iranian music is energizing.  I seem to be unable to visit this neighborhood without insisting on dragging my friends into this store.

3.description: A wonderful store for affordable tea, coffee and spices.  All kinds of apparatus for coffee and tea as well.Tea -- global tea selections at bulk rate.  There are a few in a box as well.Moroccan Mint Tea -- smell and taste super duper minty.  Steeped for 5 mins, it tasted like the real deal from restaurants without the tedious process of traditional preparation.  I got this from the dark green big bin.Coffee -- Mexican, Costa Rican and Jamaican beans etc.Arabic Coffee maker -- fancy design, all for $8.  Yay!

14.description: Went here looking for Persian tea similar to the one I had at Noon O Kebab. The woman working there was very nice after I started talking to her and willing to explain the many (at least 40+) different teas they carry. Although we sometimes had difficulty understanding each other, we were eventually able to figure it out and I picked out two delicious smelling teas. They carry all different varieties of tea including Japanese maatcha, which another customer had been looking all over for. Also picked up green cardamon which is supposed to be great for cooking and rose water.

28.description: Oh @mosphere, how you make me giggle! As a semi-pro "fag hag," I've been to few places that are more unabashedly gay. I don't know if it is the madonna techno or the boys in lamé hot shorts, but this place sort of seems like how a gay bar would be in the movies.

1.description: I've been to @mosphere twice for Wednesday night Drag Queen BINGO and have always had a good time (seeing how I've won 4 times). The regulars are more than happy to welcome a new face to the exciting world of BINGO.The bar is a decent size and the bartender isn't shy when it comes to pouring the booze. The only negative about @mosphere is that it's a cash only bar.

39.description: Great small dance bar in Chicago. Nice service and  friendly . We were here on Sat night .They have male dancers and very fun upbeat musics . Free buffet on Sun. 6pm.-8pm.     We'll comeback  for sure!

9.description: YAWN.....RUDE....Rarely any one in here and when it is crowded, the crowd is not fun and not pretty. Even the go go boys can't make this place rock. Most recently (and for the last time), I went in with some friends and was so disappointed.  Bartenders with attitude that don't know how to handle a crowd. I don't care if you are gay or straight or bi---learn to bartend boys and girls!! Yeah, serve all your friends first and ignore everyone else at the bar. Very nice. After waiting 15 minutes for a drink, the bartender continued to ignore me when a group of his friends walked in and pushed their way to his station. So wait another 5 minutes as the bartender does shots with all this friends and just about everyone else at the other end of the bar. Then I called the bartender over (politely, I called him over since I have worked as a bartender and I get it) and he shouted "WAIT YOUR TURN MF!!" Well, that was enough for me so my friends and I left and went down the street to a more friendly and fun bar. I recommend the management there watch their bartenders more carefully and maybe train them in customer service. Unless of course you are trying to be Mini-Bar, then, well, good luck with that. The door staff seemed very nice so that was a surprise. Maybe they should train your bartenders.Won't be back.

29.description: This place used to be pretty cool...fun to have a cheap drink during the week, listen to some Morrissey and flirt with the shirtless bartenders of ambiguous sexual orientation. I went back recently  (after a year or more) and it was SKANKY! I mean, I'm not gonna say I didn't watch the male strippers... or proceed to meet up with them at Stargaze and then go to Jackhammer with them...but SKANKY ;) Shameless! Also, in the past I didn't feel particularly uncomfortable being the only woman in the bar but I definitely got some attitude from the mostly male clientele this time...Oh! And I didn't see any porn, but if they do show porn it can't be worse than Clarks on Clark! GMP 24x7!

23.description: i must say that the idea of male strippers is fairly hilarious to me in the first place. muscly mens gyrating in banana hammocks and work boots just doesn't do it for me. but, if i must watch strippers, i prefer that they be semi-conscious and lucid. i realize the stage is about the size of a toaster oven but at least attempt to move around to the music. laying against the wall and rubbing yourself while gazing bleary eyed at the ceiling... not all that sexy.now that thats out of the way, i will say that the bartenders have always been very friendly to me here and though the music isn't my thing, it fits the stripper vibe they've got goin' on.

5.description: I'm starting to wonder if this place is a front for some illegal gambling or S&M in the basement.  There is never anyone in this place whenever I pass it.  I'd really like it if they'd swap places with Marty's as they always have too big of a crowd for that tiny space.

31.description: Having been in my share of similar spots, I keep coming back to this one because it just seems to have a more "up" vibe to it. Whether that's the staff, the patrons who are refreshingly not the primping Halsted lot, the open windows facing Clark, or the distracting rugby players on the screens, you've got me, but that plus a clean washroom adds up to a nice spot to put yourself under the hammer and put together a proper hangover.

25.description: I've lived in Uptown for over a year and a half. And when I came across this bar over a year ago... I found it to be refreshing to be away from the bars on Halsted. I remember discussing with friends how we were going to spend out summer up north, rather than going to BT...Summer came and went. I think I've been to Atmosphere 3 times since the first time.... I dunno what happened because we were ALL about it.I wish there was more pull to drive more traffic up there... It would be so much fun if we could get them to be busier!I gave you 4 stars for potential :)

12.description: I fully expected that this morning I would be updating my review of @mosphere, raving about how wonderful they are. How sad that I'm going in the opposite direction.Last night was the latest in a series of Yelp Chicago Gay Nights. I chose @mosphere for the event because of their widely advertised Sabbath Stripper Sunday, with $1 well drinks, $5 martinis, and male dancers at 9pm. Imagine my surprise when I walked in the door at 7 o'clock to discover that they were hosting a benefit for Season of Concern, featuring storytellers from Serendipity Theater. And imagine my combined embarrassment and annoyance when they started scolding us for being too loud.Now both of these are admirable organizations, and I can understand performers wanting some quiet and attention while they are working. And if had had any idea there were going to be storytellers at @mosphere, I would never have scheduled an event there. But at no time over the past month since Gay Night was planned was there any mention of a benefit on the same night. Their Midsommarfest schedule was clearly posted; this week's "Club Manhunt" has been up for weeks; even the weekly trivia contest is listed. But the "please be quiet because people will be reading their stories" event? Not a sign. This, in spite of the fact the @mosphere's website has an Events page, which links to their Google Calendar of scheduled events. Oops. The woman from Serendipity Theater did tell me that the information was posted on their website, as well as on the Season of Concern website. So if planned to have dollar drinks and strippers at Serendipity Theater, I would have been fully warned.About those dollar drinks. No dollar drinks. When I went to the bar, I saw the special listed as $3 drinks. When I asked the bartender about it -- the surly bartender who took his surly time getting to me, despite the fact that I was clearly the only person at the bar looking to get a drink -- he said, "Oh yeah, we don't do that any more." To which I replied, "Better change the website, then." Because it's up there, clear as day. On the freaking home page. To which he replied, "It's on the website?" *sigh* As it turns out, the $3 price is a tremendous discount from the regular $4 price. And if these drinks were any more than $4, I'd be finding another bar.At this point, you may be wondering why I even give @mosphere 3 stars.In the end, it all turned out okay. The stories ranged from okay to pretty good, and most people missed the worst one, which was the first one. By 9pm, we were allowed to talk and act like we were in a bar. About the same time, the nice bartender started working, which was a huge relief. And some time between 9 and 10 -- 9pm in gay time -- the strippers started working. Well, you can't really call them strippers, since they started as undressed as they were going to get, and you can't really call them dancers, because even if they wanted to dance, their platform is about the size of a coffee table. But they were all reasonably attractive and 2 of the 3 were actually friendly and in a bar like @mosphere, you take what you can get. Which kind of sums up the whole experience.

37.description: While Atmosphere draws a large, eclectic mix, the crowd is predominantly gay and lesbian. There's never a cover, though the space does host special events and benefits that are always open to the public. A 30-foot-long bar and an elevated seating area overlook the dance floor, often set in motion by a DJ spinning dance hits and house standards. Exposed brick walls, galvanized metal and hardwood floors and warm lighting create an inviting upscale ambiance. Closed Mondays, the week starts off with $1 bud light drafts and well drinks on Tuesdays, Wednesdays feature the Comedy and Song talent of Amy Armstrong and Freddy Allen. There's always great music on the awesome sound system with many local guest DJs .  Fridays and Saturdays feature late night Go-Go boys if that's your thing. Sunday Free buffet from 6pm to 8pm.Summer Hours: 5 p.m.-2 a.m. Tuesday through Friday; 3 p.m.-3 a.m. Saturday; 3 p.m.-2 a.m. Sunday; Closed Monday except for private parties

21.description: The $.50 well drink specials lured me in and kept me on a bar stool for the evening.  I got to flex some mental muscle by teaming up with my homegirl, Erika G.  We blew the competition out of the water by winning at free trivia night!  A sign for Sabbath strippers on Sunday with $1 drink specials is a little bit awesome.When it's nice, you can sit by the open windows and watch the activity on Clark St.Why I haven't gone in here before is beyond me.  I'll be back.

16.description: I find @mosphere to be not quite sure of what it is. I find @mosphere a bit creepy as well. A fun place in the summer maybe when they open up the outside windows for their inner deck but there isn't much here that makes them a unique place I want to go. But then again it is a bar. 3 stars for the cute dancers there sometimes. Especially the one who did the towel dance the other night. he showed me his Pee pee for only a $1 tip.

17.description: I've heard friends buzz about this place, but when I checked it out last Saturday, it was kind of boring. I thought it would have been a lot larger, and there was probably a crowd of 20 or less, including the 1 no-no dancer. Okay, I mean go-go dancer. Drinks weren't that great, and it's cash only!

10.description: The only drawback being this place is cash-only, I was still pleasantly surprised with the very cool staff-- thanks, Michael, for being a great tender o' the bar.I've only been here on a Sunday evening thus far, but I would definitely return for more fun with friends.

11.description: Boys night out for team Yelp.  This once a month fun night is usually coordinated by our own dear John.This month, he chose @mosphere.  I decided I'd go, because I'd only been once before (the night I made out with a bar tender in the street - what, don't judge me. You've done it too...besides I was waiting for a cab to go to Jackhammer, and had nothing else to do.)I arrived after 7pm, to find out that there was some sort of beatnick literary thing going on, and that there were no real drink specials.  That was fine with me, I mostly go for the company - and the alcohol, regardless if its on special.More Yelp gays arrived, the story tellers ended, and some very speedo clad muscle boys climbed up on the stripper stage.  I find it odd that they all wear white sneakers and socks.  I'd think they'd go the flip flop route, but maybe that prevents them from doing some of their special dance routines.The hot one kept showing his tuchas, which I deeply appreciated.  I again had a moment of deep self reflection, and in that minute or two I realized I do not have abs, pecs, or any sort of a tan.  I do have a bit of sunburn, but I don't really think that counts as sexy.Oh yeah.  And my blind date showed up too.  Which was fun, because there was so much less pressure - and the Yelp gays are a great group (and the super sass pot girls that come along too! hubba hubba!)The bathrooms are clean, and the stalls are divided with little walls, which is nice, because I do not want anyone to look at my penis while I'm going to the bathroom.  And for the most part, if you ask, I'll just show it to you.  But you know, its less awkward with the little dividers.As the night went on, either my drinks got stronger or I was getting drunker.  Is drunker a word? Or is it more drunk? Who cares. I'm pretty, so I can phrase it how I like.  I managed to take several great photographs, and got to meet some new people.  I have to say this may have been the best Yelp Gay Night so far - everyone was in a great mood, including the bar staff (spare the lady that told us to keep it down....I'll do the shushing thank you. I'm the professional librarian)omg! I almost forgot.  They play porn on flat screen TV's around the bar.  I think its porn.  The guys in the films make me throw up in my mouth a little.  Like imagine Burt Reynolds and Tom Selleck, with 80's moustaches, doing porn.  I mean, you don't HAVE to imagine it, but it will help you understand what I'm talking about, because I'm not going to act it out for you.   I'm thinking its porn because the guys are  naked, and touch one another.  I wasn't really watching to see if there were any money shots, because the strippers kept distracting me.  I'd totally go here again.  And I'd totally make out on the corner with someone again too.  Its fun.

26.description: Oh @mosphere!  It seems you have an identity crisis.  Please tell me: exactly WHAT are you trying to be?  You have a lot of potential.  It seems that you try to please everyone, but you don't really succeed.Sometimes there are strippers.  Sometimes there's dancing. Sometimes there are drag queens.  In the past, there have been cabaret acts.  You never know what to expect.It is a nice space.  It's clean, comfortable and nicely appointed.  The drinks are good and reasonably priced and there are always decent specials.For all of this, the place rarely is busy.  This bar is stumbling distance from my house, but I tend to avoid it.The staff is friendly and it has a good neighborhood vibe. These factors prompt me to give it three stars, although it 2.5 might be more like it.  If I do pop into @mosphere, it's as a "first drink of the night" kind of deal.  It's usually pretty quiet and makes for good "where do we go next" conversation.I just wish they could pull it together better.  For a place that calls itself @mosphere, it rather lacks atmosphere.

27.description: So I have been to @mosphere a couple of times and I just don't get it, the prices are good, the service is attentive and friendly, but I think this bar is not sure what it is. One night they had strippers, but there isn't really a stage, more of a podium so it was kinda ackward. I want one tuesday night and it was pretty dead, but they were blasting generic diva pop with the disco ball going full force and horrible, weird, almost painfully softcore porn on the tvs behind the bar. I love the exposed brick, and the raised area in front, but I honestly think they should take advantage of it. It's not in boystown, and thankfully bar patrons in Andersonville see that as a plus, so I think they should embrace their surroundings and the appeal, at least for me would go way up. I wouldn't hesitate to return given the occasion, but definitely very low on my list of gay bars.

35.description: A fun and interesting Saturday night.  I'm not sure if every Saturday has the same schedule but what we saw we enjoyed.  When we first arrived there was a dancing/singing type thing going on (I have no idea what to call it.  It was a group of people, choreographed, singing random Madonna and Boy band songs, in different arrangements of people).  It was absolutely entertaining.After that, male strippers.Perfect bar for a bachelorette party (if you want that kind of party).  There were moments of slight creepiness (and if you're "innocent" or naive or, dare I say it, prude, you wouldn't enjoy what we saw), but overall the friends and I felt really comfortable here and laughed and danced and drank.

8.description: What a shame.  Such a good market in Andersonville and this place ends up a waste of space.  To the owners, if you read this:1) Playing "untz untz untz" music at full volume with 10 people in the entire bar is NOT COOL.  Chances are, we're probably trying to have a chat.2) Whatever music subscription service you're using - please dear god, let that subscription run out.  Nobody wants to hear bad Mary J Blige remixes anymore.  Just put on an ipod and keep in mind that gay boys like guitars too.3) Go go boys?  Really?  Sweetie, this ain't boystown.  Save it for the tourists and straight girls.  Those boys are awkwardly painful to watch.4)  Fix that nasty-ass bathroom.Complete these steps, and you just might win a crowd.  As is, this bar is sad.

0.description: forgot to add... they have male dancers every Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday night... NEW drink special for Friday:  $13 Cosmo Pitchers... woo hoo

38.description: Great drink specials ($1 well drinks and jello shots on Tuesdays!) and friendly staff.  I have yet to come here on a weekend.. but during the week, the other patrons are friendly, and its not too smoky or crowded.  And the pretzels they leave out for me to nosh on are not stale.  Bonus!

20.description: This one time it was my birthday- I was drunk (but I suppose that's no surprise) we had some not so amazing (yet very intoxicating) drinks at Ceaser's followed by more drinks at @mosphere. Was it just me or did the strippers look sickly? I mean they had nice bodies and what not- but they all these sort of jacked up faces. Who knows? Maybe it was the rubbing alcohol Ceaser's gave me on the house in the form of a shot. But ever since that night I cant get the images of those dancers out of my head- and it ain't pretty.

19.description: @mosphere is possibly my new favorite bar. Or at least my new favorite place to get an ego boost. I've never been told I was beautiful more times that last night at @mosphere. I don't care that the men who were telling me were gay, they were sincere dang it, I did look cute! For me Thursday nights may be the way to go. Three dollar well drinks? Check. Male strippers giving  lap dances? Check. Boys Gone Wild on every TV screen ? Check. Good times. Hopleaf had better watch out!

33.description: For the warmer months @mosphere gets a four star review. I love going there on a weeknight when it is nearly empty and sitting at a table in the window with a couple friends for hours. Somehow I always seem to end up there on dollar drink night as well. Do they have them that often or is it just a fluke? I don't know. Hey - for cheap drinks and a nice spot to sit and chat this is a great place to check out in Andersonville.

2.description: Visited awhile back and came in for a few drinks and to hang out. Pretty large space with seating at bar, high tops, and stage for dancers (attractive men in briefs). Very laid-back bar, nothing too flashy. It wasn't overly crowded, decent music. I'd return. -1 cash only

34.description: @mosphere is possibly my new favorite bar. Or at least my new favorite place to get an ego boost. I've never been told I was beautiful more times that last night at @mosphere. I don't care that the men who were telling me were gay, they were sincere dang it, I did look cute! For me Thursday nights may be the way to go. Three dollar well drinks? Check. Male strippers giving  lap dances? Check. Boys Gone Wild on every TV screen ? Check. Good times. Hopleaf had better watch out!

32.description: You gotta love @mosphere when you're in Andersonville. My friends like to stop in here when we are in the area. They pour the drinks stiff and that's not the only thing.. they have male dancers on Friday and Saturday nights. It gives you something to look at while you're in there. They also have eye candy on the plasmas so you have something else to look at. The bartenders are sweet and they like to give you some extra vodka with your cocktail!

18.description: It's a little trashy, but also a good time.  The bartenders are friendly and the drinks are of adequate strength.  The dancers that I've seen the numerous times I have visited @mosphere have been decent and there's a variety of types and personalities.I compare it to Cocktail a lot in Boystown - both have similar decor and dancers, but @mosphere is nowhere near as crowded, which is a plus for me and my occasional social anxiety.I wont go out of my way to come here, like I would for Mary's Attic, but if I end up here I'm not upset about it.

13.description: The $.50 well drink specials lured me in and kept me on a bar stool for the evening.  I got to flex some mental muscle by teaming up with my homegirl, Erika G.  We blew the competition out of the water by winning at free trivia night!  A sign for Sabbath strippers on Sunday with $1 drink specials is a little bit awesome.When it's nice, you can sit by the open windows and watch the activity on Clark St.Why I haven't gone in here before is beyond me.  I'll be back.

4.description: Strong drinks, mediocre talent dancing in their underwear.  Place is kinda dated, it's got a distinct 1970's, gay sex is still taboo feel.  I'd say it's okay for a quick drink, but not all night...  Unless of course you're ugly.  If you're ugly, you may get turned on by the mediocre dancers.  If that's the case, bring your singles so you can keep creeping on those guys and making pathetic attempts to touch their junk! :)

24.description: I find @mosphere to be not quite sure of what it is. I find @mosphere a bit creepy as well. A fun place in the summer maybe when they open up the outside windows for their inner deck but there isn't much here that makes them a unique place I want to go. But then again it is a bar. 3 stars for the cute dancers there sometimes. Especially the one who did the towel dance the other night. he showed me his Pee pee for only a $1 tip.

6.description: Well! Trivia, .50 well drink specials, cute-charming bartender, SABBATH STRIPPERS ON SUNDAY with $1 drinks! Do specials GET any better than this?I'm going to be going here more often!Updated to add: And Kellie K. and I  ROCKED the trivia - we won!

22.description: Well! Trivia, .50 well drink specials, cute-charming bartender, SABBATH STRIPPERS ON SUNDAY with $1 drinks! Do specials GET any better than this?I'm going to be going here more often!Updated to add: And Kellie K. and I  ROCKED the trivia - we won!

15.description: Great atmosphere, drinks and great place to socialize. Drinks are reasonably price, great service and the owner is an amazing person. Warm, charming and great at making you feel welcome.

7.description: Great neighborhood place to hang out!  All of the bartenders and staff are so friendly, and the owner Charlie is maybe the nicest guy ever.  I contacted him about reserving some seating/table space last weekend for a bachelorette party, and he was so friendly and accommodating!  Cheap drinks, good beats, waxed chests - what more can you ask for?  We had an awesome time, can't wait to go back and check out a drag show or two in the future.

36.description: I always have a great time when i come to @tmosphere. The bartenders are great, the crowd is friendly and last but not least my favorite Cabaret duo sings here...Amy and Freddy. I've followed them around for the past 8 years or so and this is one of the friendliest bars they have performed at. @tmosphere you're okay in my book!

30.description: The drinks are strong.  The porn never ends.That's about it -- have been here a few times now, and it's always been dead minus one Friday late night when I stopped in, when the dancers had started.End your night here, but don't start it.

3.description: I ordered Titos but it tasted like well vodka. Skeptical that it's true Titos and not cheap vodka they put in it instead

14.description: This place used to be pretty cool...fun to have a cheap drink during the week, listen to some Morrissey and flirt with the shirtless bartenders of ambiguous sexual orientation. I went back recently  (after a year or more) and it was SKANKY! I mean, I'm not gonna say I didn't watch the male strippers... or proceed to meet up with them at Stargaze and then go to Jackhammer with them...but SKANKY ;) Shameless! Also, in the past I didn't feel particularly uncomfortable being the only woman in the bar but I definitely got some attitude from the mostly male clientele this time...Oh! And I didn't see any porn, but if they do show porn it can't be worse than Clarks on Clark! GMP 24x7!

58.description: After strutting my way through a 5k at Montrose harbor, we crashed on in to this lil' breakfast/lunch spot to restore a few calories. I have to say, I am surprised over the low reviews on this place. I have to attribute it to the advanced intellect and palates of north siders. As a lowly south sider, I could only rave over the fresh squeezed juice and "Pauline's potatoes," which is their take on potatoes O'Brien. My wife got eggs benedict with crab, which was the first time we've ever seen that on a menu. What we got was not the heavily processed Alaskan Pollock that you'd get at most places advertising crab...but REAL EFFING CRAB MEAT. It was awesome. As for myself, I got the cold saltwater salmon omelet with asparagus and goat cheese...equally awesome. Oh, and I have some advice for you peeps that are extremely dissatisfied with this place...count your blessings and take your one star..hug them tight, and go to Denny's! ;]

56.description: This has become my go-to breakfast/brunch place.  Not only is the food always fresh tasting and delicious but it always comes out in a jiffy.  You can't go wrong with either breakfast or lunch here.  The Benedict's are outstanding, pancakes are like a fluffy dream,  fresh squeezed juices are life savers, and their thick-cut bacon has to be the best restaurant bacon I have ever had.  As for lunch stuff you can't go wrong with a burger here.  But my favorite is the Turkey Bacon Swiss Club.  With carved turkey, the same amazing bacon, and a strong Jarlsberg Swiss; this sandwich is king.  Their homemade soups are always good their signature ham and bean is outstanding.  The service is always friendly and like I said earlier the service and food is quick and you are never waiting too long if they are full up.  Overall this place is consistent with great food, fast service, and don't forget the candy bin before you leave!

29.description: Pauline's is the only breakfast place within walking distance from where I live, so I frequent this restaurant often. Though sometimes I find myself driving or taking the train to somewhere else because frankly Pauline's could be so much better. Even though this is a small no frills breakfast place, which I like, you really don't get what you pay for. They charge $9 for a very BASIC eggs benedict that comes with NO sides. Their omelettes are quite good and come with a side of potatoes, which makes them reasonably priced. The potatoes, however, are a hit and miss. They're usually too mushy and flavorless. Not a fan.In other words, if you want a traditional no-frills breakfast, you can go elsewhere for much more reasonable prices.

42.description: Finally got to Pauline's after driving by it for a few months now on my way home from work. Staff was very friendly and accomodating to everyone that walked through the door. We sat outside and were promptly give water. Boyfriend ordered coffee and I ordered OJ. His coffee mug hadn't been cleaned very well as there was still lipstick on it which he wound up wiping off. I got the panacke special and he had the lumberjack special. The food was tasty and it was a change of pace from going to Golden Nugget. I will say that both of us wound up having heartburn the rest of the day, possibly from the eggs as that was the only thing we both had that could have caused it.Overall the place is OK, staff was nice and food was decent. Maybe a smidge overpriced as before tip the bill was $27. I felt I had enough food but I feel we do get more for our money elsewhere.I'd like to try their lunch/soups one day and will probably save that for cooler months.

23.description: We go to Pauline's often since it's the closest breakfast place near us. Let me break it down for you:1. Atmosphere: Pauline's has a very 50's, kitschy, diner-type feel to it. In my opinion, it is the most endearing quality about this place. It even comes with its very own regular who seems to be there almost everyday, sitting outside if the weather is nice, with his parrots. It's a fun place to bring visitors from out-of-town because they always seem to be taken by this place, partly due to the cuteness factor and partly because it doesn't seem like your typical tourist destination. I think it makes them feel like they are eating at a hole-in-the-wall, although I'm pretty sure the secret has been out for quite some time now...2. Food: Considering they are open until 3pm, they also have a lunch menu, but I haven't been impressed with anything on it. If you're going here, I would stick to breakfast.  The fresh squeezed juices are nice. The pancakes and french toast are both very good. The omelettes are huge, but just okay, in my opinion. They come with a side of potatoes which are very good. Try them with the spicy ketchup! 3. Value: I'm not really sure how I feel about the prices. The portions are quite large, but I feel like this is the kind of place that you'd expect to be able to get cheap, standard breakfast fare and it's definitely not cheap. The coffee is bottomless, but it's nothing to write home about. Just your standard run-of-the-mill diner coffee, but that's all I can really ask for from a place like this.

47.description: First visit since I moved here was great--good food and a super nice young man to wait on me.  I will be back particularly when it warms up and the patio becomes welcoming.  I'll bring my iPad and enjoy the food, the delicious coffee, wifi and the urban locale. What's not to love?

8.description: Probably the most uncomfortable place I've ever been. As a Mexican lady with a Black/Puerto Rican boyfriend who both attend DePaul University we've adopted color blindness as most of our classes are predominantly made up of white students. Going into Pauline's has been the only place to make me notice my nationality as my boyfriend and I entered and given the strangest look  by the woman seating people: grey hair, bangs, sweaty eyeliner, and glasses. The place was busy so we didn't think much of it. As she attended people who clearly arrived after us my boyfriend moved so that he could stand directly in front of her so she couldn't miss us. STILL she refused to even make eye contact with us. After about 10 minutes of waiting around we decided to leave. Pretty disappointed because we were pretty excited to try this place out. Took our brunch to Home Slice on Webster and Bissell; literally the best food.

31.description: Haven't been here in a few years. This place is still awesome. Excellent salad with great choice of dressings. Feta cheese omelette with spinach was very good as well. And I ordered heard a Waldorf salad to go. I don't see that on the menu too often these days. Oh and the waitress we had, Caitlyn, was wonderful too.

34.description: Food is above average and service is nice. Good for either breakfast or brunch. Lunch menu does not have as many options. Portions are large.

16.description: Pauline's is the only breakfast place within walking distance from where I live, so I frequent this restaurant often. Though sometimes I find myself driving or taking the train to somewhere else because frankly Pauline's could be so much better. Even though this is a small no frills breakfast place, which I like, you really don't get what you pay for. They charge $9 for a very BASIC eggs benedict that comes with NO sides. Their omelettes are quite good and come with a side of potatoes, which makes them reasonably priced. The potatoes, however, are a hit and miss. They're usually too mushy and flavorless. Not a fan.In other words, if you want a traditional no-frills breakfast, you can go elsewhere for much more reasonable prices.

13.description: The best thing about this place in being able to sit outside in a quaint neighborhood. Food was ok. Service very mediocre. They also had s stinky man with a big bird eating spaghetti next to tables. Kinda gross.

11.description: Pauline's has a really great ambiance. It feels like you're in a small town or at least not in Chicago. I came here for a friend's birthday brunch. The juice was delicious, but the food was just okay. I got an omelet, but nothing really stood out about it. The potatoes with the omelet were pretty good. I think the best thing Pauline's has going for it is their ambiance. They have an interesting collection of things displayed.

39.description: I live in the neighborhood and have had breakfast at Pauline's several times over the years.  I would describe the food and overall experience as "average," but my last visit changed that.  I would now describe Pauline's as "disgusting."  The people that work there are nice, which accounts for the 2 stars instead of 1.  Also, the coffee is good.  That's it for the positive.  The negative:-  The staff cleaning the entire restaurant while I'm eating-  The strong smell of chemical cleaning agents permeating the air, mixed with grease-  Fruit flies swarming my food for the duration of my meal-  Omelets are made with some kind of thin, pourable egg product and not fluffy real eggs-  An obnoxious sound of pigs being slaughtered throughout my meal.No, I'm not kidding.  The noise was so disturbing that I asked my waitress what it was.  She said, deadpan, "They are killing the pigs to make bacon."I am still trying to figure out if she was joking.  Being a vegetarian, I completely lost my appetite at that point.  I asked her again if she was serious or what.She then said:  "No no - it's somebody's cell phone."The noise kept repeating.  It sounded like a recording of real pigs crying and being butchered.  Whether it was someone's ring tone or some video game or what - I have no idea.  But it was really, really bad. I got the Feta and Spinach omelet, which like I mentioned above, was a bunch of spinach wrapped in a very thin layer of pourable egg product.  It was supposed to have black olives as well, but they were just a few slices of canned olive sprinkled on top.  The feta was the cheap kind that's like cottage cheese.  Their potatoes are okay. I dunno, this was the kind of experience that will keep me away, probably for good.

37.description: My brother took me out for breakfast and I had some great strawberry pancakes! Pauline's so cute! The service was great, I really enjoyed it.

0.description: Brunch, lunch? They have both. The menu covers all taste buds and the decor is one to be photographed. If you are only meeting one person or even ten people, Pauline's can accommodate your need.Enjoy!

38.description: Stopped at this place since I always run by it . It's a local cozy spot, hidden by the metra that runs along the metra. I did like the patio seating option. Food menu was pretty standard to that of a diner ( golden nuggetish). Nothing extremely unique or mouth watering. I got one of the 2 veggie options. Definitely not a place for vegetarians. But nice for a friendly brunch.

51.description: Food good, service poor.My boyfriend and I went to Pauline's around 10:30 on a Saturday and had no problems snagging a table. They didn't appear especially busy, with no wait for even large parties. We waited a considerable amount of time before we were approached by our server, probably around 10 minutes. Our breakfast came out in a timely fashion, and the food was fine. Not the best, but certainly not the worst. He had the cowboy breakfast and enjoyed his steak. At no point in time did our server come back for the customary "check in". We had to flag her down to refill our waters, and then again for our check. We only wished we had gone to Golden Nugget where the portions are bigger, the service is quick, and the ladies anticipate your needs.

27.description: I've eaten here twice, and every time was quite pleasant. Love the farmer rustic decor. Service is good. Home fries are wonderful. You can't beat fresh squeezed OJ served in a mason jar. I've eaten the veggie omelette and eggs Benedict. Both were delicious and filling. They have some of the best prices in the city. I will keep coming back..

32.description: So good. Honestly I do not care for breakfast food and it was excellent! PS order the pancakes

54.description: comfortable, neighborhood- and kid-friendly atmosphere for Saturday Breakfast. amazing hot chocolate, fresh crab and perfect hollandaise on my eggs benedict and my friend's asparagus omelette was cooked just right. We'll be back!

48.description: If quantity was the benchmark, 5 would be the stars.I have eaten a grilled cheese with bacon here, that bordered on fantastic.A recent foray left me with a half ton of potatoes, a 5 egg omelet that looked and tasted flat as a cloth napkin.Service was extremely classy, but, ya can't eat service.I've visited here several times, as I do believe in supporting local business, coupled with the fact that they do give back to the neighborhood associations, but the food hasn't evolved or improved. I'll stick with the grilled cheese.

44.description: The smokehaus omelet is AMAZING! loaded with bacon! the freshly squeezed orange juice is great as well. Pauline's is a very cute, friendly diner.

24.description: I live around the block and would love to have a solid breakfast joint. I have tried and tried but this place always falls short. The service is slow and and I have yet to have a meal (I have been here about 4 times) where something doesn't come out wrong and need to be sent back. The food is not bad. It has always been somewhere between average and good but menu is very limited. When I leave this place I always wish I would have taken the extra time/money to eat someplace better on Clark.

7.description: Blueberry pancakes were delicious. Coffee was constantly refilled. It was busy but we got a table for two quickly.

49.description: I've been to Pauline's but have never actually eaten the food.  All I wanted was some kind of combo meal that came with eggs, bacon, hash browns, and toast that I was hoping to substitute (and pay extra) for a pancake.  They have no such thing on the menu.  Not even a variation of that combination.  I would have had to order everything a la carte and that would have added up to around $15 or $16 dollars.  Nope.  Not gonna do it.  I paid for the terribly bland coffee and went somewhere else. I'm sorry, but if you're only open for breakfast, then you should really have the most basic breakfast combo on your menu.

40.description: Pauline's is a perfectly nice little breakfast spot. The fact it's "off the beaten path" is a plus because it's away from the noise and congestion of Clark Street. My dining companion and I went on a Saturday morning and had no wait for a booth inside the restaurant, which is charmingly decorated with whimsical knickknacks, multicolored upholstered seats and checkered vinyl tablecloths. Based on some reviews I checked the latter for wet or dirty spots - nope, clean as a whistle. We were waited on and served promptly and got water and coffee refills. The papaya orange juice came in a mason-jar mug and was delicious. I didn't get the coffee but my friend remarked it was good. The French toast and strawberries I ordered was perfectly fine. Was it the most spectacular French toast I've ever tasted? No, it cost $7.25 and I wouldn't expect it to be. The Pauline's potatoes were also yummy. I can't speak for their eggs and bacon since I don't eat either. Except for some overzealous plate-clearing (when a diner still has a fork in their hand, it's safe to assume they are not finished with their meal), the service was efficient. Neither neglectful nor overly solicitous. The check was not brought out unacceptably early. You have to pay your bill up at the cash register. They have pictures of dogs available for adoption on the walls and water bowls for pooches outside: bonus points. In sum: It's not brunch at the Drake, it's a cute, cheery, no-frills neighborhood breakfast joint that I will definitely go back to.

53.description: There has been some updates and changes to Paulines with the unfortunate passing of the original owners.  The most noticeable is they accept credit and debit cards.The place is still popular and the patio is slammed during the warm weather.  at times service can be spotty  and a little unfriendly at times.  This has resulted in us ordering take out.  Food comes out fast and hot and the gentleman that takes the phone orders is very nice.

30.description: Pauline's is a little hidden gem...its kinda out of the way, next to a cemetary, and ironically across the street from one of my more adeventurous dates in which i'm not eager to run into again (im very lovable with addictable kissing skill yet I'm not first date boyfriend material...sorry princess). It's also only open from 7am to 3pm, which we all know is peak Mike K world domination hours. Luckily I had some free time before a rather big day/night and feeling pretty good about myself, which meant I needed to be put in my place by a friend who doesn't see life as all sunshine and lollipops, and especially my lollipop. This was the place, a small little cafe/diner dressed up in troll dolls with an atmosphere that said "hey, I was in the last Dixie Chicks video". I like the decor, love the fact that they have bottomless sugar, cream butter, and jellies, plus breakfast all day (or at least from 7-3) how can your beat that. And its cheap! A solid little place to disappear to if you wanna get away from the busy city life and expensive priced brunch outlets Andersonville gives you.

46.description: Great food n service everytime I visit chicago this is a must and yet another breakfast before I fly back Friday amIf ur near make sure u stop by and institution since 90"s,had the French toast dipped on vanilla n orange topped with fresh strawberries n fresh whipped cream the best I've tasted ,fresh squeezed oj Canadian bacon ,everything is great here

1.description: Overall: Great atmosphere, but just decent food and service. Nothing to write home about.The good: The atmosphere was very interesting and fun. Lots of stuff going on throughout the restaurant. The outdoor seating looks plentiful and nice. The prices are pretty reasonable. Potatoes were good.The bad: The food is just very average. The veggie omelet was on the colder side and just not great. The service, while friendly, was slow.Atmosphere: 9/10Service: 7/10Food: 7/10

55.description: Classic American breakfast items can be found here, but there are also some gems that stick out and make coming here more than once worth it every time.Pumpkin pancakes! The best! Omelets are huge and delicious, potatoes are pretty good, and the biscuits and gravy were a little disappointing as far as the flavors and textures go. Just don't miss out on the pancakes!

9.description: The diner is cute. BUT it's not an excuse to serve canned biscuits with a country bfast. Make your own! The layered biscuits get soggy and are impossible to eat. We were ignored for a long time multiple times and no one asked how our meal was/tasted. Not a fan.

26.description: I love it when I walk into a place and the nostalgia of a different time in history just hits you. This is the perfect place to go and feel like you're sitting in a cute 1950's diner. The way it's set up and decorated is enough to convert me into a regular customer. Honestly, I've had better breakfast food elsewhere for the price. But at Pauline's it has a great home cooked taste, and I'll take the comfort of that experience over any industrially made food any day. And I haven't tried much on the menu, so it's not entirely enough to judge the food just yet. Can't wait to go back for more.

25.description: Friends took me to Pauline's for Sunday brunch. I definitely enjoyed the place.  The décor is kitschy, but didn't bother me.  Service was friendly and helpful.  I had the eggs and pancakes, which was plenty of food, but we also shared bacon.  The regular portions for omelets and such are huge (5 eggs), which seems excessive to me.  So I was glad my meal was just 3 eggs and 2 pancakes.  Food was good.  They have a nice patio to sit in if the weather cooperates.  Overall, enjoyed Pauline's.

12.description: This where I'd bring my grandmother from central Illinois if she could visit. A totally different kind of brunch/lunch place than what I'm used to in Andersonville.

59.description: Haven't been in a while- but had breakfast on the patio today- had our two dogs in tow- the staff brought a bowl of water over for the dogs and a treat for them..off to a great start.Then coffee right away- we had an omelet and multi gran pancakes both items were A+ and the service was top notch- Will be back again soon, sorry it's been over a year since I was here..

21.description: Friendly vibe, super attentive waitstaff and the food comes out before you know it. Their daily specials always grab me and the food never disappoints. Their blackberry pancakes are one of my favorites.

17.description: I love it when I walk into a place and the nostalgia of a different time in history just hits you. This is the perfect place to go and feel like you're sitting in a cute 1950's diner. The way it's set up and decorated is enough to convert me into a regular customer. Honestly, I've had better breakfast food elsewhere for the price. But at Pauline's it has a great home cooked taste, and I'll take the comfort of that experience over any industrially made food any day. And I haven't tried much on the menu, so it's not entirely enough to judge the food just yet. Can't wait to go back for more.

10.description: Had a basic breakfast before heading to the airport. Food was good, good prices and service was great.

5.description: If you are given the option of sitting inside or outside, I would definitely sit outside. Although the interior feels like you are sitting in an old diner, the outside is great especially during a nice summers day. I enjoyed seeing the train go by as well as enjoying the local air and scenery. If you check into Yelp, you can get $2 off your bill of $15 or more. They have offerings for both breakfast and lunch, but had opted to eat lunch instead. I am a fan of their ham and bean soup. Also, I had their house salad which was a good sized portion. In addition, my friend's breakfast dishes look quite appetizing as they were completely devoured at the end of our meal.During our meal, the owners of this place decided to bring out their parrots for display. If you want an advance peek of these birds, someone else had posted pictures on their Yelp page.

3.description: We go to Pauline's often since it's the closest breakfast place near us. Let me break it down for you:1. Atmosphere: Pauline's has a very 50's, kitschy, diner-type feel to it. In my opinion, it is the most endearing quality about this place. It even comes with its very own regular who seems to be there almost everyday, sitting outside if the weather is nice, with his parrots. It's a fun place to bring visitors from out-of-town because they always seem to be taken by this place, partly due to the cuteness factor and partly because it doesn't seem like your typical tourist destination. I think it makes them feel like they are eating at a hole-in-the-wall, although I'm pretty sure the secret has been out for quite some time now...2. Food: Considering they are open until 3pm, they also have a lunch menu, but I haven't been impressed with anything on it. If you're going here, I would stick to breakfast.  The fresh squeezed juices are nice. The pancakes and french toast are both very good. The omelettes are huge, but just okay, in my opinion. They come with a side of potatoes which are very good. Try them with the spicy ketchup! 3. Value: I'm not really sure how I feel about the prices. The portions are quite large, but I feel like this is the kind of place that you'd expect to be able to get cheap, standard breakfast fare and it's definitely not cheap. The coffee is bottomless, but it's nothing to write home about. Just your standard run-of-the-mill diner coffee, but that's all I can really ask for from a place like this.

35.description: Any omelet is sooooo good, Pauline potatoes are to die for.

19.description: Service was fast, friendly and there's outdoor seating in nice weather.  The portion sizes were a good size. The hash browns very good ! Eggs were done just like I asked and bacon cooked perfectly. The orange juice came in a huge ball jar with handle with a slice of orange on the rim. Nice touch. The decor is really cute with all sorts of little knick knacks.  You really feel like your in a little out of the way place and not in Chicago.

28.description: The breakfast was great, simple and fresh. The only thing that really bugged me was the bug catchers. The entire time I couldn't stop thinking of them, little disturbing, but nonetheless it wasn't bad, the bug thing is the only thing that would keep me from going back.

45.description: I had the egg and pancake special and it was pretty good. The portions were big for the cost.
