There weren't many options to choose from and being a person having  only chicken, I was stuck only with only a couple. Food was alright. Being located on the Clark St. - the food quality needs to improve much. I would not visit here again but wouldn't advise against as well. The food did not suit to my tastes.

31.description: Really wanted to like this place but the food is just...I'm sorry I can't eat it. Ordered delivery and the kids chicken tender ....so over fried and burnt.

34.description: New to the Area and gave this place a try, was not disappointed. Started with a saganaki, which is really hard to mess up and they didn't. Stuffed banana peppers also were good. On to the entree, had to try the Adriatic chicken. Plate presentation was an A. The chicken was cooked with just the right amount of crispness and lasted on my plate about 5 minutes. My wife had the kebab and she didn't want to finish them, so she wrapped them for her next lunch. Very flavorful.  Tiramisu is on the more creamy side, not so much rum as Italian restaurants.  Tried the crepes too for desert and those were a meal in itself. Overall a great experience and reasonable

16.description: Really wanted to like this place but the food is just...I'm sorry I can't eat it. Ordered delivery and the kids chicken tender ....so over fried and burnt.

13.description: This place is amazing! They have closed their patio, and it is warm and cozy!!!The have delicioussss crepes, sandwiches and cocktails!!! Friendly and fast service! I love it!

11.description: Great food great atmosphere inside and on the beautiful patio. Interesting mix of dishes. I shared the seafood paella with pesto with a friend. AMAZING. Service was a little inattentive on the patio but it's so nice that we didn't mind as much. Get the saganaki for a good flaming time. My friends and I will be back to see the fish and turtles in the pond. Tiramisu was a great way to top it all off.

39.description: I visited this place with a group of friends. Our waiter was nice and let us know that freshly baked bread would arrive at our table shortly. We had heard great things about this place, so we were all very excited. We waited a few minutes and there was no bread. Our waiter took our order. Fifteen minutes later, no bread and our entrees arrived. Three of the four entrees were correct. My friend was offered two choices the wrong meal at 50% discount or wait ten minutes for the correct meal. He chose to wait and the meat came back undercooked. We asked about the bread and were told it would only be one minute longer. When the bread arrived, it was room temperature.When we received the bill, we found that we were charged for the wrong items. The food was fine and the service was poor. This place is overrated. I would tell anyone who I would call a friend to pass on this place, the neighborhood has plenty of better places to offer.

37.description: We were headed to Andies and decided to try Adriatic.  We are so happy we did!  The place has 4 different dining areas to enjoy.  Outdoor, enclosed patio, grotto and inside.  Shani, our server recommended the cold sampler plate w garlic and spicy dips.  She also suggested the sea scallops which were paired w butternut squash, spinach and risotto.  My mouth has been treated.  Take a chance and give it a try.

0.description: STILL a solid little cafe in Andersonville. I've now hosted three birthday parties here, and it's always a blast. The staff is universally fun, friendly and efficient. The food is fantastic, fresh and delicious. The drinks . . . .whoa, that sangria is a delicious siren.For breakfast, the Lamb Benedict is savory goodness with a rich Hollandaise sauce. Complemented with an incredible Bloody Mary.The turtle and Koi pond in the back gets better and better with age. I love the streaming foreign music station playing.What could be improved? Cleanliness. This place could do with a deep clean, esp. the cushions on the patio.And the beer list. It's awful. 4 or 5 domestic beers and Stella? Weak. The wines are great, but the beer list could do with an update.That said, I'll still happily return here again and again.

38.description: This Balkan restaurant has had a turnaround and became more Americanized. The menu has both European and American items. I had the margarita pizza, and would personally not recommend it. It's more of a flatbread...This restaurant has a very cute patio with a waterfall. They have a nice, friendly service, and the spot is great for groups. It's very spacious. The highlight of the night-the crepes!! Very delicious!!! Worth the visit!

51.description: The service was great, our server Adriana was bee nice, informative and attentive, unfortunately that was about it. The free bread may as well be used to clean the tables, chicken was small, and the check-in promotion that this site is still running as of 7/17/12. Overall, nice place with a lot of potential but needs to work on the atmosphere!

27.description: I had a great Groupon Deal for the Adriatic Cafe, and I decided touse it  today, hey, the sun was shining, birds were chirping, etc..Upon entering I found an area with some booths and a great lookingbar, but, where I wanted to be seated was out by the garden, sothat's where I headed!I'm trying to think of the right words to express the feeling of beingseated right next to this lovely garden area, I mean, there was a pondwith a waterfall and some lovely fish, I even made friends with a coupleof turtles swimming in the pond.And, I felt so at peace and contented, sitting on this lovely patio area,the sun was shining through, breathtaking!I had the greatest server,Shani J, and she was so upbeat and friendly,what a gem she was/is!I looked at the menu but pretty much knew that I was going to order theSalmon with the grilled asparagus and mashed potatoes..Smartest decision I made today, seriously folks, the Adriatic Cafe shouldconsider making this a signature dish, best salmon entree ever!And okay, when you check in on Yelp you are entitled to a free dessert,so do yourself a favor and order the zesty orange creme' brulee', incredible!They have a full bar available as well if you choose to indulge in somealcoholic libations!Honestly, I will definitely return to the Adriatic Cafe, Groupon Deal or Not!Yes, they are that good!During the week they are open from 3pm-9pm.Weekends I believe they open at 11am..Daily Specials too, check with your server!So, to the folks at the Adriatic Cafe I say Thank You for a great dining experience.Andersonville is so lucky to have you...

32.description: Dude. Love love love. Come in to the greenhouse patio and you'll know what I mean. Great space with a beautiful garden with a koi pond and a large waterfall. Enjoy the tranquility of the plants and water falling in the background. Then introduce the drinks. Great cocktails and beer from the Middle East. Start the food with some bacon wrapped dates. Then follow up with a Greek salad with feta. For the entree, u have to have the house specialty...Adriatic chicken. A large chicken breast wrapped in crispy bacon and stuffed with cheese and prosciutto. It's delicious and really for 2 people. We also ordered the spagetti with meatballs for my son and he loved. To end, we split the fruit and ice cream crepe and molten lava cake paired with some Turkish coffee. What a great meal. Def coming back!

54.description: I recently moved to the neighborhood, and last night was my second time visiting. The first experience was stellar. My roommate and I sat outside and sipped wine and tried one of everything. The service was amazing, attentive, and our waiter was adorable and sweet. Last night we decided to go back after a month of being good and cooking our own meals. We had enough and wanted to be waited on! We got there fairly early for the Chicago dinner crowd. The restaurant was empty at 6pm on a Thursday. I was nervous. We sat down and had the same excellent server we had the month before. We ordered a couple of appetizers and drinks to start. Always get the Saganaki. Always. There's nothing that can go wrong. You might lose an eyebrow, but it's still delicious. It's flaming cheese, after all. We ordered our entrees and continued munching on bacon wrapped dates (SO YUM) and the cheese. I should mention the bread basket was fresh and warm and awesome as well. Here's where it got a little sticky. I ordered Lamb Kebobs, which come over rice with a side salad. I ordered Lamb kebobs, NO rice, double salad. I received STEAK kebobs over rice and a double salad. I didn't say anything, or send it back, because it wasn't like it was bad. The steak was good (I really wanted lamb though!), and I didn't want them to throw it away. I ate the steak, left the rice...and the salad was awesome. It's cucumbers and peppers in a light vinegary sauce. I had two glasses of Cab with the meal and felt great afterwards. For someone to get my order so wrong when we were the only people in the place was kind of annoying. But he was friendly and amazing otherwise. I'm sure my roommate and I will go back often, as we live just around the corner, but I'll be way more clear when I order my entree, especially if there are special instructions. Also, FLAMING CHEESE! OOPAA!

48.description: The food itself, I would give 3 stars. My wife's ordered ribs; decent smoked ribs at an excellent price, although quite chewy. My dish, some sort of euro sausage, appeared prefrozen & had the looks of McDonalds chicken nuggets on the inside. It was all 'okay'.The atmosphere, we would give 1 star. Absolutely awkward. Huge restaurant with no one inside. Slow service for only two people. Really bad 2000s lite rock radio playing. Just a pitiful. We won't be going back.

44.description: good food, great atmosphere, fabulous service the Adriatic Chicken was tasty... and the Tiramisu is the best I've ever had.

24.description: Great saganki, kabobs, rice and dessert, and they have a generous pour for a glass of wine :)  The hummus was good but a bit on the salty side for my taste --- otherwise this would be a 5 star review.  Friendly, good service, too.  Will definitely go to Adriatic again.

7.description: Dude. Love love love. Come in to the greenhouse patio and you'll know what I mean. Great space with a beautiful garden with a koi pond and a large waterfall. Enjoy the tranquility of the plants and water falling in the background. Then introduce the drinks. Great cocktails and beer from the Middle East. Start the food with some bacon wrapped dates. Then follow up with a Greek salad with feta. For the entree, u have to have the house specialty...Adriatic chicken. A large chicken breast wrapped in crispy bacon and stuffed with cheese and prosciutto. It's delicious and really for 2 people. We also ordered the spagetti with meatballs for my son and he loved. To end, we split the fruit and ice cream crepe and molten lava cake paired with some Turkish coffee. What a great meal. Def coming back!

49.description: Extremely bland, heavy, greasy tasteless food. The only upside was the price!

40.description: Great food! Beautiful outdoor seating! Fantastic service!I liked their Kebaps and spicy seafood pasta!

53.description: This place is EXCELLENT!!!!! Fast and precise wait staff, laid back atmosphere... relaxing.  The best martini's and dish presentation was fabulous. We went here for Thanksgiving and enjoyed pumpkin soup, martini's, rib with sweet potatoes & cranberry... they even gave us a free pecan pie!  The dishes are flavorful, light and portions are just enough.  We will definitely recommend this place and will be back.  It is one of Clark Street's best kept secrets.

30.description: I had been driving past the Adriatic Cafe for years, and finally decided to give it a try last night.  Although the service was a bit relaxed (slow), the waiter was nice.  It just seemed like they were understaffed.  I think they could use a busboy for clearing tables and filling waters and bringing out bread and such.  Anyway, we weren't in a big hurry and were enjoying the conversation around the table, but if we had been on a schedule, I think I might have been a little irritated.  The food, drinks and dessert were really good, and I loved the patio.  We sat near the koi pond and fireplace.  It reminded us of a place we ate at in Kotor Montenegro.  My husband chatted briefly with the owner, and it turns out he IS from Kotor Montenegro.  Anyway, we had a very nice experience here, but if the owner is reading this my sincere suggestion would be to step up the service a notch.  You've got a great place!  We'll be back.

46.description: Great food! I had the veggie plate and it was very tasty and enough for two. I was suggested a beer - Lav - it waste perfect

1.description: As many people commented, the patio is beautiful and cozy. we enjoyed the ambience. We ordered grilled seafood mix (shrimp and squid), pork chop, Adriatic paellea.  Food: Woohoo! Love it!Service: GreatAmbience: Wolhoo! Love it!Price: FairOur dining experience at Adriatic cafe was better than we expected. We will go back again.

55.description: Nice experience.  The outdoor patio is an idyllic city-spot to dine on a pleasant evening.  Just enough seclusion from Clark Street, particularly if you sit in back towards the pond, but close enough to keep up on people watching if you are so inclined. The service is top-notch, guys could not be nicer; one can guess the staff spend time together partying following service (and probably during, although behind the scenes).  Most accommodating of younger children, offering the obligatory kids-fun-menu + crayons. Impressed when they took the extra step to offer turtle food to my daughter to feed those floating in the pond (although the fish are greedily aggressive and swarm before the turtles can react).Hummus and feta cheese were a highlight, the pita bread is more than adequate, the octopus salad falls short (bland and overcooked).  Tried a pizza and it was more doughy than imagined.  Saganaki was fun for all, although enough people seem to order it; skip the grease, still plenty of 'Opas' to peak your interest at surrounding tables.

9.description: Huge fan of Adriatic Cafe.   My fiance and I had strolled past this restaurant a number of times, as it is super close to home.  The outdoor patio caught my eye in particular. It was obvious that immense care was taken in designing and maintaining the greenery outside.  The atmosphere is extremely laid back and you almost forget you are in a relatively busy neighborhood.  If you have the chance to come to Adriatic, I would advise coming on a warm afternoon to enjoy all the two patios have to offer.  The plant life is truly beautiful.We were lucky enough to be seated just next to their gorgeous koi pond and tropical plant garden complete with trickling waterfalls and song bird to serenade us periodically as we ate and drank.To start my fiance ordered the calamari (which he raved about), and I the spinach gnocchi.  I didn't know what to expect with this appetizer, but upon trying did not regret my order.  It was amazing! Each dish was authentically eastern Mediterranean.  The flavors were spectacular. Not a bite was left of either starter.Our entrees were the chicken kabobs, and scallops.  If I could give the scallops 10 stars, I would. My kabobs were slightly overcooked, but I am assuming with the quality of the rest of the food that it may have just been an off moment.  The flavor was on point.  We brought our 11 month old son with us and he enjoyed eating off of our plates the entire meal.  I'll add that this restaurant was very family friendly, at least for our experience on a Sunday afternoon.  We spoke with the owner/master gardener for a while and he is very kind.    We will be regulars here and I look forward to exploring more of their menu!

26.description: The restaurant has a fantastic outdoor space which is beautiful in the summer but that's pretty much where the "awesomeness" stops. The food is barely average and wasn't exciting or fresh. Service was good but the food brings them down in my opinion. Not a bad place by any means but I will not be going back or recommending it to anyone.

25.description: This place is as close to perfect as you can get. When I say perfect, its not in the decadent, 5 star restaurant sense. Its in the, "laid back, welcoming, tranquil, i-could-sit-here-all-day" sense.They offer a beautiful contrast of chic, modern, indoor dining and natural, serene, outdoor dining. My mom and I sat outside in big swivel chairs. We were so comfortable as we were shielded from the sun, but could feel the nice breeze. We also had a stellar view of the rainforest-ish ecosystem they had set up outside. It was full of moss, fish, waterfalls, turtles, plants of all kinds, and birds. It was so nice to eat and enjoy the sound of nature!My mom had the fried artichokes with a white bean puree and I had a greek salad. Both of these choices blew us away with the freshness and flavoring! We ended up sitting there for almost 2 hours just enjoying the environment and the calmness of it all. I highly suggest eating (or drinking, they have a full bar) here. Its like a little getaway!

12.description: This Balkan restaurant has had a turnaround and became more Americanized. The menu has both European and American items. I had the margarita pizza, and would personally not recommend it. It's more of a flatbread...This restaurant has a very cute patio with a waterfall. They have a nice, friendly service, and the spot is great for groups. It's very spacious. The highlight of the night-the crepes!! Very delicious!!! Worth the visit!

59.description: We chose Adriatic because we wanted al fresco dining but honestly we didn't have high expectations. But what a nice surprise. The food was excellent and a good value, and service was friendly (but they have a relaxed pace). They have an interesting wine list but limited beer choices. Definitely worth a return trip.

21.description: Great food! I had the shnitzel entree (can't remember how to spell the first part of the name, it's very long and has two J's) -- it was one of the best things I've ate in a long time -- My friend Yanan had a seafood pasta with shrimp, salmon, clams & mussels, which was very good & Gonz had the lamb chops - his dish was the least favorable for the price. Only five lamb chops, heavily seasoned and over cooked. Our waiter was great though, no complaints there. The atmosphere is beautiful - we sat right next to the koi fish pond. Overall it was a good experience!

17.description: This place is worth a try.  The wait staff is very nice.  The seafood is good.  It is especially nice in the summer in their outdoor area where they have a fish pond.

10.description: I agree with Kabir S, the patio is sadly where any interesting aspects about this place end. Unfortunately, that's the lone good aspect, about a restaurant that's disappointing.I ordered one of the schnitzel entrees on their menu, and while that was okay, the food I tried from others eating with me was worse. The service from the server we had was okay, but nothing special. Ditto with the bread, we got before our meal.Seriously, too many other great places one can eat at nearby(and despite the loss of Edgewater Lounge), so no need for me to (more than likely) ever come back here.

5.description: I had a great Groupon Deal for the Adriatic Cafe, and I decided touse it  today, hey, the sun was shining, birds were chirping, etc..Upon entering I found an area with some booths and a great lookingbar, but, where I wanted to be seated was out by the garden, sothat's where I headed!I'm trying to think of the right words to express the feeling of beingseated right next to this lovely garden area, I mean, there was a pondwith a waterfall and some lovely fish, I even made friends with a coupleof turtles swimming in the pond.And, I felt so at peace and contented, sitting on this lovely patio area,the sun was shining through, breathtaking!I had the greatest server,Shani J, and she was so upbeat and friendly,what a gem she was/is!I looked at the menu but pretty much knew that I was going to order theSalmon with the grilled asparagus and mashed potatoes..Smartest decision I made today, seriously folks, the Adriatic Cafe shouldconsider making this a signature dish, best salmon entree ever!And okay, when you check in on Yelp you are entitled to a free dessert,so do yourself a favor and order the zesty orange creme' brulee', incredible!They have a full bar available as well if you choose to indulge in somealcoholic libations!Honestly, I will definitely return to the Adriatic Cafe, Groupon Deal or Not!Yes, they are that good!During the week they are open from 3pm-9pm.Weekends I believe they open at 11am..Daily Specials too, check with your server!So, to the folks at the Adriatic Cafe I say Thank You for a great dining experience.Andersonville is so lucky to have you...

3.description: This place is as close to perfect as you can get. When I say perfect, its not in the decadent, 5 star restaurant sense. Its in the, "laid back, welcoming, tranquil, i-could-sit-here-all-day" sense.They offer a beautiful contrast of chic, modern, indoor dining and natural, serene, outdoor dining. My mom and I sat outside in big swivel chairs. We were so comfortable as we were shielded from the sun, but could feel the nice breeze. We also had a stellar view of the rainforest-ish ecosystem they had set up outside. It was full of moss, fish, waterfalls, turtles, plants of all kinds, and birds. It was so nice to eat and enjoy the sound of nature!My mom had the fried artichokes with a white bean puree and I had a greek salad. Both of these choices blew us away with the freshness and flavoring! We ended up sitting there for almost 2 hours just enjoying the environment and the calmness of it all. I highly suggest eating (or drinking, they have a full bar) here. Its like a little getaway!

35.description: I really enjoy eating on the outdoor patio and the food is great! I really suggest trying  there hummus.

19.description: Food was delicious, but service really brought this one down. Service very inattentive; it appeared like only one woman was working the write restaurant. Food took a while to come, but arrived hot. The outdoor patio was beautiful and dog friendly which was a plus. We had the chicken picatta, chicken kabob (a little dry, but tsatsiki sauce helped), tiramisu, and paella. All we're good and I would happily eat again. They split the checks four ways, too!

28.description: Absolutely the best lamb chops in town; juicy and tender. The flaming cheese is excellent and the server attentive but not pushy. Highly recommend this place.

45.description: We sat outside in the enclosed area that was so poorly lit it was hard to see all of the mosquitos buzzing around. The service was good, but all of the entrees were bland and cold. Wont be going back soon.

33.description: Love this place ! it's a good looking place whether you sit inside or outside. there's nice outdoor seating and a large beautiful coy pond with waterfall and turtles too. the drinks and the food are always really good. the dishes are interesting and nicely adorned on the plate. the wait staff are always accommodating and freindly. there is a small lot in back for parking and a back door you can enter from. I pray they get busier cause I want them to stay in our neighborhood.

43.description: Very good food, great scene, nice staff! This place is very easy to miss, but don't let its outdoor appearance fool you! If they improved the outside look I know they will be in much more business.

2.description: This is absolutely one of my favorite restaurant in Chicago! Atmosphere is great with all the greens surrounding you. Service is attentive - a tall gentleman is always there for our late lunch appearances. Fantastic flavors in all of the dishes that we have tried so far. They definitely have a chef who knows what he is doing! Some of my favorite dishes: Chicken Picatta (melt in your mouth combination of flavors)Spinach Gnocchi (their tomato sauce is to die for)Bottom line, the flavors that this restaurant was able to produce can rival any one star Michelin restaurant! Left a memorable impression on my palate and I can't wait to return for my 4th time there.PS. I actually quite like the fact that it's usually empty, not alot of traffic in. Makes me feel like I discovered a secret garden that I can truly enjoy deliciously prepared food. But of course, I wouldn't want it to go out of business either so what are you waiting for, come and try this place out!

18.description: I've been excited to try this restaurant since I moved to Andersonville a couple of years back. I saw the lovely patio a lot driving or walking by, so I decided to purchase the Gropuon that was available a couple of weeks back. We went to brunch on a Sunday early afternoon, and when we arrived we were one of two tables in the place. This was a bit worrisome but more people did start to arrive over our stay. We sat on the patio which was very nice.The service was a bit strange and very slow for how empty the place was. I noticed a woman a couple of tables away only order a beer and it didn't come out for 15 minutes. It took a long time to receive water, order appetizers, and order our food. They never even gave us a drink menu, which they did give to everyone else (and I saw a lot of yummy looking sangria and bloody marys heading out to other tables). We ordered the cold spread sampler with the goat cheese pesto, urnebes, and hummus. If the meal had stopped there it would have been a much better experience. The hummus is actually one of the best I have had at Mediterranean style eateries. It has a lot more flavor than the traditional that seems to be only flavored with olive oil. The goat cheese pesto dip was also great, however I am wondering if it was made in-house. The urnebes is a cheese mixed with spices (it is orange in color) and definitely spicy but really yummy. Also could have definitely not been homemade but I'm not sure.Once again our appetizer as well as main dishes took a very long time (entrees over 45 minutes) to come out. Which was really strange to me considering, once again, there were hardly any other people in the place, and what we ordered cooks very quickly. I had the breakfast burrito off of the brunch menu, which is served with a pineapple relish and what were advertised as house potatoes. Generally speaking the burrito was OK, typical with eggs and guac. However the guac was clearly brown and had been sitting since at least the day before. The burrito also includes pork which was dry and chewy, and really had no flavor unless combined with the guac or cheese. The pineapple relish was OK alone but with the rest of the dish it just didn't fit. The house potatoes were extremely greasy and not even hot. In fact not much of my dish was hot, bringing me back to the point that it took 45 minutes to serve...Anyhow my boyfriend got the Balkan Sandwich which was just unfortunate and strange. I'm not familiar with Balkan cuisine so maybe it is just a cultural thing but the sandwich was cold and stuffed with TONS of raw mushrooms. He likes mushrooms, but it was weird that they were not cooked and there were just way too many. There was also just way too much ajvar on the sandwich. He really did not care for it. The sandwich comes with fries, which were very good but clearly not house-made and came from a freezer bag. I think they actually may have been the same fries that Aldi sells in the freezer. Not that I don't like these fries, I just think that making your own french fries is so easy like why not do it? So once again, just to emphasize that eggs and a cold sandwich took over 45 minutes to come out of the kitchen. I am not sure what they were doing back there but it certainly was not cooking.Overall I'm glad that we had the Groupon so it was a pretty cheap experience. Unfortunately I wouldn't recommend this place to a friend and I doubt we will ever go back.

41.description: The Adriatic Cafe is one of the best and most underrated restaurants on Chicago's North Side, The restaurant has a new menu that includes dishes from Italy, Yugoslavia and Greece. I took a dinner party there recently and everybody raved about the food. The best dishes are the Lamb Shank (with plum preserves and watercress), the Grilled Salmon, the Spicy Seafood (shrimp and salmon over pasta), and the Adriatic Paella. They have a very appealing outdoor patio, and a nice ambiance inside as well, with lots of exposed brick and dark wood and white table cloths. Prices are moderate and quite reasonable for the quality of the fare.

52.description: Outstanding dining experience!      Four of us family members went there for Thanksgiving Dinner and were bowled over by the quality of the food - the appetizers (wrapped pepper jack dates, shrimp scampi), the savory pumpkin soup, salads (radicchio cranberry and goat cheese; pear arugula and sweet potato; feta, radicchio, spinach and toasted pecan), the main course (juicy turkey or super-tender short ribs), sides (dill butternut squash rice, braised sweet potato), and the dessert (pecan pie made per our server's grandma's recipe - mmmm yum!). Everything was fresh and prepared to perfection. The wine recommendations were spot-on excellent, and the end-of-meal coffee was delicious. The service from our waiter Adam was the very best - personal, friendly and attentive - and the courses were perfectly paced.     I've seen the other 5-five-star reviews of Adriatic Cafe, and am delighted to add to that list. I encourage anyone who may have visited the restaurant a year or two ago to now come back and relish the same superior dining experience as we just enjoyed.  This restaurant is serving seriously good food!     Cheers and virtual hugs to the owner, cooks, servers and support staff for doing their professional and personal best.

50.description: We just had my son's classroom holiday party at Adriatic and I had to write a review. My whole experience at Adriatic was perfect from start to finish! Service was amazing, Shaniqua server went above and beyond to serve all of the guests, food was delicious, and holiday decor and atmosphere was wonderful! There were about 30 of us and everyone said the food was great. I must mentioned that i was so impressed with the owner Tanja when she offered to help me with wrapping up gifts for children before everyone arrived - THANK YOU! I also visit Adriatic on regular basis with my two sons right after I pick them up from Peirce school. My favorite meal for lunch or dinner is the urnebes appetizer, calamari, and sea scallops. My two sons love their nutella-plazma crepes! If you are looking for a place that can host any size group and offer a wonderful service and delicious food, I highly recommend Adriatic Cafe.

4.description: My boyfriend and I came here for brunch on Sunday and took the advice of all who talked about how gorgeous the patio is. We were lucky and got seated right next to the little man-made pond/waterfall area. Soon we realized we actually weren't so lucky at all. Although this is a beautiful little area to look at, it's also apparently a kid magnet. It was not at all a good experience to have children yelling to their parents across the patio to come look at the fish. This literally happened about a dozen times while we were there. And I mean YELLING. Does anyone ever, you know, like, umm..., SUPERVISE THEIR CHILDREN?! So, beware, the beauty might not pay off if you still have your hearing. One more thing about this little area is that it's kind of a mess. Obviously someone maintains this little beauty, but they also leave all of their crap out when they're done. So it kind of looks like you're dining at your messy grandmother's backyard. Is it that hard to clean up after you're done?Alas, we mostly came here for the food, which was pretty good. The goat cheese pesto appetizer was plentiful, but nothing to rave about. It was just good. I can get the same cheese at Mariano's, so I wasn't too blown away. We also got the salmon benedict and the gypsy plate. The benedict was a little bit too smothered in sauce, which overpowered the dish. A slightly lighter taste would've been better. The gypsy plate was simple and delicious. The best part of both dishes was probably the potatoes.

6.description: Great service! Loved our food! Look forward to returning and trying out the beautiful patio!

22.description: Loved this place. Relaxing and serene, the outdoor oasis is always to be taken advantage of, even if you go like I did on a day when it was 67 degrees and raining.I decided to go because the plants always caught my eye, then I saw a Groupon and knew I was MEANT to go. They were super busy with a party when I walked in but I was still greeted right away. Even though the weather was icky I asked to be seated outside because I thought the oasis was completely enclosed. It was not, but still very covered and most of the wind was blocked so I was fine in my fleece jacket. I received prompt and upbeat service from Shaniqua (sp?). I had spinach gnocchi as an appetizer and chicken kabob for dinner finished with the chocolate lava cake for dessert. Service was fast and the food was hot and FLA.VOR.FUL! I wiggled in my seat and hummed and savored. My hot tea was kept refilled and I was even given an extra bag. I took pics of the appetizer and entree, but was so excited when the cute lil lava cake came out I forgot!A few people from the party came out to smoke during the beginning of my meal, so I asked if it was normally allowed. Shaniqua advised no, that there was a different area they should be in. While I was away from the table in the restroom, she noticed and let them know they were in the wrong area and even apologized to me for the inconvenience. So sweet! And while I was eating an older gentleman (maybe the owner) offered me a blanket! How's that for care and concern?!Based on this visit I will DEFINITELY become a regular.

15.description: Great food! I had the shnitzel entree (can't remember how to spell the first part of the name, it's very long and has two J's) -- it was one of the best things I've ate in a long time -- My friend Yanan had a seafood pasta with shrimp, salmon, clams & mussels, which was very good & Gonz had the lamb chops - his dish was the least favorable for the price. Only five lamb chops, heavily seasoned and over cooked. Our waiter was great though, no complaints there. The atmosphere is beautiful - we sat right next to the koi fish pond. Overall it was a good experience!

57.description: The Adriatic Cafe is a new discovery for us -- so this is a one visit, first visit review.Main point: we'll be back for the large, excellent entres.I had their version of a pina colada -- very good, nice balance of flavors.  Fran had their cocktail with ginger liqueur, lemonade, and champagne (they left out the pear vodka at her request) -- that was wonderful, just strong enough for her.We took the Yelp reviews recommendation on gnocchi -- excellent.  The portabella   mushroom with feta cheese and peanuts was ok but not great, and didn't justify the price. An odd note was the bread and olive oil, brought immediately to the table when we sat down. The bread was square, separated rolls -- and was not fresh.  If there's anyplace that should have good, fresh bread, this is where you'd expect to find it. (Especially as the two other Serbian restaurants we've visited in the area have excellent home-baked bread).But the entres were absolutely wonderful.  Fran's lamb chops were beautifully presented, nicely seasoned, and beautifully presented.  My paella was large. with shrimp, mussels, calimari on top and under the rice as well. Each of us took home enough for another meal.  Fran asked for Turkish coffee -- and got a full 6 oz cup of it. My request for a regular coffee yielded a cup of very strong, very dark, very good stuff.For dessert, Fran loved the pineapple with caramalized sugar and ice cream; my Serbian brownie had an interesting texture, but is more like a cake than a brownie and needed ice cream on it.  They did not have their cake of the day, which the waiter said was a favorite.For the food, my rating from this visit would be more like 3.5 stars -- but their beautiful outdoor seating area, private parking lot(!), and excellent service  justify the full 4 stars.

20.description: I agree with Kabir S, the patio is sadly where any interesting aspects about this place end. Unfortunately, that's the lone good aspect, about a restaurant that's disappointing.I ordered one of the schnitzel entrees on their menu, and while that was okay, the food I tried from others eating with me was worse. The service from the server we had was okay, but nothing special. Ditto with the bread, we got before our meal.Seriously, too many other great places one can eat at nearby(and despite the loss of Edgewater Lounge), so no need for me to (more than likely) ever come back here.

36.description: This place is super good. Friendly staff and inventive menu. My only criticism would be that the lamb was oversalted, but everything else was great. Really like the serene patio with the koi pond and turtles. Will go again!

14.description: Excellent first date spot. I've never been disappointed with the menu.

58.description: Really cute and cool store of curiosities and "I remember that"s.  Great for looking around, finding odd stuff to ogle, and make your home more interesting.

56.description: ....Oddities, definitely.I could probably spend an hour looking at stuff. It's a cabinet of curiosities.Cow hoof made into drinking bottle. Armadillo shell. Medical charts, taxidermy animals everywhere. I want the small fox in the window.I will have to come back again.

29.description: This place is fabulous! Lots of creepy toys, vintage dental and medical supplies/tools, taxidermy, found photos, and so much more! The prices were mostly fair in comparison to some of the other oddities/antique shops that I've been to. Bought my husband a super adorable beaver skull for his birthday for $30! I will definitely be back!

42.description: I read too much Stephen King, and have to admit that while I was wildly curious about this tiny shop with its absurd displays in the windows, I was too scared to go in. It just looks like Needful Things. A stalwart friend, and a sign saying the shop had been on television (how evil can something be if it's on television? uh, never mind . . . ), convinced me to go through the door, and I am so very happy they did. I love this place. I love it. I left with some weird clock things and a few wonderful old photos, and I feel like any time I am at a loss for a gift, this is going to be my go-to. Everything is so odd and interesting. I thought the prices were very reasonable, but I'm not a bargain hunter outside of the city's confines, and I always expect prices in the city to be higher than at these objects' place of origin. I mean, someone had to go and find them, buy them, and bring them here, right? Why shouldn't they be more expensive than if you traveled yourself for miles and spent hours sifting through someone's attic or garage? I have my eye on a couple other things. I hope they're still there when I get back.

23.description: I could basically just echo what many of the other positive reviews point out, but instead I want to thank the owners of this little shop for keeping up the hard work. I fully recognize that the aesthetic, merchandise or style of this store isn't for everyone. But for those of us who have an appreciation for the the bizarre - a place like Woolly Mammoth is a tiny gift. I recognize how much of a struggle it is for many small businesses to keep their doors open. I don't have a relationship with the staff and/or owners, so I can't claim to know if the shop is raking in the cash or not. That said, the fact that the store is so niche and unique - leads me to believe that it takes their hard won regular customers to keep them searching far and wide to stock new and interesting items for resale. I have been greeted and treated just fine on my few visits. I certainly wouldn't claim Woolly Mammoth is super affordable, but I also wasn't outright insulted by the price tags. Their merchandise is subjective, and I found what I was looking for and was perfectly happy to pay the cost of my item. Perhaps because I already have an idea of what I want when I am browsing, I actually prefer a simple acknowledgment instead of a sales person offering me their full attention? I can't criticize some of the other reviewers who felt slighted, I don't know their expectations and I won't question them. But I do know that I am not alone in my appreciation for the odd ephemera lining the shelves. I also suspect that a majority of people browse and gawk over the items they find but don't necessarily buy. So I can't imagine the staff here can just pay each person that walks in with 100% of their attention when many visitors are "just looking." I really hope that this store remains, and I will return to show my support.

47.description: In response to the owners comments that my review was less then honest, there was infact a mouse skull in a curio cabinet right next to the fetal shark. I purchased a slightly larger fetal shark (then yours)last year in Monterey Ca for $25.00. The solution was also crystal clear, compared to the murky solution seen in your store. I believe you had a fox skull that retailed for $60.00. I purchased a better quality one at Paxton Gate (San Francisco) for about $20.00.The night I was at your store there were two men "working". I drove 65 miles to see your store, so I was excited! I walked in and the two men never said a word, they were deep in a conversation about how the register was broke and they had to turn down a $100.00 sale. When I said "hello", they just looked at me...... So I wasn't going to ask about your pricing tactics.I honestly wanted to buy something, so trust that I was looking, and was unable to find anything priced at $1.00!!I'm not heartbroken that your store disappointed me... There are better, friendlier places to buy from. Your store is great eye candy, but left me with some nasty cavities!

8.description: I found this fabulous store on Instagram & finally made it here last Thursday. Woolly Mammoth is a must-see if you get to Chicago. Worth the trip to Andersonville, for sure. Specializing in oddities, it is part art museum, part curiosity shop. So much to see & learn about. The day we were there, we met Skye who is co-owner along with her husband. She is knowledgeable & friendly. A pure delight to talk to!  The prices are higher than I'm used to but I don't begrudge them for charging them. They have very unique items and sell to a niche market. People will gladly pay to add a rare or unusual piece to their collection.

31.description: It's scary how accurate all the reviews are. The stars range of course, but read what the people are saying. The store is full of weird shit. Mia Z. says it best.The store itself is kind of cute, if you ignore all the weird stuff (though then it might be almost empty). But super expensive. I found a bank that I wanted but it was $60. No thank you.We walked through the store, trying to avoid the faces staring at me. The formaldehyde filled jars made me ill (a CAT is in there. No joke. A real, dead, cat.). There were just tons of things that I didn't ever, ever, ever want in my house. Ever.It was like the most hipster antique store I've been in. It's like a cute boutique in a cute neighborhood, and then you're face to face with a jar of dead frog.Anyway. It's totally not for me, but I imagine there is some market for it since it's in business.It's worth a visit even if you are

34.description: Sweet Baby Jesus, how did a store get inside my brain?!  So many sweet taxidermied animals.  This store is like a cuter version of the attic in Flowers in the Attic, minus all that creepy incest and grandmotherly abuse.  There are all kinds of vintage oddities and antiques from old animal teeth, to vintage children's books, crazy creepy santas, and a giant, wonderful giraffe.  I need to go back when I can spend a little more time but I've already fallen in love and could never give less than five stars.  Taxidermied dik dik-like creature, I'm coming back for you.

16.description: Whoa. Holy weirdness batman! I've been dying to go into this shop since I moved to Chicago and I finally stopped in with a friend last weekend. Just as expected from the window displays, there is a bunch of weird s%&^ here. I am rating it only two stars because the prices are absolutely ridiculous. I understand some of the items are "rare" and "odd" but that does not always have to equal insanely expensive. If you ever need human bones or anything mummified, this is your place.

13.description: Love this place.  It's odd, it's weird, it sometimes creeps me out.  But, it's artistically designed and clearly a well-thought out space and store.  I've never seen a place like it before and the owners of this establishment are kind, genuine, and approachable.  Great customer service.Everyone can find something uniquely perfect for them here.  This great Andersonville treasure has the fine craftsmanship from an excellent carpenter in its design and the beautifully precise and creative eye of an artist.  A superb combination.  A family friend recommended this shop a long while back and I'll always be grateful!

11.description: Loved this store! If you are into the weird and interesting you will thoroughly enjoy browsing this store. Not for the squeamish. Will visit every time I am in town.

39.description: I have stopped in Woolly Mammoth a few times and each time was greated in a very friendly way by the emloyees. Every time I asked a questions about an item the employee knew about it which is impressive since they have so many diverse items in the store. Even when I don't buy anything I am treated well. I really enjoy the wide variety of unusual objects in the store. Nostalgia from decades ago or objects from nature such as skulls from animals,etc. I finally bought a mounted animal head and feel like I got a good deal. I have recommended Woolly Mammoth to others who are looking for unique items for their homes.

37.description: this place is so cool! i stumbled upon it on my way to the middle eastern market next door. they have everything you could never possibly think that you want, but once you see it you wonder how you got through life without it before. the woman working behind the counter was very friendly and interesting. i will absolutely make the trip back to take something home with me ASAP!!

0.description: Such an interesting shop with a range of cool oddities. I stepped in right off the bus to find myself surrounded by various stuffed animals, skulls, bones and such. So many treasures and spirits. If you're in Andersonville it's worth to check this place out you can find pretty much anything. So many little surprises. Who knows what you'll take home with you.Adam was working when I stopped by and he is super friendly and helpful. He gave me a neighborhood map and even some suggestions for a bite to eat in the area. They pick up pieces from around the world. It's like a little museum of things you rarely get to get up close and personal with so now is your chance!

38.description: Taxidermy turtle with wings! Zebra head with a top hat! Burlesque prints!Sold.

51.description: My friends and I were looking for a gift for our other friend and we remembered how cool Woolly Mammoth looked every time we passed by, so we decided to give it a try! The place was filled with awesome treasures and taxidermy. My favorite thing was the fish that was turned into a lamp by "the best artist". Adam was extremely helpful and funny. We will definitely be back!

27.description: Super cool stuff, but like most everything else in Andersonville, the markup borders on absurd. You'll occasionally find some gems at a reasonable price, so I go in from time to time. I love the whack shit they get in here. I don't love the high prices. In my dreams, they move to a neighborhood with no hipsters, so the rents are lower, so they can drop their prices and I can afford to shop here.

32.description: This place has a lot of really really really weird things. If you like taxidermy and dead animals- have at it. It's not really my style. But if you're into that stuff, it's great for you!

54.description: i usually never bother to review places but i have to put in a good word for this one. This is for sure the best new store ive been in and the only one that nails oddities to a T. there are so many unique items, nothing was priced outrageously, the place is packed with cool stuff  but theres still tons of room to move around, the owner was really cool an  talked my girlfriend and i the whole time we were in there, seemed really knowledgeable on the different antiques and items in the store. i strongly recommend checking this place out, and dont wait to long because ill definitely be back to try and buy more cool stuff before you do

48.description: It never helps to not acknowledge customers when they enter and leave, especially for a small indie store. The employee, hopefully not owner, was having a conversation with 2 friends (I guess), and not once even made eye contact with my wife and I.Anyway, I love that a store like this exists, even if it could use a lot of work. Honestly, it seems like a kid's version of the 'Oddities' store featured on TV. I could never expect this or any store to be as cool as that store but, taxidermy all over does not make your store odd. Taxidermy is nasty, tasteless, redneck junk that loves dust. The "Frankenstein" animals they have are simply dumb. I get the feeling the store relies on these dead animals to create the illusion that they have weird stuff. Mostly, they have lots of stuff that would look weird only in a thrift store. Old toys on the common side, lots of disgusting teeth and skulls that is not anything special. There's not one thing in the store that I would buy, not even with a discount.I like that they have a small, stand-up version of the classic 'Centipede' video game that one can play for free! Unless all the cool stuff 'Wooly' has is on eBay, I will not have much of a reason to return.Well, since I'm not a total ass, when in Andersonville with friends, I'll take them there to see what they think. Maybe the clerk will notice us!

44.description: 3 stars for having a great variety of vintage/oddity items..... Loved the old Gremlins comics! The store it set up nicely.  I saw many neat items I could see in my house. But upon checking the prices , I was disappointed.  Thanks to shows like American Pickers and Storage Wars, it seems the pricing on  recycled/used items have sky rocketed through the roof.  I just can't jump on that wagon. So needless to say I do most of my shopping online. I've purchased taxidermied insects for almost 3 times less than what WM is charging. Some of the other critters are over priced for the condition they're in.  Part of my review process(and probably most others) is customer service. Sadly there wasn't much of that here. ''The lady'' behind the counter was lost on the internet. There were 9 people in the store and I did not hear her speak once to anyone. I was there for about 20 minutes. Not even a hello. My friends and I were standing close to the counter and not even a look up... We did say hello to the dog. Cute!    Also, be prepared for trash talking e-mails from the owners if you leave anything less than 4 stars or a negative comment.

24.description: I recently visited this place for the first time and I must say I love this shop! It isn't very large but it is filled to the brim with all kinds of interesting things. If you like taxidermy, strange medical equipment, specimens or unique antiques this is the place for you! I went because I love wet specimens and skulls, here they had several of each for me to look at. I ended up purchasing a bob cat skull. The guy who was there was really nice and helpful. I'm not from Chicago and I am not familiar with all that is had to offer so he gave me some tips of other places with odd and unique things. He was also very knowledgeable about all the items they had, I learned lots of new things about the interesting items they have. A very cool place to stop in!

7.description: I was drawn in by the taxidermy giraffe bust, I was intrigued by the man who sold the shop a petrified camel penis for beer tickets to local street fest, and I stayed to ogle the $2500 hippopotamus skull that I decided I might need when I win the lotto. They've got some pretty decent specimens here, but I don't know. $75 for a taxidermy mouse seemed like a little much I mean, I'm sure it takes a lot of intricate and detailed work, but after seeing that hippo head, it'd be hard to sway my money from investing in anything else. ...not that I'll ever have an extra $2500 lying around. The store had plenty of dusty, rusty, musty, but at the same time chic items that were fun to peruse. The people working in the shop, well, they weren't the friendliest. Seemed like they were kind of anti-hipster but with a very hipster elitist attitude. I smiled at the store pup (who was super sweet and cute) and the couple working kind of gave me a judge-y elevator eyes type look like I was some kind of tourist digging through their things. They didn't acknowledge the people coming in to the store, and instead seemed to give distant glares and then turn to talk amongst themselves, making for a super uncomfortable situation. I guess it was probably a rather busy and annoying weekend giving it was the Saturday of the Andersonville Midsommarfest, but still. A moderate interest in customer service would have gone a long way. I think the shop people probably get a kick out of weirding window-shoppers out, but I love weird shit and while this place is neat and kitschy, I've seen much better collections of oddities that didn't come with so much attitude. See Also: Trundle Manor --- yelp.com/biz/trundle-man…

49.description: You will either love it or hate it.  It's filled with taxidermy and odd objects, toys and ephemera.  If you love old odd weird things, you will love this place.It's tiny. We visit many resale, thrift, antique stores and this one is truly unique.  Very fun if you enjoy the odd things in life.

40.description: I want to begin by saying that this review is entirely subjective.  The girl at the register seemed very nice and I'm sure for a lot of people, old teeth, medical junk and dead things stuffed with sawdust are right up your alley, but I was just skeeved out.As we left, my boyfriend turned to me and said, "Did that place sell anything but children's nightmares?"  For some of you, I'm sure that sounds amazing.I checked out the website before we dropped in, but was still unprepared for just how much of Wooly Mammoth's inventory is taxidermy, bones, and dead things in jars.  It was like walking into the garage of a budding serial killer.  I really do not like taxidermy, and it is so pervasive there that the place smells like... taxidermy.I love antiques, stores that sell weird things, and resale shops.  I didn't find anything of interest at Wooly Mammoth, but I did find:  a container of old dental crowns and implants, scary old medical and dental implements ("Nazi torture devices?" - Boyfriend), a bin of dismembered doll parts, a jar of used lead bullets, the tail of a buffalo, a mummified deer skull, lots of other skulls, freeze dried mice and fetal pigs in jars, dead insects and bits of dead insects, a lamp made out of a taxidermied lizard, sets of glass eyes, plenty of full-scale taxidermy, a lamp made out of the leg of an unidentified ungulate, a skinless stuffed cat of some sort, various gooey things in jars and tubes, terrifying old photographs, mounted heads of dead things, and some poor animal's entire spinal column.I wanted to like this place so badly, but by the time we left I was just queasy.  Recommended for:  People who like taxidermy, avant-garde artists, people trying to decorate a hunting lodge, sociopaths curious about dead things, lovers of the macabre and grotesque.  Just not me.  Bummer.

53.description: Woolly Mammoth Antiques is a small place, and that's a good thing - if it were any bigger, I would become totally lost in a hallucinatory daze and never find my way out again, much less to the #50 bus.Antiques and Oddities are right. Among the things that were on sale were:-  Stuffed animals. Yes, really. Not cats or dogs, thank goodness, but they might have been wolverines- Photos a soldier in 1940's New Guinea took of headhunters, one of whom is actually holding a head- A license plate from (I think) the Island of Malta.- LPs- Vintage clothesI am reluctant to list more items I saw, because you will think that I am making it up. This collection is crazy, eclectic, unique (an overused word, but appropriate here), kitschy, probably totally useless and impractical but absolutely necessary to anybody who has a twisted sense of humor, an appreciation for the oddball, and maybe, just maybe, despises Walmart. This is for the person who doesn't like shopping, but likes having things that other people don't. (The framed headhunter picture falls in this category.) You buy something from this store because it amuses you when you look at it. Your parents will be appalled. Your friends will be jealous. When you move, these are the items you'll take with you in your car rather than entrust to the movers.I get the feeling that the owners are having fun with all of us. I like that energy. This store makes me want to light a match to my current apartment and spend the insurance money here. (Note to StateFarm Insurance - no, I'm not really going to do it. Woolly Mammoth just fills me with imagination and longing. And I like my bed too much to burn it.)Have you guessed that I don't like Walmart? But I do like Woolly Mammoth.

30.description: It's highly unlikely I'd ever buy something from here...that the Mrs. would let me display in our home that is. This store is an oddity of awesomeness. If it's weird and has a price tag, you'll probably find it here. Looking for used medical equipment from way back yonder? How about some random animal heads? This is your stop. No trip to the Chicagoland area is complete without a stop at W.M. You will NOT be disappointed. And there's no hassle; they know lots of people just browse, er, ah gawk, and they're cool with it.

46.description: i don't know, they have some pretty cool shit in there, but it is tiny. i might check back in there if i am on that block, but otherwise, i can't really see rating it 4 or 5 stars....

1.description: I stopped by here on my latest Chicago adventure. The place is chock full of fun things from taxidermy to medical devices. I ended up buying a few skeletons keys since many of the items may not have traveled well on the train during the holiday rush. This is a very interesting place to check out if you are in town.

55.description: I have to say in my own personal experience - this place is freakin beyond AWESOME!!!I've been meaning to get on here the past couple of weeks and post something (I'm wayyyyy behind on my reviews) - but I just have to share my delight on this kick-@$$ store. I could hardly believe my eyes when I walked in - which was a total accident as my husband and I were shopping across the street, and out of sheer random curiousity decided to hop in since we still had time left on the meter. This was a complete gem of a find and I can't believe I hadn't made a visit much sooner!Meet Chicago's quintessential and definative store for the geeky, old-school, throwback, rare and unique nerd loving collector! If you had it as a child, it's here. If you want off the wall and "what is that?!?" - it's there. If you want a quality experience at a game of old school "Space Invaders" on a quality old school arcade machine, you can find it here. This place is truly an old school/vintage dream. There are so many items I've lost over the years that are now found in this little shop, I'd go broke if I dropped some serious money on everything I wanted to buy here. This place is a mini time machine full of treasures to be discovered - both old and new, and I can only hope their collection and customer base grows over time. People of Chicagoland... if you haven't visited Wooly Mammoth, get off your lazy tusks and hoof it, take the bus or take a drive out there. It's a memorable experience and a place that will always stay in your mind for any gift idea that calls for the purchase of the truly unique and memorable both past and present and just may inspire you to make an impulse buy on that long lost (whatever it is) that has now been found!

9.description: Open Tuesdays 3-7 PM and Wed-Sat Noon-7 PM.This store is not for all tastes.  But it's fantastic if your tastes overlap theirs.  It's the sort of place I'd imagine David Sedaris would shop at.  As other reviewers have said, taxidermy is very big here.  There is a little niche of books on stage magic and hypnotism.  Musical instruments (brass mostly).  Need a gunsight for your WW II vintage Sherman tank?  They've got you covered.  A small selection of vintage LP's.  Lots of bones, animal bones and replicas of human ones.  Dental instruments.  A variety on insects and arachnids in what I guess are small jars of formaldehyde.  Lot's of box cameras from about the 50's & 60's though I don't know where you might get film or flashbulbs for them nowadays.Make one circuit of the store, and then go back for a second pass.  For me, there were quite a few things I didn't notice the first time around.

26.description: I was drawn in by the taxidermy giraffe bust, I was intrigued by the man who sold the shop a petrified camel penis for beer tickets to local street fest, and I stayed to ogle the $2500 hippopotamus skull that I decided I might need when I win the lotto. They've got some pretty decent specimens here, but I don't know. $75 for a taxidermy mouse seemed like a little much I mean, I'm sure it takes a lot of intricate and detailed work, but after seeing that hippo head, it'd be hard to sway my money from investing in anything else. ...not that I'll ever have an extra $2500 lying around. The store had plenty of dusty, rusty, musty, but at the same time chic items that were fun to peruse. The people working in the shop, well, they weren't the friendliest. Seemed like they were kind of anti-hipster but with a very hipster elitist attitude. I smiled at the store pup (who was super sweet and cute) and the couple working kind of gave me a judge-y elevator eyes type look like I was some kind of tourist digging through their things. They didn't acknowledge the people coming in to the store, and instead seemed to give distant glares and then turn to talk amongst themselves, making for a super uncomfortable situation. I guess it was probably a rather busy and annoying weekend giving it was the Saturday of the Andersonville Midsommarfest, but still. A moderate interest in customer service would have gone a long way. I think the shop people probably get a kick out of weirding window-shoppers out, but I love weird shit and while this place is neat and kitschy, I've seen much better collections of oddities that didn't come with so much attitude. See Also: Trundle Manor --- yelp.com/biz/trundle-man…

25.description: I'm certainly not well versed on the city having moved to the suburbs from out of state but it's a huge treat. I collect antique medical pieces, the macabre, and eclectic oddities so this place was right up my alley. It's not a huge store by any means but they have a great selection. It's a bit overpriced but seeing as how it's the only spot in town with this kind of selection I guess you have to take the good with the bad. I purchased a few things there and I'm sure I'll be back again soon to continue adding to my collection. Definitely worth a stop!

12.description: Sweet Baby Jesus, how did a store get inside my brain?!  So many sweet taxidermied animals.  This store is like a cuter version of the attic in Flowers in the Attic, minus all that creepy incest and grandmotherly abuse.  There are all kinds of vintage oddities and antiques from old animal teeth, to vintage children's books, crazy creepy santas, and a giant, wonderful giraffe.  I need to go back when I can spend a little more time but I've already fallen in love and could never give less than five stars.  Taxidermied dik dik-like creature, I'm coming back for you.

59.description: I ABSOLUTELY ADORE THIS PLACE!!!!  I was running late on my way to somewhere else, but NOTHING could stop me from trying out this place--I was intrigued and mystified when I first encountered it when it was closed--wowww....it is bursting with treasures galore!!!  My incendiary artist friend found some tooth slides (only 50 cents each!) and THIS GEM OF A HEART (only ten dollars--whoaa!!!)--she called it the find of a lifetime---the heart was modelled after a human heart and was brilliantly placed in this aquarium that was shaped like a brandy snifter--you could reallly pump it and it just defies description--can't really do it justice!  I also bought the Scaredest Scarecrow book (written by the same guy who wrote Rudolph the Red-nosed Reindeer!) during my first visit and found some GORGEOUS golden lacy placemats on my second visit--the staff is super friendly (not obnoxious just nice and intelligent!)--both times we've had extensive conversations!  There are a lot of just extraordinary antique items -- and fun stuff from my youth--like smurf items!!!  I will visit often; I am immensely happy and completely satisfied with this discovery!!!  My new favorite shoppe of curiosities and oddities!!!!

21.description: I was super excited to find a store that sold all these little weird things!I would totally give this store 5 stars just for their merchandise. I mean, how awesome is their stuff! I could spend all day looking at the human teeth and skulls, perusing the old and weird photos and all the jarred animals and taxidermy. The thing is, the people working there act like they don't want you in there. No acknowledgment walking in, I actually greeting the lady at the desk in the back and she didn't look up or greet me back. I get it, its a small shop, independently owned, but I could have used some help from the lady there. I was looking to buy some old photos but she didn't want to get up to talk to me when I tried talking to her about them.I would love to come back and get some things and have the chance to look more at their collection, but I don't know that I will. When you get such a cold reaction to being a customer, it makes you not want to go back.

17.description: I finally had a chance to visit this lovely shop on my most recent trip to Chicago and it did not disappoint. The aesthetic is PERFECT. It is so thoughtfully curated and not a crook of space left unfilled. The store walls and shelves keeps the eyes busy and the heart happy. I had a chance to speak with one of the owners at length and she was very nice and informative. A place I look forward to visiting again and telling anyone else to do so as well.

10.description: They have hair wreaths here from the late 1800s! Apparently, family members would cut hair from deceased family members and weave it into wreaths to wear in mourning. Also, they sell comics by Isabella Rotman. A very interesting way to read about health an wellness.I'm definitely going back because I'm sure I will find something new every time.

5.description: My husband and I visited Woolly Mammoth Antiques about 6 months prior to our first purchase. We were in the market for a peacock and they said I could keep in touch as to when one came in. As soon as a new peacock arrived in the shop, I was contacted, we drove down from Milwaukee WI, and now Kevin is a happy member of our household! I believe this to be EXCELLENT customer service, and we are VERY happy with our purchase. The store is a visual feast, the prices are excellent, and the owners are happy to chat! I 100% recommend you take the time to visit this Chicago oddity!

3.description: A great store to check out in Andersonville. Bones, stuffed animals, creepy medical instruments galore! Plenty of things to look and learn. Many times we had google at the ready when we saw an item and said "what the hell is that?"Just be careful as many of the items are fragile (so if you have small children, maybe skip this store). I was clutching my purse the entire time as I was afraid of my purse going rogue if I turned too quickly and smashing an expensive case of irreplaceable items. We bought an interesting dental tool as a gift for a friend and the employee mentioned that this store gave him an appreciation for modern medicines and all of the advances. So go there to learn and explore, and then don't be surprised when you see something cool you want to buy. But don't worry because you can find something in pretty much any price range here.

35.description: Just visited the store today and as much as I wanted to purchase some items I decided to wait for some paychecks to come through and hope the item I had my eye on will still be there.I met Adam who works there and had a nice conversation about National Parks. Yes a bit off subject but it was nice to chat! I plan on visiting again and bringing my friends who I know would like the unique antique and vintage oddities in the store.Thanks for the great visit and amazingly unique shop :)

19.description: We dig the kind of stuff for sale at Woolly Mammoth.  It was by chance we found this place, we walked past on our way to the Lebanon restaurant next door.  Saw some amazing taxidermy like a giraffe wearing a top hat, the mourning hair which you don't see everyday, and boxes and boxes of bones, drops in the bucket that is the inventory.  Can't wait to go back, they may be interested in a particular item in my collection.

28.description: I love the eclectic mix of odds and ends. It's a little bit like a bizarre roadside museum. But all the beautiful stuffed animals! This hurts my heart. I cannot come back. It's too painful to see a giant beautiful giraffe minus its body. I will not be back.

45.description: Although I feel guilty simply browsing as often as I buy here, I can't stop visiting Woolly Mammoth whenever I am out running errands or drinking in Andersonville. One of the great things about it is that its owners are working artists, which means that their inventory and look changes constantly-- they are prone to work on new displays at night so that a different store can await you if you go back every few weeks. Not to mention that when I have asked for them to look out for certain curiosities that I have seen out west (i.e. silver spray painted framed spider webs), not only have the owners been curious and excited, but they have said the magic words: I COULD PROBABLY MAKE THAT! Another great thing about the place is that its owners are very approachable and knowledgeable about their relics. I am a history geek who appreciates stories, and have received anecdotes along with most of my purchases. I have ended up going home with: $30-40 laminated WWII posters to use as placemats (side of Stalingrad with your salad, anyone?), $? Nixon campaign buttons (was "slightly tipsy" from Hopleaf), $5 Bon Jovi paraphernalia, $5 costume jewelry (owls!!!) and $1 records ("It's A Small World After All!") I keep meaning to buy the antique toboggan suspended from their ceiling. You guys should too.

33.description: I saw a stuffed kangaroo in the window.Not like a cute kids stuffed animal, the real bona fide thing.  Glass eyes and all.I had to go inside.Upon entering the shop, I got gooseflesh..  There were dead things in jars of formaldehyde, bowls of teeth, taxidermied mice, mounted large game heads, and a general odor of sawdust and dust.This place would surly make Steven King clap his hands.  It was a tiny Field Museum - only you could buy EVERYTHING.In addition to the freak-a-saurus stuff, they also have tons of vintage/retro kids things.  The juxtaposition of the seriously macabre with children's toys amuses me to no end - but may creep some others out.This may be a small shop, but it requires a lot of time to investigate.  There are so many things to see, and touch. This might be that perfect shop to buy your favourite biology teacher a gift, or to purchase that lower mandible that you've been searching everywhere for.Check it out.  And then wash your hands.

43.description: I could spend hours in there laughin', gaggin', buyin'.... I'm still having nightmares about the mummified cat mounted on the wall.

2.description: This place is unique. I've never been in a store quite like this. Hard to describe what exactly you'd find. We found animal skulls, stuffed animals, ancient dentistry tools, Victorian jewelry made from the hair of the deceased. It's a whole gamut of things. There was not a second I was bored in the store. There is so much to see in the store that you won't be disappointed even if you left without purchasing anything. It's the place to go to buy something for that friend of yours that is into weird and obscure finds.Definitely check this place out if you are in the area.

18.description: So it's really hard not to give this place a 5 star review. I bought an alligator hand on a stick there today for $16, which I think is a pretty great deal for an ALLIGATOR HAND ON A STICK!!! (or s it technically a claw?) The lady who greeted me was really nice and wasn't weirded out by my social awkwardness, which I'm guessing is status quo in a place like this. There was a friendly dog in the back and a million different things I will buy if I can find an excuse to incorporate them into a video project or stop motion animation for any reason.

41.description: Love this place. I usually only buy a few knick knacks when I go in (which is about once a week), but I never feel like I'm being judged for only purchasing small items. I always have funny conversations with the owners, and always leave excited about my purchase. The best thing about Woolly Mammoth, is that there is a story behind every item. I'm not a citizen of the world or anything, but I've never found a store quite like this. They have everything from full scale taxidermy to antique salt and pepper shakers. Adam (the brain behind the operation) even makes lamps out of random objects (like a prosthetic foot, or a dead alligator. Rad.) Definitely worth checking out. Maybe you'll walk out with an old bowling pin or a mummified cat.

52.description: To the best of my knowledge, there are no actual wooly mammoths for sale here, but it wouldn't surprise me if there were. Stepping into Woolly Mammoth is like stepping into your grandmother's attic, assuming your grandmother was half mad and had a fetish for taxidermy. Along with the stuffed animals -- as in, once living, now full of sawdust -- there are plenty of bones and parts and I don't know what all. Looking for beaver teeth? You can find them here.Taxidermy is just the tip of the iceberg, though -- if a rather large tip. There's antique furniture, toys, and knick knacks, most in the mid-20th century range. I was particularly taken with the printing blocks and the Soviet era lapel pins. The store claims to offer antiques, oddities & resale items, but they're definitely heavy on the oddities. It's tiny and packed and a bit of a madhouse, which is just what a shop like this needs to be.The owners are terrific. They're a lovely couple in their 30s (?), and 10 minutes into the store I felt like I had known them for years. They obviously love what they do, and enjoy sharing their passion with their customers. Our conversation ranged from Kreskin's ESP to Ouija boards to mid-century glassware. All of which they sell.Stop in. You may not be looking for anything, but you'll find it here.

50.description: Fantastic little shop tucked away on a side street in Chicago. We stopped in and although the store was closed (owners were unloading their latest finds) they nicely let us browse the wares. Good selection and reasonable prices!!There were taxidermied animals, collectible curiosities, vintage clothes, unique tchotchkes and the list goes on. I'm sad I was not able to buy anything since they weren't open for business but I will go back on my next visit to Chi-Town!!

4.description: Sweet mother of taxidermy! This little gem is a must-visit for anyone on the prowl for something unique. Oh, sure, the giraffe tibia ($325) is a little more than I expected to pay for giraffe tibia, but this is all about convenience.Korean War-era blood transfusion bottles? They have a wonderful assortment of those.Crocodiles stuffed in semi-erotic poses? They've got ya covered.Arrowheads and religious oddities of all kind? Wooly Mammoth is on point.Looking for an entry-level item? Maybe something unique for your next white elephant exchange? Extracted human teeth are just $10 each. The bigger and darker the cavity, the better, I say.The staff are a wonderful assortment who've quite literally seen just about everything. But they're always in the market for the unusual and strange.  Just be sure that it's REALLY unusual or REALLY strange. You'll be talking to people who sell preserved pig fetuses on a regular basis.

6.description: This might be the most interesting shop I've ever seen. I'd pay to see a museum exhibit curated by the owners. Where else can you buy decorative bottles of expired catheter cleaner or Victorian ornamental wreaths made of human hair? Bonus points for creative taxidermy and a wide selection of creepy dental accessories. This is where you need to go to see something you've never seen before.

22.description: I love this place even more now that they host taxidermy classes through The Detroit Academy of Taxidermy! I wish there was a Yelp listing for that. Anyway, it was a really interesting and fun class that I'd love to take again. Woolly Mammoth was the perfect spot for this since you could admire their taxidermy pieces and be inspired.

15.description: I am visiting my sister in Chicago and we came here to find a present for my nephew for Christmas. The merchandise is really interesting and if you are looking for anything having to do with taxidermy this is your place.  Skulls, stuffed giraffes, bear rugs, bottles with snakes/sharks etc in formaldehyde......Beyond this, there are other really interesting oddities.  The owner was super nice and helped us find other GREAT shops in the area.    He was super chatty and made some suggestions about what we were buying too.  This is a small shop and you will be a bit eeked out at some of the merchandise, but all in all it is an experience.

57.description: I love this place.  I found a collection of Bears cocktail glasses that I remember from when I was growing up.  All 10 in pristine condition.  The owners are cool too.  If you haven't stopped by this place, you are really missing out.

20.description: I am visiting my sister in Chicago and we came here to find a present for my nephew for Christmas.
