36.description: Walked in 15 minutes after my pizza was supposed to be ready. No line. Only a handful of diners, but I was still told it would be another 10 minutes. Initial time given? 40 minutes. Actual wait time? 65 minutes.

30.description: Came here for lunch today and loved my experience. Due to the wonderful weather they hit a button and the windows closest to the street open up and it feels like you're sitting outside. I sat down and enjoyed a personal pan pizza (which was filling), fries and a Matilda Pale Ale. This spot is a good addition to the neighborhood.  There are other Giordanos' locations up north that are comparable in terms of food and service.  But none of them have the aesthetic awesomeness of this place

3.description: ORIGINAL CHICAGO CHICKEN CHOPPED SALAD. My mouth was watering for this salad the day after eating Giordano's because it was THAT good. It's the perfect blend of everything you could want in a salad. It's also the perfect appetizer as you wait 45 minutes for your deep dish pizza. Other appetizers that we ordered were the garlic parmesan fries and chicken wings. All of the appetizers were so delicious that I almost forgot what we went to Giordano's for in the first place! As a first timer to Chicago, I can't compare the pizza to other locations in the city, but it sure was yummy!I haven't been to any of the other Giordano's locations, but I was very satisfied with this location. We went at around 7:30 or 8pm and expected to be waiting outside for a table. There was actually no wait for our party of four and there were several empty tables around us. There's a bunch of seating upstairs, which is probably why we didn't have to wait. I also heard that this location is fairly new. If I was ever back in Chicago, I wouldn't mind coming back here, but I would also want to try other deep dish pizza restaurants.

14.description: Literally just picked up my order, when I got there I only got 2 things and they were going to send me away without my tiramisu.  Which might have been a blessing... Instead whilst enjoying it I discovered MOLD on my tiramisu! I'm thoroughly disgusted and thoroughly angered! It's lunch time on a Saturday in a bumping part of Chicago.... Considering here... DON'T DO IT!

58.description: Chicago's Andersonville and North Centre boasts quite a few gems that pander to the palate that indulges Swedish and Scandinavian tastes. I was already aware of Ann Sather and Tre Kronor, but was surprised to find that there are indeed more dining options of the Swedish, Scandinavian, and Danish set. Svea Restaurant is one such restaurant.Eggs. Hashbrowns. Sausage. Swedish pancakes with lingonberries.Arriving just as the door opened for business, I received a greeting that was an indication that the service would be top.Being able to look into the kitchen whenever the door swung open briefly, I knew I would get an authentic Scandinavian breakfast. And that was exactly what I got. The eggs were real, not that scrambled madness from the carton. The hashbrowns were not the shredded get-up that you get at many restaurants, but rather cut potatoes. Sausages are never a must on my list of dining options, but these went well with the dijon mustard. As to the Swedish pancakes, I gobbled them to completion.Oh my God, they were so good.Svea Restaurant has a cash-only policy, so head on over to the ATM before going to get some tasty Scandinavian brekkie.

56.description: With daughter KT and bf living so close to the business district in Andersonville, this was a really easy walk for Sunday breakfast.  We went a little late and although they were fairly busy, we were able to get a table immediately.  This is a really nice local restaurant filled, like you would find on Main Street in any small town that still has a main street.  And like those small towns there is usually an original immigrant group who were the first settlers, leaving the mark of their culture and heritage on the town.  In the case of Andersonville, it is Swedish and Svea is a "Swedish" restaurant, featuring some of the traditional fare.The wait staff is very friendly and naturally so.  The food is not fancy or creative.  You get pretty standard Midwestern breakfast items, but all done well.  The food is 3-1/2 stars and I am rounding up for the ambiance, tradition and hometown feel.  I really felt comfortable here.We all had eggs and potatoes with a meat choice.  The Swedish sausage is like a fine ground ring bologna, well flavored, but not garlicky, which is a nice thing at breakfast.  The fried potatoes are probably some of the best I have ever had, clearly homemade and not dumped out of a freezer bag, they were well browned and well flavored.If you stroll in some morning for a pleasant breakfast, be sure to have some of the Swedish bread called limpa which is apparently Swedish for rye.  It is delicately flavored with anise in this case.  It is delicious.

29.description: Let me first say that I generally do not do breakfast. Cup of coffee and minimal conversation is fine by me. Not out of some prejudice for the first meal of the day, but the abhorrent hour in which breakfast is served. So, it was to my surprise that even at my most cranky, Svea can put a smile on my face. It might sound cliche, but the old world charm of this place keeps me coming back. The staff is incredibly nice, the coffee is respectable, the food is delicious, and the prices are of another era too. Whether it is the lingonberry pancakes, the salmon sandwich, or the Gothenberg special, I know that my day is going to be better because of this place and if I ate here everyday, I might actually start to believe that breakfast is the most important meal of the day.

42.description: we sad down right away and for a Saturday morning it was quite impressive. great service. great prices also. the Swedish pancakes were great and the jam (forgot what it's called) that comes with them is amazing! apparently it's imported from Sweden. the only thing I didn't like was that my eggs were a little oily. otherwise, id definitely go back!

23.description: Horrible service. My 9-year-old daughter insisted on coming back here. So we drove the half hour to get here, and I dropped my wife and daughter at the restaurant at 2:30 PM on a Sunday, Jan 18, 2015, while I looked for parking. They refused to seat them in their mostly empty restaurant until I got there, and told them the kitchen closes in 15 minutes. I ran up at 2:40, and they told us the kitchen is closed. (The hours are till 3.) How heartless. I will never spend a dime in this place again.

47.description: After a being quoted an hour wait at M Henry, Svea seemed like a decent alternative. Until we got there and were somewhat turned off by the old diner look and cash only... And not the most thrilling menu. But 8 people and a Koval tour in just a little over an hour wouldn't get us in and out of many other places on time so we gave it a shot... And it was great!!2 words: Viking Breakfast.1 recommendation: Split it between 2 people.Stack of Swedish pancakes w/lingonberriesRoasted potatoesEggs your waySwedish sausageToast (get the limpa (rye))Ordered a side of meatballs- I would skip this next time.Where else will such a breakfast for 2 (with coffee tax and tip) cost $25?!

8.description: Great breakfast joint in Andersonville.  Nicely decorated.  Can usually get a seat right away.   Service is friendly and fast.   Very accommodating for children (1 year old).   Standard breakfast fare, with some Swedish twists (i.e., pickled herring).

31.description: For quite some time now, my husband and I have wanted to check out this place.  We have walked passed it numerous amount of times.  We finally made it here for my birthday breakfast.  There was no wait so we were seated right away.  Great way to start off our day.  Our waitress was friendly along with the rest of the staff.  The decor is super cute and homey.  It's like you walked into a more dated very cute swedish colorful diner.  They have vintage and antiques pieces through. And modern day pictures of festivals hosted in Andersonville. I ordered the Swedish Tease and a small OJ. Something sweet and something savory, the swedish tease has the best of both.  My husband got the Gothenburg Special with coffee.  I enjoyed my swedish pancakes and my husband enjoyed his dish as well.  The sausages were huge and plum.  A swedish pancake is thin like a crepe, but has more moist and has texture to it. We were not so fond of the limpa rye bread. The prices here won't break the bank and its a cash only place so bring some greens when you come.  If you are in Andersonville and want to try Swedish cuisine, check this place out.  You will enjoy the inviting charm of the Swedish culture.

34.description: SVEA is one of those old fashion places where you pay cash (only) and get simple good food in return. I'm a fan of simple and adequately prices food.  Most of the time, I want my eggs and potatoes with a toast sans any additional craziness. That's what you get at SVEA. Be warned, those potatoes are the best and are addictive! Menu is simple, but you still can order a huge (Viking) breakfast; and food is consistent. Mind you, this is an old Swedish place: small and decorated accordingly. If you sit on the bar, you will most likely be hitting not only your knees on the counter, but your neighbors also (them with shoulders). It add to the atmosphere. Service is friendly and once you order, wait time is reasonable. Happy to have a place like this around.

16.description: Chicago's Andersonville and North Centre boasts quite a few gems that pander to the palate that indulges Swedish and Scandinavian tastes. I was already aware of Ann Sather and Tre Kronor, but was surprised to find that there are indeed more dining options of the Swedish, Scandinavian, and Danish set. Svea Restaurant is one such restaurant.Eggs. Hashbrowns. Sausage. Swedish pancakes with lingonberries.Arriving just as the door opened for business, I received a greeting that was an indication that the service would be top.Being able to look into the kitchen whenever the door swung open briefly, I knew I would get an authentic Scandinavian breakfast. And that was exactly what I got. The eggs were real, not that scrambled madness from the carton. The hashbrowns were not the shredded get-up that you get at many restaurants, but rather cut potatoes. Sausages are never a must on my list of dining options, but these went well with the dijon mustard. As to the Swedish pancakes, I gobbled them to completion.Oh my God, they were so good.Svea Restaurant has a cash-only policy, so head on over to the ATM before going to get some tasty Scandinavian brekkie.

13.description: For quite some time now, my husband and I have wanted to check out this place.  We have walked passed it numerous amount of times.  We finally made it here for my birthday breakfast.  There was no wait so we were seated right away.  Great way to start off our day.  Our waitress was friendly along with the rest of the staff.  The decor is super cute and homey.  It's like you walked into a more dated very cute swedish colorful diner.  They have vintage and antiques pieces through. And modern day pictures of festivals hosted in Andersonville. I ordered the Swedish Tease and a small OJ. Something sweet and something savory, the swedish tease has the best of both.  My husband got the Gothenburg Special with coffee.  I enjoyed my swedish pancakes and my husband enjoyed his dish as well.  The sausages were huge and plum.  A swedish pancake is thin like a crepe, but has more moist and has texture to it. We were not so fond of the limpa rye bread. The prices here won't break the bank and its a cash only place so bring some greens when you come.  If you are in Andersonville and want to try Swedish cuisine, check this place out.  You will enjoy the inviting charm of the Swedish culture.

11.description: (NOTE: I translated this to Swedish for the Yelp 100 Challenge: Stockholm. For the English version of this review please scroll down to the original.)Jag är hälften svenska .. och så jag alltid efter god skandinavisk mat, vilket är svårt att hitta. Men Svea är ett av undantagen.Detta är oftast en frukost och brunch plats, som ligger i hjärtat av Anderson, den gamla svenska stadsdel i Chicago, som nu i första hand höft, artsy, och lesbisk. Men maten står fortfarande högt som svenska biljettpris ... och platsen är alltid trångt.Frukostar består mestadels av svenska pannkakor (mycket stora tunna pannkakor vikta i trianglar och serveras med smör, lingon och sirap på begäran), även korv (potatiskorv, princess korv (liten), och tjockare stora sådana som fyller du upp snabbt i vinter. de tjänar också ägg, potatis och andra frukost godsaker. det finns några svenska brunch objekt på menyn, som svenska köttbullar, men jag går alltid för frukostar.Alldeles intill är en av de sista svenska marknaden i staden, om du behöver leveranser.Detta är ett måste försöka minst en gång.

39.description: Decided to try Svea since Ann Sather's closed. The restaurant was pretty full. I was a bit disappointed. The food was very average tasting. I had the Viking style French toast which was supposed to be made with a thicker Texas toast but looked more like regular bread. So - all in all - it was only ok. I'll go to Ann Sather's next time.

37.description: I love this place. A friend of mine told me about it. We went on a Sunday morning around there peek rush. We ate at the counter because we didn't want to wait for a table but it looked like the line wasn't to long. We had amazing food and amazing service. It reminds me of my Swedish great grandmothers kitchen.

0.description: This is my FAVORITE breakfast spot in the city. The staff is absolutely incredible - super nice and so, so attentive. The draft from the door is a bit cold but I like going early before there's a wait. It is a small place, but very cozy and charming.The prices cannot be beat and it's the perfect size meal to start a day. I've had a lot of the menu and am always super satisfied with the quality. Everything is simple but done extraordinarily well.

38.description: This super cute Swedish diner is great, one of the few remaining old timers in a rapidly gentrifying Andersonville.  I get the same thing every time I go there, the Popeye Omelet, which isn't remotely Swedish but still pretty darn delicious.  A must try is their Swedish Limpa bread. Service is always friendly but remember to bring cash as they don't accept credit cards.

51.description: Pluses: Both Swedish pancakes and the "Viking" French toast were tasty. Food was delivered efficiently and drinks were quickly refilled. Restaurant had a rustic, yet cozy appearance when you walk inside.Negatives: They tried to run the restaurant a little too efficiently, to the detriment of the customer comfort. Most of the tables were empty when we came in, but the server (or maybe it was the manager) almost rudely insisted that we only sit at the one of the two-top tables since we came in as a couple. However the seating with regard to two-tops was limited, and the only ones available were either dirty or right in front of the window where it was hot because the sunlight was pouring in. So we instead decided to sit at the breakfast bar where it was rather cramped and you had to stare at the bus tubs and kitchen sink. Why would the customers not get their preference with regard to seating when the restaurant is not busy at all? Awkward experience. OVERALL: It's a shame that the quality of the service is not equal to the quality of the food in this establishment. Interact with the customers more. Smile. Let customers sit where they want when the restaurant is mostly empty. Perhaps if there were more focus on the customer experience rather than restaurant operational "needs", this restaurant would earn a higher rating from me.

27.description: This place is cute, but I have to say I think the reviews are a little high for this place based on the food. It's really cute and quaint. It's not very big so as you would expect, plan for a wait on the weekends. Also, plan to have cash as it is cash only which is automatically -1 star for any establishment in my book.The menu is larger than you would expect and I like that it was rather varied. I also liked the diner at the front if you just want to stop in during the week for a quiet place to chill.I had the Viking breakfast and the bf had a lot of pork. I ordered the Viking breakfast so I could sample what they had to offer and it was just underwhelming... as were the sticky tables. My eggs were good, the wheat toast was fine (I don't like anise/caraway seed so I'm not a limpet fan), the sausage was not good. Other items I just found to be really salty. I did like the Swedish pancakes which are crepe style served with the lingonberry sauce. Our server was good and the food came out quickly (we were there during the week). I just wasn't all that impressed so I can't say I would come back, and I definitely wouldn't wait for a table here.

32.description: Ordered grilled chicken breast sandwich and veggie omelette, both were good, good service. Beautiful interior style.Ps. Cash only.

54.description: Wonderful food.

48.description: I love you Svea, oh I love you so.I love your charm, I love your decorations, I love your staff, I love your food, I love that you are  less than a 20 second walk from my apartment.I want to eat here every day but thankfully I restrain myself. Every day that I drive by in the morning on my way to work I die a little inside because I am not sitting in their window, coffee in hand, Swedish pancakes on the way. Boyfriend and I have have been here too many times and have sampled a lot of their menu. I think everything we've tried has been really good. My go-to now is their Swedish Tease: Swedish Pancake with 2 eggs over medium,  and bacon (side of Limpa please). Their omelettes are really good although a little greasy. We've started ordering sliced tomatoes on the side in place of their potatoes. Their tomatoes are randomly really good. We've enjoyed sides of their herring, smoked salmon, biscuits and gravy, we've even tried their burgers ..... everything is delicious! It's a quintessential diner with a chef that actually knows how to cook and cook well!Svea is a staple in Andersonville and if it ever changes I'll die. Actually lose a part of my soul. I'm never more content than when I'm sitting in Svea across from my boyfriend with a cup of coffee, early on a Saturday or Sunday morning with nothing to do and the aroma of bacon and herring in the air. That is apparently bliss for me.

44.description: A couple of weeks ago I visited this establishment since I have recently moved to the hood I thought I should check this place out. I got the breakfast sampler with the potato sausage. Damn that sausage was good, and I know it's popular but the mustard they use for it made me want to eat it with everything. So good. The swedish pancake was solid, and the lingonberries that came with were quite delicious. Plus the woman who served me was such a sweet and lovely person. Definitely check this place out if you have any inclinations towards Scandinavian food

24.description: Swedish love - family who owns is amazing, and the food and presentation is spectacular. I would live here if I could.

7.description: Svea has been around forever, it is a Swedish diner which is cash only and on the smaller side. I have always found the food to be fresh and the service fairly quick.  One aspect that I do enjoy especially in the summer is that you are able to substitute fresh tomato slices instead of the breakfast potatoes.  If you are into the sweeter side there are certainly some options for you as well.  Lingonberries are a popular condiment as well.As mentioned by many others this is the best bacon for miles around.  While I have been tempted to order other breakfast meats they offer, I just can't do it.

49.description: Feast like Viking after your late night exploits!  My favorite breakfast place in Andersonville; it's tiny, cheap and unpretentious.  You won't find a bunch of fancy this or that but everything is pretty solid and the menu isn't so large as to add to your Saturday headache.  Downsides are no booze and there are often small children running amok in a small space.

40.description: I had decent Swedish pancakes with eggs and linked sausages.  I'm not crazy about their coffee.  ;-(

53.description: This is not a place I go to for good food - Svea is basically a replica Swedish 70s diner; pure Scandinavian trucker food. The coffee is weak and nasty. The juice is made from concentrate. The potatoes are greasy. All the condiments come in little plastic packages. The Swedish sausage is all lips'n asses. But the pancakes are awesome, the mustard is authentic and the service is impeccable, and just the right amount of friendly. Svea is the quintessential "sunkställe" and I love it. I will always come back here. I just can't give it a great grade.

30.description: First I want to say I like little dives, I just like them to be clean. We were sat a dirty table with empty and used items and when we asked to wipe it down they only wiped part of it. We were handed a greasy and filthy menu and just to add to the perfect beginning, a severely sharp water cup was put in front of me. We liked their food so we decided to order to-go. Would rather not sit at a dirty table we asked twice to be wiped. While waiting for our take-out we watched as dirty plates and glasses were emptied into a sink where they placed clean water pitchers. I don't think I need to explain cross contamination. The waitress that was using the sink as a bus bin didn't even wash her hands before touching clean plates and glasses, EWW. Maybe some health codes are being broken?The food was atrocious. The potatoes tasted old and had soaked so much grease I think they were scrapings from other plates. The Swedish meatballs were undercooked and tasted odd. I have eaten here before and never had it be such a terrible experience. What happened to quality control and just plain cleanliness!? Boo on Svea, you have disappointed and we will not return. What a shame. :(

46.description: It's quiet early, the radio is on low. The joint's über-charming. Cash only. Hash browns are perfectly crunchy, the toast comes buttered. It's the greasiest of greasy spoons, but isn't that the point?

1.description: I love love love Svea. From the adorable rustic decor to the super nice staff and best of all the Swedish pancakes. The batter and thickness of these is perfection. You don't even really need any powdered sugar which is added and is a nice sweeter touch. Omg and the lingdon berry jam is also stellar. And their potato pancake is to die for too. It's also thin but huge and oh so delish. The coffee and hot chocolate here is also amaze. One of my fave brunch places when I'm in Andersonville. Ps: they only take cash.I suggest you pop in!

55.description: I'm all for local and independent, just realize my aversion to this place is the cheap diner food made with completely cheap garbage ingredients... no maple syrup at a place that serves pancakes, only cancer-causing paraben-loaded, HFCS fake chemical garbage? Sorry, it's not me, it's you.

9.description: This place is cute, but I have to say I think the reviews are a little high for this place based on the food. It's really cute and quaint. It's not very big so as you would expect, plan for a wait on the weekends. Also, plan to have cash as it is cash only which is automatically -1 star for any establishment in my book.The menu is larger than you would expect and I like that it was rather varied. I also liked the diner at the front if you just want to stop in during the week for a quiet place to chill.I had the Viking breakfast and the bf had a lot of pork. I ordered the Viking breakfast so I could sample what they had to offer and it was just underwhelming... as were the sticky tables. My eggs were good, the wheat toast was fine (I don't like anise/caraway seed so I'm not a limpet fan), the sausage was not good. Other items I just found to be really salty. I did like the Swedish pancakes which are crepe style served with the lingonberry sauce. Our server was good and the food came out quickly (we were there during the week). I just wasn't all that impressed so I can't say I would come back, and I definitely wouldn't wait for a table here.

26.description: A nice breakfast diner. Cute, if not fancy.   The food was good and very reasonably priced.  My only issue with it is having to find parking, but this is true for the whole Andersonville area.

25.description: Cute little restaurant with decent food. Our waitress seemed to be in a bit of a hurry while taking our order but made plenty of time to stop and talk to another customer a little while later but other than that she was very nice. I'm deducting two stars, one for the waitress that was in a hurry and one for their hours. I wish they were open a little later. Oh, and they only take cash! Luckily my Daughter had some on her because I never carry cash!

12.description: So I decided to go to this restaurant again because of their great food. This is after I have been treated unfairly by this waiter that works there during the week. As I walked in, she asked if I drove the car that was parked outside and I responded yes. The waiter was so nice to me providing cutover service more that I would ever dream of from her. I kept wondering why she decide to be nice to me. While eating away, she pulled out her phone and asked if I had wrote a review about her on Yelp. I said yes I wrote it. To bring you up to speed. This woman was so rude, mean and disrespectful to me the firs time she served me. So I left my experience on yelp. I guess she wasn't happy about that. I even mentioned I wouldn't go back to the restaurant again, unfortunately I did.So she pulled the phone out questioning me about the review and I explained to her why I wrote it. She suggested that if I knew she was so mean to me and if I knew she'll be at the restaurant at that particular time frame, I should have chose to come on a weekend while she is not there. Because of her attitude the first time she served me at the restaurant I decided not to tip her. I cannot have that sort attitude towards me and still tip. It doesn't work like that in the service industry. I say that because I have experience working in the service industry. The customer is always right no matter what. She even tried to embarrassed me in front of other customers and one particular old man tried to make me uncomfortable by sitting right next to me and stared at me. At first I just wanted to leave the restaurant, pay and walk out but I wasn't going to give them any sort of satisfaction. So I decided to stare back at him and gave him the look as if I was about to do something nasty. I guess he got uncomfortable and looked away. What kind of restaurant tries to intimidate their customers? Never heard of it. When it was time to pay, I felt bad and thought all that drama wasn't necessary. So I decided to give her a tip and let bye gone be bye gone's. This same lady sarcastically returned me tip to me, telling me that she doesn't want my tip. She then asked if there is anything else she can do for me. Even if I write a bad review about a service, isn't in the managers job to correct the issue and make sure they be nice to their customer. The young blond Scandinavian lady that works there on weekends knows me very well and always smiles, talks to me and ask if there is anything else I need when I go there on weekends. At one point I started to feel as if because I'm black but I didn't let that get to me. I'm African and even though racial issue has been a big issue in United States lately, I tried playing that down. Nevertheless, this woman made made it a must to get back at me and she even told me not to come to their restaurant again. It's unlike me not to tip. I also understand it's not mandatory either but iced worked in the service industry. Although, the restaurant seems more like a family business based on the attitude of that particular waiter. I truly feel SHE DOESNT DESERVE EVERY PENNY SHE EARNS there. I do not recommend going there in a weekday but you can at your own discretion. She left a bad impression and that's why I didn't tip her. Nothing should have been taken personal. She had to wait a year and even hold a grudge against me. Who does that in the service industry.

59.description: I really miss living by this place, but it's worth the 20 minute drive. The Swedish pancakes are to die for, as is the coffee. The place is decorated in a darling way and the service is always very nice. Wasn't a fan of the swedish sausages, but that was mainly because of its looks rather than a taste - if you've ever had them served there you know what I mean. My friend and I reverted back to 16 year old girls and couldn't stop giggling when we saw them on our plate. Eggs are very fresh and the toast is tasty. Great, great value not to be missed!

21.description: I am a regular at SVEA and eat breakfast there twice a week for several years now.  The food is excellent - Swedish pancakes, popeye omelet, etc.  It is not a fancy place but is clean and very warm and welcoming and has many, many regulars.  The servers have mostly been the same people for years and give excellent service.  It is cash only and there can be a wait if you go later in the mornings on the weekend.   I highly recommend this place.

17.description: Cute little restaurant with decent food. Our waitress seemed to be in a bit of a hurry while taking our order but made plenty of time to stop and talk to another customer a little while later but other than that she was very nice. I'm deducting two stars, one for the waitress that was in a hurry and one for their hours. I wish they were open a little later. Oh, and they only take cash! Luckily my Daughter had some on her because I never carry cash!

10.description: My breakfast was good but was super disappointed in the Swedish Meatballs. They didn't have the mashed potatoes which was fine we subbed the breakfast potatoes but the meatballs were blah. Tasted like the sauce was a powder mix and the meatballs had no flavor at all. Tasted just as bad as store bought frozen meatballs. If your going to be a Swedish restaurant the signature dishes should be spot on.

5.description: No wait for Sunday brunch?  Seems a little suspicious, but we were hungry and there was Svea.  It's a cute, Swedish cafe, with close tables and a small waitstaff.  The omelettes were a solid choice, nothing special, but good hangover food and reasonably priced.  My English muffin came out a bit burnt, but there were more than enough greasy potatoes to satisfy my morning carb cravings.  The Limpa toast was nothing special, but I felt like we had to try it being in Andersonville and all.

3.description: I came here with 3 other friends and our 2 year olds. Yes, pure chaos! But this place is great, the service is fast and the food delicious.I got the Swedish pancakes with lingonberry sauce and a side of potatoes. So good! The coffee was strong and refills kept coming.The inside is really small so if you come during peak times/days expect a wait. Other than that, I will definitely be back!

35.description: Visitors of Swedish ancestors from Pennsylvania were visiting and wanted visit the Swedish American Museum. After the visit, we walked across the street to the Svea Restaurant. Our visitor ordered eggs and anchovies. My wife and I had the Swedish meatballs. Our visitor lived in Sweden for a time and thought the  eggs and anchovies were authentic Swedish, except for the addition of tomatoes and onions. The addition of mayo and dill would made the dish more authenic. The Swedish meatballs were good accompanied with mashed potatoes and gravy over two slices of rye bread. The service was prompt and efficent. The prices are inexpensive. The decor was Swedish and the Svea is a definite fixture in the Andersonville community around the Clark & Foster streets.

19.description: First I want to say I like little dives, I just like them to be clean. We were sat a dirty table with empty and used items and when we asked to wipe it down they only wiped part of it. We were handed a greasy and filthy menu and just to add to the perfect beginning, a severely sharp water cup was put in front of me. We liked their food so we decided to order to-go. Would rather not sit at a dirty table we asked twice to be wiped. While waiting for our take-out we watched as dirty plates and glasses were emptied into a sink where they placed clean water pitchers. I don't think I need to explain cross contamination. The waitress that was using the sink as a bus bin didn't even wash her hands before touching clean plates and glasses, EWW. Maybe some health codes are being broken?The food was atrocious. The potatoes tasted old and had soaked so much grease I think they were scrapings from other plates. The Swedish meatballs were undercooked and tasted odd. I have eaten here before and never had it be such a terrible experience. What happened to quality control and just plain cleanliness!? Boo on Svea, you have disappointed and we will not return. What a shame. :(

28.description: We enjoyed our very generous, piping hot breakfast items, our very friendly waitress and the unassuming (cute!) dining room. Cash only! Stop at the ATM and give em a try!

45.description: I met a friend here for brunch a couple of days ago. I was early, so I enjoyed my coffee while I waited for my friend.  The decor is so awesome. Ok, I have to admit that I'm a little obsessed with Sweden, Switzerland and Norway, so I was really charmed by the decor. Plus, the restaurant was all decked out for Christmas. I was never hurried to order while I waited for my friend and the owner kept my coffee topped off.Once my friend arrived, I ordered the Swedish pancakes with Lingonberry sauce. Yum! They arrived promptly with the sauce on the side as well as butter and syrup on the side. We sat there and chatted for a good two hours and were never hurried. On one hand, I wish they took credit cards. On the other hand, it's good they don't or I might end up here more often than I should. In any case, this place is charming and wonderful. I look forward to going back and bringing friends from out of town to show off this gem.

33.description: Don't go there in a rain storm - instead of allowing a few people to hang out in the entrance area, not blocking the entrance/exit  as it was pouring down rain they kicked us out. One family had two young children - very poor customer service. It is now blacklisted for me sorry sassy eggs!

43.description: Kitschy. Kind of tasty. Made the wife want to go to Ikea.Coffee was light but refills were fast and plentiful. Wife said orange juice tasted like the concentrated stuff out of a can. Childhood memories!Ordered the Viking breakfast. Felt like my non-existent beard wasn't red enough. Wife probably should have been wearing a busty bronze breastplace. Wait, are Swedish Vikings a thing? Google says maybe.Yelp was right, though. Viking breakfast is fit for 2, and thus makes a (relatively) cheap breakfast. Swedish pancakes are tasty. Lingonberry jam a plus, and about three-fifths healthier than IHOP HFC syrup.Swedish sausage tasted like Hillshire Farms. Wish I could've subbed for meatballs. Limpa toast tasted like rye. Turns out that's what it is. Glad my palette isn't completely shot! Eggs and potatoes were fine.Overall: a solid breakfast.

2.description: I'm new to the area, and after one visit I already know this will be one of my regular spots. It's super cute and cozy inside with table and counter seating. Be adventurous and try the pannbiff med lök, which is like a juicy bunless hamburger stopped with grilled onions, served with mashed potatoes and gravy. It really hit the spot. I can't wait to come back and try the Swedish pancakes! Service is great, but bring cash. No cards.

18.description: Kitschy. Kind of tasty. Made the wife want to go to Ikea.Coffee was light but refills were fast and plentiful. Wife said orange juice tasted like the concentrated stuff out of a can. Childhood memories!Ordered the Viking breakfast. Felt like my non-existent beard wasn't red enough. Wife probably should have been wearing a busty bronze breastplace. Wait, are Swedish Vikings a thing? Google says maybe.Yelp was right, though. Viking breakfast is fit for 2, and thus makes a (relatively) cheap breakfast. Swedish pancakes are tasty. Lingonberry jam a plus, and about three-fifths healthier than IHOP HFC syrup.Swedish sausage tasted like Hillshire Farms. Wish I could've subbed for meatballs. Limpa toast tasted like rye. Turns out that's what it is. Glad my palette isn't completely shot! Eggs and potatoes were fine.Overall: a solid breakfast.

41.description: Love a cheap breakfast joint-but the one item I had on the menu was way to Buttery or oily or whatever for my pallet (veggi omelet). Maybe the food is like this because it's a cheap dinner.Waitress seemed sort of surly upon entrance and initial greeting and seating but warmed up once she noticed I was so nice and easy going.  The restaurant was tiny and tidy-didn't understand the general theme or lack thereof but definitely felt comfortable.

52.description: Excellent $5 pancakes cannot be beat.I used to go here in college and they are still serving up Swedish without attitude or expense of the more famous Ann Sather.It is cash only, kid friendly, and prices are great.Always nice to come here, and if you cant get a table (it is not a big place) in the Sat or Sun breakfast deluge, you usually can get a seat on a stool at the 'bar'.

50.description: Not a huge menu, but they do what they do oh so well! Very cozy and tasty.

4.description: Yay Svea!  We stopped in early on a Sunday after an unexpected morning errand.  I was looking for something near where we were and also somewhere that wouldn't have an hour wait before 10am on a Sunday.  We lucked out here and got seated immediately (however, things did pick up and get busy pretty quickly after we sat down).We were quickly and warmly greeted.  I had a coffee cup from home with me when I sat down, and they nicely offered to fill that up instead of their mug when I ordered coffee (I chose theirs).  Some restaurants would have been annoyed I bought mine in, but they were very gracious about it.  I was going to try the Swedish Tease (I think that was the name of it) as I really like Swedish pancakes.  However, the smoked salmon sandwich was calling to me after I saw someone else eating it.  The smoked salmon was very simple (bread, butter, lettuce, tomato, pickle and onion on the side) and it was SO GOOD.  Really flavorful and it didn't need any other accompaniments.  I was pleased with my order and the salmon itself was nice and thinly sliced, delicious and a nice consistency (anyone who has had slimy smoked salmon knows what I mean and this was the opposite of that).I also had a bite of the ham, cheese, onion omelet - this was very good.  I typically don't love omelets, but this was perfect - cheese in every bite, a good mix of meat and veggies.  All in all, a perfect egg dish.  Breakfast potatoes were perfectly crunchy and also nice and meaty inside.  The food was simple, but delicious and I will definitely return.Cash only.  Great service, delicious food and a charming atmosphere make this a really great spot.Food - 5Service - 5Atmosphere - 5Value - 5Bathrooms - 4

6.description: This is a great little breakfast place with some unique options. The prices are very cheap (cash only). The Swedish pancakes are fantastic! Every thing else is pretty standard breakfast fare, except the potatoes are always under-cooked for some reason.

22.description: So I decided to go to this restaurant again because of their great food. This is after I have been treated unfairly by this waiter that works there during the week. As I walked in, she asked if I drove the car that was parked outside and I responded yes. The waiter was so nice to me providing cutover service more that I would ever dream of from her. I kept wondering why she decide to be nice to me. While eating away, she pulled out her phone and asked if I had wrote a review about her on Yelp. I said yes I wrote it. To bring you up to speed. This woman was so rude, mean and disrespectful to me the firs time she served me. So I left my experience on yelp. I guess she wasn't happy about that. I even mentioned I wouldn't go back to the restaurant again, unfortunately I did.So she pulled the phone out questioning me about the review and I explained to her why I wrote it. She suggested that if I knew she was so mean to me and if I knew she'll be at the restaurant at that particular time frame, I should have chose to come on a weekend while she is not there. Because of her attitude the first time she served me at the restaurant I decided not to tip her. I cannot have that sort attitude towards me and still tip. It doesn't work like that in the service industry. I say that because I have experience working in the service industry. The customer is always right no matter what. She even tried to embarrassed me in front of other customers and one particular old man tried to make me uncomfortable by sitting right next to me and stared at me. At first I just wanted to leave the restaurant, pay and walk out but I wasn't going to give them any sort of satisfaction. So I decided to stare back at him and gave him the look as if I was about to do something nasty. I guess he got uncomfortable and looked away. What kind of restaurant tries to intimidate their customers? Never heard of it. When it was time to pay, I felt bad and thought all that drama wasn't necessary. So I decided to give her a tip and let bye gone be bye gone's. This same lady sarcastically returned me tip to me, telling me that she doesn't want my tip. She then asked if there is anything else she can do for me. Even if I write a bad review about a service, isn't in the managers job to correct the issue and make sure they be nice to their customer. The young blond Scandinavian lady that works there on weekends knows me very well and always smiles, talks to me and ask if there is anything else I need when I go there on weekends. At one point I started to feel as if because I'm black but I didn't let that get to me. I'm African and even though racial issue has been a big issue in United States lately, I tried playing that down. Nevertheless, this woman made made it a must to get back at me and she even told me not to come to their restaurant again. It's unlike me not to tip. I also understand it's not mandatory either but iced worked in the service industry. Although, the restaurant seems more like a family business based on the attitude of that particular waiter. I truly feel SHE DOESNT DESERVE EVERY PENNY SHE EARNS there. I do not recommend going there in a weekday but you can at your own discretion. She left a bad impression and that's why I didn't tip her. Nothing should have been taken personal. She had to wait a year and even hold a grudge against me. Who does that in the service industry.

15.description: I had a nice basic breakfast omelet and potatoes and they substituted the bread with a nice grapefruit. Great service- very attentive and food came fast. Fun Swedish decor right in the heart of Andersonville.

57.description: If you are ever in the Andersonville area, you MUST stop at Svea! Ann Sather is much more widely known and is much overrated in my opinion. But Svea is the real deal without the fanfare.  Traditional Swedish breakfast fare includes the best Swedish pancakes you will ever have. Such a warm friendly atmosphere, filled with lots of regulars from the neighborhood, and fast service.  I could, and used to, eat here practically everyday.

20.description: Service was great. Potatoes had a nice texture. Meat was way too salty -- and I LOVE salt. The atmosphere in here is very cute, but the food is nothing spectacular.

36.description: Authentic (I think) swedish brunch. Damn delicious either way. And very cheap as well. Grew up going to this place on weekends and today I would fly in from out of state just to get breakfast here. Almost. Pancakes are the way to go, they are not like any other pancakes you've ever had. The only downside is that its a bit small and can get crowded during peak times. Just put your name in, wander around (there is a bookstore across the street) and you will be enjoying delicious nom nomz in no time!

14.description: Tiny and crowded, nothing spectacular in the eggs and toast we got here. Nice, fast service but there are better options in the neighborhood.
